We can compare the Ritz standard to the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo where we stayed two nights before moving to the Ritz - not a good choice.While Mandarin offered us a free upgrade to a corner suite we had to wait 45 minutes for the checking-in procedure at Ritz because the front desk lady tried to sell us an upgrade for 750 Euro/night to another suite. Spa is not complimentary (as at Mandarin for suite guests), everything you might expect from renting a suite costs extra. Interior of the room is not impressive, lights are by far too low and the front desk lady excused herself by saying that many guests find the suite to be to dark but organizing for an extra lamp might be to complicated. Ok, what should you expect from a room of 1.000 USD plus/night ??Unbelievable but true we tried to get a table at the window in the lobby after eating in the michelin star restaurant and we were told both evenings that this table was already payed (!) for by another guest and that's why we won't get it, though no one was there. And this is exactly how it feels to stay at this hotel: as a cash cow who should not expect extraordinary 5 star service and the friendliness you are used to from other Tokyo hotels like the Mandarin.Not to mention that I waited for 30 minutes for my omelett on Club floor during breakfast and didn't got it. Then we had to leave, very unsatisfying.Hopefully, service at Ritz at Kyoto is better, we will do a hotel check there in 1,5 weeks and after that unsatisfying experience in Tokyo we're wondering if Ritz is doing there a better job. Will let you know!

Wonderful experience and great location! This was our first stay in Tokyo and choosing Ritz Carlton was exceptional. Everything from: welcome, check-in, room, restaurants was exceptional. The staff was extremely helpful and in particular, Concierge team was great. We never felt strangers and recommendations were detailed, accurate and objective. We explored local restaurants and tried "street food", all through excellent guidance. Rooms are generous and clean, the housekeeping team was virtually unseen and yet everything is working like a clockwork. On the same trip, we stayed few nights in other five star hotels in Tokyo and Ritz Carlton will be our only choice in the future.

This is an extremely beautiful hotel I am extremely beautiful city. My partner lived in Tokyo for almost his entire life before moving to the United States in 2015. As a result, we travel to Tokyo often. The Ritz is located in Roppongi, which is in the middle of Tokyo. It is conveniently located next to the Tokyo subway; Hibiya, Oedo and Chiyoda lines. The property is immaculate with amazing views from the 45th - 53rd floors. The club lounge is spectacular. The staff are well-trained, extremely helpful and always go out of the way to assure your stay is pleasant. Because it is Japan, no gratuities are accepted. The only less than good thing I could say is stay away from the hotel's fine dining restaurant-Azure 45. It supposedly has a Michelin Star, but I strongly disagree. My partner and I made reservations in advance and requested a window table. This request was neither acknowledged nor accommodated. The "french" food was not what one would expect. Bland, no complex, flavorful cream sauces and too much nouveau foam and froth. In fact, there was emphasis on spicy, such as overly indulged in paprika. Do not let the restaurant dissuade you from staying at the Ritz. As you would expect, staying at the Ritz is not cheap, but it is overall well worth the money spent.

Hotel services, and environmental design are very considerate The front desk was very enthusiasm can be convenient to communicate in multiple languages Hope there will be more communication and understanding arrangements or the taste of food on guest for tomorrow needs（中文不能提交网上翻译的）

Stayed at Ritz Tokyo for two nights. This was the second stay for me. The room was comfortable and spacious. There was a little problem locating my suitcase that I had had delivered from another city, but not a big deal. During the first stay, I had an issue with noise coming from bathroom, ventilation noise, but I did not have that this time. The view from the room had Tokyo Sky Tree in distance. The selection of in room dining is very limited and pricy. But you can go to Midtown square and get take out or shop at super market there. It is only 5 minutes away and easy access. If you were an elite member of either Marriott or Ritz, you might want to check what privilege you might have beforehand, since they do not explain it at check-in time. I am an elite platinum member but did not find out what I can request or access to until at check-out time. Overall, it was a very relaxing stay and I recommend it!

One of the nicest hotels and rooms weve been to. Extremely expensive but i wouldnt hesitate coming again. Room was beautiful with very nice view. Staff were all nice and helpful. Drinks at the bar were good and breakfast was great.

Great Location and access to Subway is located in the Mid Town building. Conceirge can get reservations at hard to book dining locations. Rooms are very nice and they provide complimentary shoe shines.

From the beginning our stay was not ideal. We checked in by chance at exactly at the time rooms are agreed to be 'ready'; however this was clearly not the case. After being asked to wait for a 'few minutes', which amounted to just short of half an hour, we were eventually shown to our room.The room was nice, the view as expected and the amenities as one would expect from such a hotel - I imagine like something Macaulay Culkins parents would have enjoyed on their trip in the original 1990 Home Alone - however the sequel would have seen them outdated. Do fittings from 1990's qualify as classic yet?In any event, we arrived in the room, and waited. And waited. After an hour I felt as if the young gentleman who had only moments ago sincerely promised to take good care of my luggage, had not been as heartfelt as first thought. After calling reception, the bags arrived in exactly the amount of time it would take for reception to call the lobby and the lobby to think 'crap' and run the forgotten bags up to my room. The sweaty bell-man came free.After our afternoon activities, we returned to the hotel lobby and attempted to organise to eat at the hotel - something one would think is not daunting. Ha.I understand a good restaurant should be booked in advance; but this completely neglects the purpose behind having a HOTEL restaurant. The restaurant we preferred was booked out, as I'm sure you've gathered by this point, so we were suggested the other (only) available option, which was not available however until 9PM, or thereabouts. The lovely staff suggested we move to the hotel bar for the wait, which seemed like a good idea for almost all of the 20m walk across the lobby.Arriving at the bar, we were informed of the $20 US cover charge to simply, well, drink at the bar. A $20 cover charge?? Yes. You need to pay us so you can pay us to drink at our bar whilst you pay us to stay at our hotel.We sat at the bar, surrounded by drunk non-guest businessmen entertaining even drunker clients. I'm not sure exactly what point the hotel bar became a turnstile for additional-revenue - but it was clear this was at the expense of the actual hotel guests.We retired to the room to change, cancel the reservation and embark on an expedition to find somewhere else to eat, and ironically on the elevator ride out, we were accompanied by one of the large tables of loud, drunk businessmen; who occupied the bar to the same extent an insect occupies your kitchen; uninvited and certainly not paying the exorbitant rent.At a hotel of this range, the writer would have expected the level of service to go beyond simply employing good staff and toward good management, which certainly resulted in a terrible stay for us.Dear Ritz - please don't write the standard, albeit condescending, 'we're sorry for your experience' comment under this, we both know it's for the benefit of the readers/potential customers, and not mine.

The hotel is excellent - fromCheck in to the room I had an excellent stay. The front desk gave me a good room and the concierge was very helpful. I only had one real issue with the hotel. The lobby restaurant needs to prioritize hotel guests. Apparently many local housewives frequent the lobby restaurant for lunch, high tea or evening drinks. On two separate occasions I was told that I could not sit in the restaurant in the non smoking section due to reservations made. On the first occasion in the evening of my arrival I sat in the smoking section (and I hate to eat near people who are smoking for obvious reasons). On the second occasion at lunch I got a bit testy. I observed that the customers were groups of Japanese women taking the occupied tables and there were empty but "reserved" view tables throughout. So at 1pm on a weekday I can't have lunch in my own hotel lobby restaurant because locals had "reserved" tables. I told the hostess that as a hotel guest I should have priority over local housewives who occupy the main dining area for over two hours each afternoon. The hostess finally sat me at one of the "reserved" tables but the hotel needs to keep a certain number of good view tables in the non smoking section open for hotel guests. Guests pay to have the amenity and convenience of in house dining and to enjoy the view of a city that they may not visit again. Hotel guests should be treated as guests not as ones who interfere with the locals who do not pay a hefty amount for that in house amenity. Like any high end hotel if there is a wait to sit in the hotel lobby restaurant there should be a line for hotel guests and tables held open for them. Any other outside visitor should be given tables with limited views and there should be a limited number of tables designated for non hotel visitors.

I have stayed at a lot of nice hotels but the service and luxury of the Ritz in Tokyo make it to the top three overall. It's located in midtown Tokyo and close to the Shinjuku and Harajuku shopping districts. Also, close to two metro stations. From the time I checked in until the time I left, the service was impeccable. Leon Cates, the Towers restaurant Supervisor was so welcoming and helpful during my visit. He spent time telling me where I should go and assisted getting around Tokyo. He really help made my visit to Tokyo special. I can't say enough. I hope everyone gets a chance to experience the superb service of this hotel! (BTW- like all of Tokyo, it's expensive but worth it!)
user_name:
GFTraveler1
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Although I was only in town for 1 night, the staff (especially Ikuko Sato) went above and beyond to make sure I was comfortable and had another great stay while in Tokyo. Excellent facilities (especially the gym/health club), and located so close to everything I needed and wanted in Roppongi. Thanks again to the great team at the Ritz Carlton -Tokyo

It has been a seamless experience from my trip to Ritz Carlton Tokyo. This trip has been wonderful to us. We are definitely coming back for Ritz Carlton Tokyo when we returned subsequently. I am honored and thankful specifically to have Amico (hope I get her name right) from Club Lounge serving us at her highest level. From the time I step in to the time I stepped out, she has never failed to assist me and even do her upmost best to give us the best. So is the rest of the club lounge team including the supervisor Seiko. My experience at the Club Lounge surpass any other properties across the globe. I would say my first time magnificent Ritz Carlton experience. The service the team has provided is world class J Apart from the amazing club lounge staff, the house keeping were operating at tip-toe condition! They are fast and quick and this is the first time in my whole entire Ritz Carlton experience that any housekeeping staffs goes under 7mins to reach us and to attend to us immediately. It is truly a way how to keep your guest experience amazing. I would like to further my thanks to Hector who has been really helpful in my reservations and giving my guest experience first-hand via email communication. His eye for loyalty within the Ritz Carlton Platinum Members has been truly great! I would say as Reservations Director, he has been far more accommodating – attending my requests, and also give me a lending hand when needed to. Last but not the least, the bell desk and the concierge desk by far have given me an experience of a lifetime by recommendations and going back and forth without any hassle. Their recommendations were great or more than great and I am extremely happy about it.

I stayed 1 night on points at the end of my Tokyo trip. It was the best decision I could have made. I was greeted out front of the hotel, walked to the front desk by an attendant, walked to and shown around my room by a different attendant, and visited by room service soon after check-in to see how I was doing and bring me some snacks. Spent the evening in their swanky jazz lounge with my date then retired to my spacious room with a giant, panoramic, high-floor view of Midtown Tokyo that looked to be right out of Bladerunner. The lounge staff was charming and attentive. Our waiter walked us through closed areas of the hotel so we could get a look at Tokyo Skytree and take some additional photos. World-class experience. Was very sad to leave. Worth every penny and point I spent. This hotel is luxurious, modern, and well-decorated - but it's the service that puts the experience over the top!
user_name:
Bobby B
New York City, New York

review_body: Great location and staff.Perfect spot for a stay in Tokyo with kids. The hotel is directly above a subway stop; over a grocery store and a food court.The staff makes small children feel very welcome.

The hotel was centrally located. We had the greatest view of the Tokyo tower and the city! The Japanese restaurant had the most amazing food! Just wish there was a little help available to help plan sightseeing in advance.

Had a great 5 night stay here using Marriott Points. My room was clean and very quite which is very important to me. Breakfast was very good each morning at Towers restaurant. All the staff are great but the concierges deserve the award for best customer service. They were so helpful with all my questions and needs. There is a great little bar called A.bleu which is 2 blocks away that is open until 5:00 AM and serves pasta and some other dishes. The owner Aki is Japanese but speaks very good English and he's there every day which is great. The bar is in the opposite direction of Roppongi which is also great because you don't get bothered by all the touts trying to get you into girl bars while walking to and from the bar. I would recommend this hotel and stay here again.

Ritz is amazing! Gorgeous view of Mt. Fuji. Enjoy a cocktail from the best selection of Japanese and non Japanese whiskey in Tokyo! The food is wonderful as the kitchen only uses the best ingredients available locally. Prices are Ritz Carlton but I suggest if you are on a tight budget to still come and enjoy one drink and the view! No time limit on how long you can stay.

Beats competition hands down. Last two stays in Tokyo stayed at Peninsula and Mandarin Oriental. Fine hotels. Very satisfied with both (would choose Mandarin over Peninsula though). But wanted to stay in Roppongi since traveling with my daughter. No comparison. Ritz has truly exceptional comfort and service. Assistant manager helped with reservation before trip. Had a slight medical problem during trip. Reached out to hotel manager who went above and beyond to personally help resolve. Concierge service outstanding. Rooms exceptionally comfortable. Olympic size pool for laps (opens at 7; gym 24 hours). Great location (subway right below building). I've been to Japan dozens of times. Most comfortable hotel I've stayed in. Staff makes it a truly exceptional experience. Highly recommend.

A beautiful, well located property with beautiful decor and a sterling staff. Strongly recommended as one of the loveliest hotels in the world. In the center of the Roppongi area, hotel lobby is on the 45th floor with room floors above. An actual view of Mt. Fuji from our room.
user_name:
billinda2017
New York City, New York

review_body: Best hotel in which I have stayed primarily due to the service. The service here is second to none. They remembered my name since the first day I arrived. I've stayed in other hotels in Tokyo, and the service in Tokyo is the best in the world, and the service at this hotel is the best in Tokyo. The club lounge is fantastic. Thank you Ritz-Carlton.
user_name:
W9215BLdavidh
Salt Lake City, United States

review_body: Stayed here last summer as part of a tour. Without knowing what exactly the stay cost, can’t really comment on the value proposition. Have to say it meets all that can be expected of a 5-star hotel. In addition, it could be a welcome change of scenery for a foreign tourist who has been a little weary of Japanese style hotels and onsen ryokans for most of the duration of a trip, to ease back into mainstream western accommodations.Our room is luxurious and has a killer view of the city. Best hotel pool I have ever been to, a little bit like an old fashioned European resort pool, classy and actually relaxing.Location is in proximity of relatively modern area of Roppongi and Sinjuku. No ancient charm but all the food and entertainment a foreigner would ever need. You could argue this is an area depressed expat squander their youth away. The movie “Lost in Translation” came to mind as we roam the nearby streets.

Best ritz Carlton I have ever stayed at and I have stayed at least 10 ritz carltons around the worldService and facility are second to none !!I can't wait to go back there must do the club lounge the views are the best in the whole city

The hotel is great -- but its just another luxury business hotel. Hardware is the same at every Ritz Carlton, it is the service that is supposed to make this brand top-notch. Unfortunately, Ritz-Carlton Tokyo just didn't live up to it. I felt like the staff (especially the gentleman at the front desk who checked us in) thought only they themselves were "ladies and gentleman" doing us a favor by checking us in. Just an overall arrogant/haughty way of speaking down to you (maybe because English wasn't his first language?), in addition to the way that he took us to our room, but didn't introduce any facilities to us, just kind of left us at the door. The fellow at the main door downstairs was also very unhelpful when we left -- got us a taxi yes, but didn't assist in telling the driver where we wanted to go, leaving us fumbling on our mobile phones to find the address in Japanese and a phone number (so that the driver could put it in his GPS). Thanks Ritz Carlton.

Excellent service from check-in to check-out. Wonderful views from Mt Fuji in the distance to the city skyline with Tokyo Tower close by. First class rooms, service, restaurants, fitness center and business center. Club lounge is one of the best!

Stayed 2 nights at the RC Tokyo, brilliant location and amazing views, very spacious hotel rooms and large bathrooms. Lobby lounge has amazing views and live music each evening. Walking distance to many local cafes, restaurants, shops and bars. Service Level - Reception & lobby lounge area only - slightly unorganized, slightly arrogant and my family was made to feel 2nd class during our stay. However the service in the club level lounge area was exceptional so I am confused as to why we didn't feel this service level elsewhere.I was actually staying at the hotel to complete a conference site inspection for a very large group in August 2017. Sadly the hotel didn't tick all of the boxes required to host our event. Word of warning - if you are considering this hotel as a conference venue a proposal offered in writing can change without notice & without any form of decent communication. I experienced Unprofessional & unethical dealings with hotel management. I was forced to book our large conference event at another luxury hotel. I hope this message might assist someone in the future if you are considering this property.

As you'd expect. Hospitality, cleanliness, rooms - all excellent! We had a great room with a view of Mt. Fuji, unfortunately it was foggy every day so we never got a clear shot. We had a wonderful experience with the concierge desk and lots of great recommendations. Highly recommend

Rooms are spacious, and well laid out with comfy beds, luxurious bathrooms and picture window views over Tokyo city. Staff are professional, efficient, courteous and helpful. The Business centre and conference facilities are very good and the food served was excellent. Service was also very good in the Lounge . A very good all round hotel experience.

Great hotel, expensive so you expect the best. Rooms were very clean and lounge was good. Was a little too busy at times and had to wait for table at breakfast. Also smoking in the bar but it is Tokyo! Would go again. Lovely views that high up.

We just spent two nights at the Ritz Hotel in Tokyo. Our room was on the 53rd floor and the view was amazing. The room was spacious and really nice. We used the club a lot and the staff was exceptional! We had dinner in Tosca and the food and service was unbelievable.I think what I loved the most was how I was treated by every employee at the hotel.I also loved the location of the hotel. `It is in a great area and the mall that it is attached to is very nice as well.I highly recommend the Ritz in Tokyo.

Be aware of the spa. Anywhere in the world, you walk into a 7 star hotel spa, no spa is going to charge you an additional usage for the facility!! This spa literally charges 12,420 yen on top of your treatment which was 28,000yen !!! I was thinking I'd get a nice 60minute massage for around $300, and ended up paying close to $500!? Unbelievable!!!! Other wonderful spa facilities such as Mandarin Oriental with TOP notch service was a whole lot more reasonable than this.

Second time at a Ritz Carlton and first time in Tokyo. The overall experience was fantastic and the views are simply astonishing. Views of the whole city and surroundings, my friend on another room could see Mt. Fuji!

My wife and I stayed there for three nights on the club level. The service was very good and the food in the lounge was great. I loved the breakfast. My favorite part of the hotel was the gym. It's got a lot of different equipment and the view of the Mount Fuji is not too shabby while working out. On the negative side we had dinner at the Japanese restaurant and it was not good.

Had a wonderful stay at the Ritz Carlton Tokyo. Great, friendly and accommodating staff. They anticipate your every need. The concierge was very helpful in making restaurant recommendations are reservations and directions too. The hotel itself is beautiful. The lobby lounge has a great view of the city. The rooms and bathrooms are well-appointed, comfortable and clean. We had a view of the city and Mt. Fuji in the background! The hotel connects to the MIdtown Tower, where you have tons of restaurant choices, shops and a supermarket. The hotel is also very close to the subway station. Would highly recommend staying here.

Just a great hotel which is faultless but at a price. For special occasion or business. Staff are just the best, polite as you would expect but also friendly & charming. Great bar areas & breakfast is a must. The Earthquake warning system is reassuring.

This property was centrally located and easy to get around by taxi (many of them waiting outside). We had a club room here for 4 or 5 days and it was absolutely wonderful. If I was to book again - I would get the same type of room with Club Access. Everyday we had breakfast, dinner and snacks in the club room. As an added plus, the staff members could remember what my girls liked to drink as well as my husband and mother-in-law.

This was our first visit to Japan and hence our first stay at this hotel as well. The level of personalized service is excellent and the rooms were extremely nice. If you can, do no not pass up the club level!!!

Love the Ritz Carlton, whilst still preferring the Park Hyatt. This one is superbly located in the center of the city with amazing views. The Spa is great as well and the rooms are very spacious. Only downside is the prices for any extra, yes it is a Ritz Carlton but that does not mean that everything has to be x3! Just to give you a flavor, the lowest priced local Japanese Wine at the bar cost as much as a bottle of Moet champaign 45 floors down in Roppongis most crowded and popular bars! Otherwise nothing to complain, but if you are a fan of fresh air don't go into any of the Japanese skyscraper hotels as there is nowhere a window :-)

First time try and soooo impressed by the room size & facilities. Wonderful view from the room i can see the tokyo tower & tokyo skytree .. wowI personally love the pool and gym whice located on the same floor to a spa.Lobby is on the higher floor by thta time i check in was quite crowded and took time.Over all was a nice stay.

We booked the hotel from Booking.com for a club room, and luckily upgraded to a club Tower room in the corner, and the view in the view was the best among Tokyo, that we can enjoy two different sides of Tokyo: the Tokyo Bay with Tokyo tower side, and the Skytree side. Each side of view was spectacular, but we enjoyed the Tokyo Bay most. The service of Ritz-Carlton Tokyo is absolutely impecctable, from the pick-up of bellboy, check-in and club room service and in the breakfast restaurant, we enjoyed the sincerity of the staffs very much, some of them could even called our names. Although overall the design is older than expected but well-maintained. It is no doubt one of the best hotel in Tokyo.

The Ritz-Carlton Tokyo is a stylish 5 star hotel. Conveniently located above a shopping centre and with underground access directly below the hotel. The rooms were beautifully appointed and we were able to book connecting rooms in advance which is great when travelling with young children. We were blown away by the staff - who were amazing with everything from booking restaurants, cars, and in particular, the concierge staff, who even helped us plan a birthday party for our daughter in Niseko - booking a restaurant and organising a birthday cake. Directly below the hotel there is a great supermarket in the shopping centre - perfect for snacks and necessities, as well as a Dean + Deluca for take away coffee. The hotel has incredible views of Mount Fuji - and a lovely sense of understated luxury. Its location, away from the main tourist sites wasn't a problem, as the underground is a quick and convenient way of getting around the city. Top Tip - take a private walking tour - its a fantastic way to get a hands on experience of the city taking in all the major sites (Shibuya, temples, shopping etc) with a local guide.

Ritz Carlton Tokyo is an exceptional hotels Their ladies and gentlemen are the very best in the hotel industry. I was impressed with the staff and the beautiful room I had. Wasn't just cleaned it looked brand new. Thank you Ladies and Gentlemen for making my first experience in Tokyo an amazing one.
user_name:
wsantiag0
New York City, New York

review_body: We had a great overall guest experience at this hotel. Leon and his team at Towers do a great job, as do the concierge and front desk teams. Very personalized and professional service. Special thanks to John R. and Ikuko S. for helping us to enjoy a fantastic room on our special occasion. Overall a really fantastic stay experience, we'd recommend highly, this hotel.

I had myself fetched at the airport using one of the high end vehicles of the hotel and it was very pleasant. They had a liaison waiting for me at the arrival (despite my flight being delayed for 2 hours) and the driver greeted me with a very warm smile! I was greeted with excellent hotel staff up until I got to my room. Everything was swell except the quality of the breakfast menu and checking out.

Ritz Carlton Tokyo is one of the most luxury experience that I have had with hotel accommodation. Both the "hardware" and the "software" are at top rate. The service was very heart warming. I shall return to this hotel again with my family next time.

We booked a deluxe room with a king bed but were upgraded to a Tokyo deluxe which had two double beds. Looking at the website, it looks as though the size of the rooms would be the same though - and when I talk about size, I mean big. The beds were super comfortable and there was a huge television for us to watch those crazy Japanese shows at night.The bathroom was incredible. I only wish we stayed there longer so we could make better use of it! Large bath, separate shower with two different showerheads (one of which is a rainwater head), two separate sinks and even a TV!The views from the room were exceptional.As we were only there for one night I can't comment on many of the restaurants but we did spoil ourselves and enjoy a degustation with matched wines at Azure 45. Boasting a Michelin Star this is certainly not a cheap eat, but well worth it if you'd like the treat yourself. Attentive staff, an incredible view of Tokyo Tower (ask for a table by the window if possible) and a mouth-watering array of food.Staff at the hotel are very helpful with everything and will bend over backwards to ensure your stay is comfortable. The area surrounding the hotel (which includes a nice park) defies the Japan stereotype of small, squishy and packed with people. Much more spacious than other major parts of Japan and quite affluent - I would need two hands to count how many Ferraris were around!If you can afford it, an exceptional place to stay!

The attention to detail was the first part of a great stay! The room was fantastic and the service was second to none! Great place and great staff! The bar offered one of the best views of the Tokyo skyline and at night it was a phenomenal view. The room also offered a great view of the Imperial Gardens and the Skytree! What can I say? The Ritz Carlton lived up to its name! Will be back!

The Ritz-Carlton sits at the top of one of Tokyo's tallest buildings and has great views of the city. Our room was very large and well maintained. The bathroom comes with many amenities, although soap and shampoo supplied were meagre for a hotel of this quality. Service is very good and the staff are friendly and obliging. The pool and spa are especially nice. The bar has the same spectacular views as the rooms but we were disappointed in food quality there. Location is very convenient and the shops in the complex are high quality. Lots of dining choices in the immediate area. You can pick up some of the city's expensive but very enjoyable berries and melons. Overall very pleased with the Ritz-Carlton Tokyo and I would definitely return.

Have stayed at the Ritz Carlton in Tokyo more than 10 times over the last few years on business and holiday. Really love this hotel. Excellent location at the top of the wonderful Midtown tower in Roppongi which is well connected to the Tokyo metro system (everything is close: Shibuya, Omotesando, Ginza, Marunouchi are all a few stops away). The hotel is on the top floor of midtown tower with wonderful views from the lobby and all rooms. Rooms are really spacious with huge bathrooms, super king size bed and seating area by the panoramic window. Everything is well thought out and well fitted. Nespresso and excellent tea in the room, great wifi and connections, flat screen TV. Quality materials. The gym is fantastic with a huge pool and fitness space with a view. The breakfast room is wonderful with amazing quality food. Perhaps one of the best breakfasts I've had. The bar and lobby have nightly jazz-style entertainment. Best of all is the service. The staff is very professional. Everything works well in this hotel. I've also stayed at the ritz in Kyoto and Osaka and I think the ritz Carlton group is doing something right in japan. Quality of management is excellent. Always look forward to going back to the Ritz Carlton Tokyo!

excellent staffs and services!! We felt like a guest of the city! We have a view to the Tokyo Tower which made us a fabulous night to stay in Tokyo as the last night of the entire trip. Cosy and chilled lobby with a band performance at our visit. Location is good for those by car or taxi.

The Ritz Carlton Hotel in Tokyo is the place to stay if you are looking for a superb experience. The property is magnificent, the staff could not be more welcoming and helpful, the food delicious and the location fabulous. My favorite hotel in the world by far.

Everything was perfect. The staff were amazingly amazing. Unfortunately, breakfast area were extremely small and not much of varieties to choose. If you wish to have your breakfast from 8 o'clock onwards, you must wait in the line for the table which could takes around half an hour.

Upon arrival to the Ritz Carlton Tokyo we were welcomed as if we were home. Check in was truly fun as we were whisked away to the 53rd floor and made comfortable in the Club Lounge. Before our drinks arrived Ikuko Director of rooms arrived to greet us (she’s amazing) then introduced us to Valter who took care of all our paperwork. Our room was large, spotless and had all the amenities one would want. The bathrooms a delight with dual sinks, soaking tub and my absolute favorite shower. The walk-in shower is large with both a hand sprayer and overhead rainforest fixtures. Beds, sheets, towels all luxury.  The Ritz Carlton is located in the Roppongi area with a Metro station just a few steps away. The Tokyo Metro subway system is convenient and goes everywhere. Be sure to get a Pasmo or Suica prepaid card (reloadable) to make it easy to just jump on and off trains. The Midtown Galleria Mall is directly below the Ritz hotel with a great selection of stores and dining options. There’s even a high end grocery store called Precce in the mall. Roppongi is loaded with great attractions by day or night. Tokyo or Shinagawa stations are a short cab or Metro train ride away and very convenient to get to the Shinkansen (Bullet train) which is a must do. The Club Lounge the Concierge to us Marriott Elites is second to none. The service is truly amazing, the staff is extremely attentive and speak perfect English. We were having trouble getting wifi on our phones and Leo jumped in and got us online in seconds Kudos’ Leo! Amazing views of Mt Fuji and Tokyo. The Club Lounge has several rooms our favorite was the Library. Food options were tasty we were also able to have breakfast in Towers on the 45th floor. The buffet and full service menus featuring western and Japanese dishes was simply delicious. Be sure to try the Perfect Egg. The sunrise over Tokyo Tower was truly spectacular do yourself a favor and get there early for sunrise at least once. You really need to treat yourself to the Club Lounge level. The spa and fitness center staff was great and the equipment received high marks from my wife. The view from the treadmills was spectacular to say the least. The pool has to be seen to believe! The front desk staff was attentive and very helpful converting currency, making Limo bus reservations, looking up phone numbers. Same great service with the Concierge Team. The overall atmosphere and dedication demonstrated by the staff is something every hotel should take note of. Getting there is easy from Narita airport the Limousine bus will take you to the front door of the Ritz Carlton for 3100 Yen or the Narita Express train which is quicker but you have to deal with your luggage to Tokyo or Shinagawa station then take a cab or a metro subway.  As with our visits prior Ikuko made it a point to come say goodbye and thank us. The only bad part is leaving this piece of Paradise.

Good location and good service . Requested for connecting room and smoking floor . Staff are bery friendly and spoken good english l. Very helpfull and quick responds. Try the japanese restaurant , it's good service and good food

The property is at center convenience location and with many night activities and restaurants and mall opens late hours with quiet 5 minutes walk from hotel. The hotel price on this property was reasonable.

For seasoned travellers that require a flawess hotel experience you can fault the Ritz Carlton Tokyo. While the location is convenient it's the staff and the attention to detail that make it an ideal base to call home regardless if you are staying for business or pleasure. Thre's no doubt any Oceana guest will rave about the amazing Leon in the breakfast room, you will find that each team member is extemely skilled and professional - our children still treasure the oragami gifts they received at breakfast. Mariko (excuse the spelling) was so helpful on concierge, especially given I was less organised on this trip given a busy work load. Nothing was painful and she gave us all the tools to get around. The rooms are amazing and very large. The Children's safari experience is so gorgeous I could cry. The staff members at the pool and fitness centre were very helpful and welcoming and engaged our children and made them also feel welcome. The views from the spa/fitness centre and pool are unbeatable and on a clear day you can see Mount Fuji. I can't thank the hotel enough for the lovely stay. We will see you again soon.

Our stay here was perfect. The service was above and beyond. The location was excellent. The room and the view was amazing. The hotel is above a mall with lots and lots of food. There is even a 24 hour Supermarket that we can just run down anytime a grab a snack. Will definitely stay here again.

This hotel is situated in a great spot for exploring Tokyo. It is a simple walk away from Roppongi and Midtown, where you can find restaurants and cool shops. There was always taxis outside if you needed one to get anywhere too. From the moment we arrived, the service was excellent. The receptionists helped us create a plan for getting to the airports for restaurants and for getting to the airport which was very helpful.The views are magnificent. From practically anywhere in the hotel, there are large windows with sweeping views of Tokyo's skyscrapers, which is breathtaking at night. My only qualm is that one of the bar and hangout areas allows smoking. I felt uncomfortable in this area, but I suppose if you're a smoker you will have the opposite feelings.I would definitely stay here again, and look forward to it!

The Tokyo Ritz Carlton is quite literally what one expects - The Ritz: Grand, opulent, charming, all in a way that would speak to an older generation rather than the younger types who prefer their dose of luxury packaged in a more minimalist way. The attention to detail and impecable service by the personnel place it squarely in the major hospitality league where it rightfully belongs - and the only league it should be in considering the price. The hotel's restaurants and the breakfast buffet serve wonderfully prepared dishes, both Japanese and western. The rooms are impecably clean, with furnishings in classic, laquered wood, invoking a modern art-deco look (albeit somewhat dated, with a patina left by years of use slowly becoming evident). The panoramic views of Tokyo are stunning and worth every cent (we had a standard double on the 48th floor). Where Ritz had me puzzled however was in the most unexpected places, and by things that clearly belonged in an establishment with fewer stars and lower prices. For one, we were asked to pay an additional 50'000 yen per person (about usd 40) to be able to use the sauna/steam room facilities at the spa (the swimming pool was free) - something simply preposterous given the 1'200 USD price tag of the room. Charging extra for basic spa facilities simply doesn't belong to a hotel of this level. Neither does being put on a waiting list to get a table at breakfast. Whether this happened because tables had already been taken by external guests or because there wasn't enough tables to accommodate all of the hotel guests in the first place - I don't know, but the closest association a line of hungry people waiting to have breakfast invokes in my mind is an all-inclusive Club Med resort. It's these relatively small things that kept us wondering whether the hotel is simply trying to maximize revenue (and diluting its brand in the process), or whether it's fallen on hard times and needs the extra cash - which with places such as the new Aman, Hyatt and the Peninsula making for formidable competition wouldn not be surprizing. Either way, we'll be booking elsewhere for our next trip to this stunning city.

We used the Ritz Carlton Tokyo as the base for our first visit to Tokyo. The hotel is ultramodern and occupies the top floors of one of the tallest buildings in Tokyo. The view from the lobby and the rooms puts you in the middle of a vista from a science fiction movie, with an endless city in most directions and Mt Fuji -- if you are lucky -- rising in the distance.Service was exceptional. We are not the most demanding hotel guests in terms of our service expectations, but we were surprised -- in a positive way -- on a couple of occasions. Upon check in, for example, we were presented with the appropriate personalized documents before presenting any identification. Did the woman who greeted us at the car entrance open up our luggage tags and radio our names to the lobby 45 floors above? Perhaps, but it was all seamless and invisible. Every day when we came back from a day of wandering around Tokyo, we would be met in the lobby by a greeter who inquired about our day and gave us advice for the next day.The rooms are excellent, with no evidence of any element showing any sign of age or wear. Room service was excellent and punctual. On the morning of one of our stays, we experienced a substantial (M6.9 or M7.3 depending on who you ask) earthquake that caused the whole building to slowing sway for a couple of minutes. Room service still arrived exactly on time, about 30 minutes later.The sushi restaurant at the hotel is outstanding. It is not inexpensive, but that was not a surprise. It was probably our favorite meal in Japan, with the possible exception of a many course kaiseki meal that we had a few days later in a ryokan.Tokyo is such a sprawling city with no well-defined center that we weren't sure the best location to use as a base for exploration. The Ritz-Carlton worked extremely well. We had easy subway access in every direction.For us -- an American couple looking to explore Tokyo -- the Ritz was an outstanding choice.

The hotel is amazing with tremendous service. The hotel has great views and pretty fun lobby with nightly musical entertainment. The concierge was also very helpful in recommending places for meals and to visit.

This hotel is up to the general Ritz Carlton standards and is what you expect of a city skyscraper modern hotel. There are excellent views and staff everywhere to help.Only major downside here was that they allowed smoking in the lobby and even from the non-smoking section you could smell it. I was very surprised by that and even if in Japan that is legal/allowed, I never stayed at a nice Western brand hotel there that allowed it or didn't successfully mask the smell.Small other quibbles were that the bathroom was not as modern as sister Ritz Carlton properties in Japan (the tv felt a bit dated among other things) and turn down wasn't as consistently thorough like I've noticed at other comparable hotels where they might fold some items and stack them. The concierge was responsive though two small things were that one restaurant they said was open on NYE was in fact closed and they wouldn't send names of suggestions in advance (perhaps preferring to do face to face for better service but it allowing me to do my own research in advance of checking in). The pedestrian entrance also is a bit underwhelming and a small labyrinth to access the elevators to the lobby (the car entrance on the other hand is what you'd expect). That said we had a wonderful stay here. They certainly recognized the hotel loyalty status and overall tried to be as helpful as possible.I'd consider coming back here.

Having stayed at many of the top hotels in Tokyo, and other parts of the world, everything at the Ritz Carlton Tokyo (service, décor, rooms, view, etc.) was top notch. I recommend this hotel for all occasions (business, couples, family).

Great location with top notch service. We were unexpectedly delayed on our trip to Hokaido stranded by cancelled flights due to snow. We fortunately were able to make the best of our misfortune with two wonderful days in central Tokyo at the Ritz.

Theres not much to say here that hasn't been said already. It is a Ritz Carlton after all and there is a standard of service that one generally expects with that. The Tokyo property does not disappoint in this regard. This property provides the best level of service, staff and amenities that we have every experienced.The lobby is on the 45th floor and the rooms go up from there so no matter what side you are on you are guaranteed breathtaking views.Treat yourself to an airport pick-up or drop-off the property concierge will book for you in their Rolls Royce Phantom. Nothing quite like it.We would recommend this property to anyone and will not hesitate to stay here again on our next visit to Tokyo.

We stayed at the Ritz Carlton in Tokyo for two nights and enjoyed every minute of it. From the time we entered we were greeted from the staff and escorted to our room upon checkin. The room and the bathroom were large, clean and modern. The staff left a tray of macaroons which was a nice touch. Throughout our our stay the staff was gracious and pleasant, offering everything from luggage assistance to help with directions to complimentary water bottles.Breakfast was included in our package and was well worth it. The Ritz offered both American and Japanese breakfast items, and everything was delicious. I highly recommend the Ritz Carlton, you will not be disappointed.

Just finished a fabulous 5 nights stay to celebrate X'mas at RC Tokyo, from check in to check out all things went to very smooth & professional. The hotel is situated at top of Midtown shopping mall (with a 24hr supermarket Precce) & surrounding area of Roppongi, Aksaska got hundreds different restaurants & bars are very convenient. The room is spacious, my one at the 49th floor with the most beautiful Mount Fuji sunset view, I too loved everyday starting 4:30pm drank sake with the splendid window sunset scene. The bed is extremely comfortable compared to the others. Although the room is not the modernest & newest in town, but the service could be one of the best with RC reputation.

I spent two nights there after two nights at Prince Gallery hotel. The Ritz Carlton is a very nice hotel as is the Prince Gallery. I would rate it one star below the prince Gallery which is brand new and slightly more modern. That being said Ritz Carlton room (on 51st floor) had an amazing view of the Tokyo Bay, and most features we experienced ad Prince Gallery. The bathroom was very large with two sinks and a great shower. The gym is nice too, so is the pool. The hotel offers a "heating experience" which consists of an onsen, a cold bath, a sauna, and hammam. The breakfast was also very nice but less food options than at Prince Gallery. The hotel is in Roppongi, good area for nightlife and shopping.

My family and I loved this hotel. The very best service you will find. Even found us a few spectacular hole in the wall eateries that I suspect almost no one who stays at this property is looking for.

I never thought of myself with a traveller with a lot of needs from hotel staff. I can usually wheel my own bag, I know how to google things, I've been in enough hotel rooms to figure out the various buttons and where to look for the hairdryer. So I never understood what all the fuss was about service. Then I went to Japan by myself and stayed at the Ritz-Carlton Tokyo. Mariko and all of the concierge staff there helped me with relentless patience as I worked to get Michelin-starred reservations way too late in the game and did assemble a wonderful eating itinerary in the end. I left a raincoat there and Osamu Ishikawa delivered it personally that same afternoon to my new hotel (switched just to be at the train station for an early morn) when all I did was reach out to see if they had it. It's like they have mastered the art of making you want them to help you. I feel I am not doing it justice in this description but I appreciated it so much and it really set the tone for a wonderful vacation.Also the view is awesome, from the lobby and my amazingly upgraded room. The cocktails were fun and seasonal. The location was perfect. I miss this place so much!

After staying a few days at The Park Hyatt, we moved to the Ritz Carlton. The hotel is on the top floors of the largest building in Tokyo. We were upgraded and given a corner room with Tokyo Tower View. This was a about a 270 degree view of Tokyo. Super amazing view of both Tokyo Tower and Tokyo Sky Tree. Check in was very easy and extremely welcoming. The room was large and clean. Huge closet. Spacious bathroom with all the amenities. Two comfy beds. Small sitting area. Did I mention the view? The hotel is very nice and certainly in the top tier of Ritz Carlton's. The service was exceptional. Someone was always there to help or ask questions to but never obtrusive. Japanese hospitality at its finest. The food was good but I only ate breakfast here. The pool was very nice and does have an adjacent hot tub that you could use without having to buy into the Spa. I did like how the Park Hyatt did give a one time complimentary pass to their beautiful spa. I can not comment on the spa here as I was not going to spend $50 to check it out. One asset to this hotel over TPH was the location. The hotel is attached to Tokyo Midtown which is a high end mall with plenty of places to eat. There is a 24hr super market too. All while being above a metro station. Roppongi can get seedy at night but so is Shinjuku. Seedy in the way that people will try to solicit you for whatever. I never felt for my safety anywhere in Japan. I can't say that I had any affinity to either area of Tokyo though. This is an exceptional hotel with an excellent "immediate" location. I would not hesitate to book here again. I did like Roppongi over Shinjuku. Other luxury brands are also located in the Ginza area, but found that area to close down after normal business hours. It is a ghost town after 6pm.  Tokyo is so big with so many sections of town and plenty of places to stay. The Ritz was a perfect place to have a base of operations. With its convenience to transportation shopping and restaurants, I would not hesitate returning.

Was thinking the Ritz will set a higher standard after coming from another hotel. First was confirmed on the phone that we were upgraded to a suite, only to be told on arrival we weren't. Was here for a special occasion and i couldn't sense if they actually cared about the occasion or our stay. Apart from a personalised note from John their president, nothing else was asked. Felt very commercialised and as i just checked out from the front desk, no one bothered to ask about my stay (a simple question that even 4 star hotels will ask), hence i don't even get a chance to share my feedback. At least for me and wife, we didn't feel the service that all the others are raving about. I won't be recommending this hotel unless you want to claim that you have stayed in the Ritz here before. For the price i paid there are plenty of other hotels that offer much better personalised service with much more modern amenities. Won't be coming here again.

I'd like to thank the staff for the impeccable service. Every person with whom I spoke was incredibly kind and professional.The spacious rooms meet the highest standards, and the view from the rooms (all of the, I believe) is fantastic.

I have traveled and slept in many hotels, the Ritz-Carlton Tokyo is probably the best combination of facilitates (room, lobby, restaurants, location) and service (front desk, concierge, room service, house keeping). Just outstanding on all counts. Even a few days before check in I was in communication with the front desk to arrange some special events for me and wife - all was done as promised and when expected. Japan is high service level across but the team at the Ritz is taking it to another level. Great stay, thanks.

If it was location, service, views, room decor or views from your room, this is second to none. Its high rise, clouds float by. Some rooms give you the view to Mt. Fuji. Close to great shopping without getting outside if its raining.Great WiFi, great breakfast, breathing bar views, cigar section and a hotel with a soul. I have stayed over 20 years in Tokyo and this is the best.It dies not have a business centre but front office have helped me print and book tickets to the movies nearby.

Arrived at the Ritz, met at the door by courteous staff who welcomed us by name and guided us to the elevator to the Club level check in which is on the top floor (53th floor). You realize quickly that you are now on the highest floor in the tallest building in Tokyo with Ahhhmaaaazing views of Tokyo below! The club lounge staff were always at your beck and call to pour you drinks, serve you breakfast or cook up afternoon snacks, or in our case arrange tour guides and make restaurant reservations. Our room was right down the hallway from the lounge. The rooms are very clean and modern as you would expect in this building and the large windows allow you to see what is in my opinion the best view from any hotel in any large city in the world! This is a real 5 star hotel! So our first morning we awoke to a 7.2 earthquake that hit Fukushima! I am from California so I have lived thru several large earthquakes and this one was crazy to experience at the top of a 53 story building!! The whole room/building was rolling from side to side and the only thing I kept thinking as I grabbed the handy battery flashlight from the moving closet was this building must be on rollers and theres no place id rather be for this than inside this room! After a minute or two of rocking around i couldn't believe we still had electricity and water and no alarms went off. Everything was good so we stayed in the room for 4-5 hours waiting to see if our tour guide for the days tour of Tokyo arranged by the hotel would be downstairs at the agreed hour of 8am??Well sure enough our tour guide texted us that yes she would be late.....5 minutes late only! Wow ok so its safe lets go explore. The Japanese restaurant in the hotel has a super Teppanyaki service with excellent (and expensive) Kobe beef among other things like a sushi bar. The hotel complex is on top of the Midtown Shopping mall with all sorts of stores and food outlets in addition to a subway station. This hotel is in a "nice" expensive area in what is central to all other neighborhoods you might want to explore. We spent every day out exploring including a day trip to Kyoto on the bullet train so our activities at the hotel mainly consisted of daily breakfast in the club lounge (excellent and extensive selections), occasional room service (fast fast fast), and sleeping in a comfortable bed. If you can afford the club level I would highly suggest it and Id suggest this hotel in general if you want extra high level attention to detail expected in a 5 star hotel. P.S. booked via Amex FHR and got a 4th night free promo.

Upon arriving, I was whisked away to a magnificent lobby, made even more enchanting by the Christmas choir and 10-foot tree that lay at the center of a luxurious-looking Christmas party. The staff was on hand to run circles around me, whilst they simultaneously checked me in and arranged for my luggage to be brought to my room before I knew what was happening. The front desk and concierge team were both exceedingly joyful and professional at the same time, and the hotel manager even came to personally thank me for choosing to stay with them. I travel for work, and stay in hotels for approximately 150-200 nights a year--the service I experienced at this Ritz Carlton before, during, and after my stay--was entirely unmatched.My girlfriend and I were upgraded to a stunning executive suite and were extremely impressed by both the room and the spectacular views it provided to Chiyoda, Shinjuku, and Mount Fuji (which was particularly beautiful the sunny morning after we arrived). The bathroom, in particular, was on the more luxurious side of the hotel rooms I have seen!The hotel is conveniently located so as to be only a short taxi (or train) ride from Shinjuku, the Imperial Palace, and many of Tokyo's other iconic landmarks and districts. Additionally, it is only a short, 15 minute walk from Roppongi Hills and all that lie in that area.When I make my way back to Tokyo, I see no way around returning to the Ritz Carlton. It was truly one of the best hotel experiences I've had to date.

this hotel is located at the 9 floor from the top of midtown tower. the view is excellent. the room space is larger than the hong kong one that I've stayed.The swimming pool also bigger than the Hong Kong one.one of the best hotel in tokyo japan

We celebrated our sons 40th birthday in Tokyo and had a booking of three rooms at the 49th floor! First day we had a snowstorm, but staying in the Hotel was very comfortable! Next day we saw the Fuji!The service from the staff is outstanding!The Club Service was fantastic! We had such a help to settle some bookings from Mr Valter Goncalves and he took so much care of all of us! A big Thank you!We come back!
user_name:
Susangermany
New York City, New York

review_body: I recently stayed at the Ritz for 6 nights on business.PROS: -- The room was beautiful and well equipped with toiletries, tea, bottled water, etc. And the view of Mt. Fuji (on a clear day) was spectacular. -- The Roppongi location was very convenient and there is a subway stop in the next building which is very convenient. -- Sushi at the hotel's sushi bar was a highlight of the trip, although the prices are insanely high and that's saying a lot when you're on an expense account... -- The gym was also nice and I enjoyed the steam room and whirlpool area which also has had fantastic views. I believe this is an additional $50USD / day depending on your room rate/Marriott status.The main reason I gave this 4 stars instead of 5 is that I found the concierges a bit lacking in information (or perhaps things were lost in translation). We wanted to go to the market at Meiji Shrine and they emphasized that we MUST get there early because it opened at 4am and the shops closed by noon. We did get there early-ish 8 am), only to find that the shops didn't open until 10 am. We also tried getting restaurant recommendations from the concierges and didn't have much luck in that regard either. At a Ritz, my expectations would be for a concierge to be able to give accurate information and good recommendations.
user_name:
MissEinDC
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: The Ritz Tokyo is everything you would hope for in a Ritz. It has a great location, great amenities and a very attentive staff. The bar is always active and the views are impressive - best in the city! I would stay here again anytime I was visiting Tokyo. The property was meticulous and the staff all lived up to the expectations I would have for the Ritz. The Ritz mid town is definitely the go to hotel for Tokyo.

After a rough start, everything got into place and it got better and better. Communication is a must :-)The service is perfect, the food is very good. Although there are not enough options for vegeterians, the service provided by the staff is so good it compensate for that lack. Being a non meat eater, I am very picky when it comes to what goes into my body and the staff, the chef and everyone else working there was always making sure that the food met my expectations. The View at the lounge is spectacular and so relaxing!!! great stay , highly recommended. The Ritz is the Ritz, you can't top their top notch service :-)
user_name:
MyriamClk
New York City, New York

review_body: The location and service is the best in the Tokyo Mid Town area. You will be treated like royalty- but made to feel like family and at home with everything you wanted but forgot to get to make your stay wonderful. It is a place that once you arrive - you don't want to leave but stay on for many more days to come.

This was the first stop on our first visit to Japan. Checking in on the Club Floor after a twelve hour transpacific flight on JAL (an exceptional airline, but that's another story) was efficient and welcoming. The Hotel's aesthetic, while contemporary and incorporating all the modern conveniences, is also very much of its locale. Artwork, water features and floral displays make the public areas inviting. And the views from 40+ stories up are as impressive as you'd expect, when the clouds clear (which, sadly for us, was somewhat rare - but when they do... wow!). In opting for a Club Floor Room, the additional food & beverage amenities provided in the Lounge from morning to evening (refreshed & scheduled to day-part) were some of the finest and most extensive we've ever experienced. Our room (a "Deluxe") was spacious, comfortable and well laid-out. Top notch bedding, seating and lighting. And the bathroom, an unqualified happy-face from "the Missus" for the mirrors, counter space and illumination options (and yes, the commode is indeed a technological marvel). But what really makes this place special is the Staff! Far beyond simple courtesy (which, in itself, is sadly becoming a rarer commodity), the various people we interacted with really seemed to take pride in their work and be personally invested in providing exceptional service! To the men at the door (who never failed to inquire whether we needed directions/transport/umbrellas as we went out), to the Concierges (who provided us with insightful & practical guidance and well-recommended restaurant reservations) to the teams at the various Lounges and Desks (who invariably greeted us with smiles and seemed truly interested in our experiences and assisting us) - may we say "Domo Arigato Gozaimasu"! Our stay at the Ritz-Carlton Tokyo was one of the best hotel experiences we've had to date! On returning to Tokyo, we'd absolutely look forward to staying here again.

From the time we walked in to the time we checked out, the custom service is top-notched. The room is beautiful and very spacious with a huge bathroom with two separate sinks. The city view is beautiful at night. We were welcomed with some goodies (chocolates) in the room. It's everything we expected from a 5 star hotel.Service:The concierge and personnel are very attentive. We were greeted every time we pass by them. We wanted to visit Karuizawa during the day. The lady at the concierge not only provided us with useful information (e.g. type of clothes we need to wear, train schedule) but also printed out the train schedule with all of the available trains to and from Karuizawa. We really appreciate it as it was a bit of a challenge for us to see which train we could take without a reserved seat.Location:The hotel is located in Roppongi, which is a nice area. The neighborhood has lots of restaurants (e.g. Ichiran ramen). It's also conveniently located right above the metro line (Marunouchi Line, Hibiya Line) and Toei Line station (Oedo Line), though it was a bit confusing at first when exiting the metro and trying to find the hotel. Just follow the sign of the hotel or ask someone. For us, I believe that Ginza has more to do and to see than Roppongi. However, Ginza is just a few stations away. If you arrive at Haneda Airport, just take the Tokyo Monorail (Pasmo/Suica card) to Hamamatsucho. Get out of the station and exit the building. Look for the Oedo underground entrance at the crossing. Take the Oedo Line train to Roppongi. It's very convenient. Airport coaches are only available from Narita to Roppongi but not from Haneda to Roppongi. Of course, you can always take a taxi. We just like to do what the locals do, so we took the metro. It's more fun.

Ritz Carlton perfectly located. Views from our beautiful corner room with SuperMoon, Tokyo Tower, Tokyo Bay amazing!!Staff are wonderful, gracious, attentive, & extremely helpful and friendly!Easy to get around to any of any of the districts. We just walked or or used a driver (Tokyo Sakura) find her on trip advisor...awesome!Hugh Restaurant selections & shopping attached to the same building so you don't have to go outside.Our only complaint was ...we were looking to go to the lounge and have a cocktail before dinner but when we got there the cigarette smell was so awful we couldn't enjoy the area.The smoke was still in the air the next morning.We also did not like location of concierge... too much noise and congested area. Should be moved off to the side where you could actually hear their answers. We gave up and just used trip advisor for our info.Overall , we loved our stay at the Ritz Carlton Tokyo!

The view from our room on the 49th fl was spectacular. The service impeccable. In a great location near many shops and restaurants. First time at a Ritz property. Glad it was this one in Tokyo. Wondering how the others compare.....

I stayed here on business for five days. The location is top notch. The hotel was also top notch and the staff was very professional and courteous. My room had a view of Tokyo Tower that was amazing. There are a lot of eateries around the hotel as well as a mall attached to the hotel. The lobby was very beautiful but was very smokey. It was disappointing to walk into a grand lobby and be overwhelmed by the smell of stale smoke.

We stayed in Tokyo 2 days went to visit other cities and came back to Tokyo 3 days later and the staff said" Welcome Back", even the breakfast staff said welcome back. I was very surprised that they remembered that we recently visited. It was really appreciated, we felt like royalty. The hotel is amazing, the staff is very courteous and polite. I would recommend this hotel to anyone.

Great hotel. definitely stay here again!! Stayed here using Marriott reward points. Was given a terrific room and great service. Wish I had brought a bathing suit, there is a large lap pool. Would definitely stay here again and pay next time.

Getting in that beautiful, crowded but organized city, where everyone is so polite, the experience must begin at the Ritz-Carlton, Club Level. The view at the 53rd floor is breathtaking, you'd be welcomed by an extraordinary team. Each moment is a Japanese experience that you'll remember forever "au pays du Soleil Levant"

Beautiful hotel, great location, amazing service, insane views, great restaurants, amazing concierge (Misako). It could not of.been nicer. It will always be our hotel in Tokyo. From beginning to end--amazing.

4 night stay on the club floor. Club access is a wonderful add-on here. There is always someone to answer questions, or help with arrangements (important in Japan). It was a delight to sit at a private window table, sip a glass of wine and watch the sunset behind Mt. Fuji at day's end. Staff at the club are gracious to a fault and all speak excellent english. They were a big help confirming arrangements and finding off-the-beaten path locations. Club food offerings vary during the day including made-to-order eggs in the AM and Udon in the evening. The bar offers (complimentary) premium liquor and well selected wine and sake by the glass.Views are outstanding. Room selection is unimportant here - virtually every direction offers an interesting view. The club faces SW, so those in search of variety might opt for an east facing room. Aside from a handful of suites, most rooms are of comparable size and layout. Furnishings are tasteful, comfortable and in excellent conditions. Elevators seem to arrive the moment you approach them.I dined in Hinokizaka three times - twice in the Sushi room and once for tempura. The meals were uniformly excellent. Where else in the world can you have such an outstanding view from the sushi bar? Staff quickly recognized me and was incredibly attentive without being cloying. Not cheap, but the combination of view, quality and service made dining here an appropriate value. The Tokyo subway is a 5 minute walk through the attached Galleria mall and Midtown Tower complex. Get a Suica card on arrival at Narita - essential for smooth travel throughout the subway system.I've stayed at 4-5 star hotels around the globe and this is one of my favorites.

While the price per night might be higher than other hotels, the service is impeccable. Ritz Carlton management even takes notice of past stays and address your needs accordingly. This is akin to Business / First class treatment by airlines. The facilities like indoor pool and gym are excellent

We visited for the afternoon tea in the lobby. Advertised on the website to be until 5pm on weekdays. They told us at 3pm they were "sold out" on afternoon teas. Finally agreed to serve us and served more than ten afternoon tea clients after us. Way less food than in others afternoon teas. No real scones. Venue is beautiful however. I would go elsewhere for that price.

RATING: The Ritz-Carlton surpasses all the luxury properties I've experienced so far in Tokyo: the Park Hyatt, the Capitol Tokyu and the Royal Park Hotel, beside the two five-stars Dai-Ichi and Hilton Tokyo in Shinjuku.Ritz Carlton delivers a superb customer experience. The property's features and views, the politeness of the staff, the kitcken creations perfectly fit with the expectations I had from this brand.OVERALL IMPRESSION: lively and warm luxury. I guess that the Management is leading the collaborators with ambition and passion: they really care.ROOM: a corner suite with superb woodwork walls, a large bathroom with fully satisfactory amentities. Many details to be praised, including furnitures.LOBBY-RESTAURANTS: High ceiling (equivalent to 3-4 floors?); the lobby is lively, with a combination of both warm and bright colours. Views are spectacular, as in high rise hotels. At night the central stage delivers fine music. I had dinner in the main bar and was truly satisfied -excellent pastas and fish. The bar area has a wonderful layout -worth a visit. It faces Shinjuku.COMPARISON with PARK HYATT: Ritz-Carlton wins, to my opinion: better views (it's located between Tokyo/Ginza and Shinjuku and you can admire both skylines); better lobby area (more lively -the music stage is part of the lobby, while in Park Hyatt you have to walk to a separate site, the famous and surely appealing New York bar). Probably the pool is better at Park Hyatt -the Ritz Carlton's looks more elegant and modern, but is somehow less spectacular.The Park Hyatt benefits a lot from the "Lost in Translation" aura; but it may even be forced not to chenge, not to evolve from what it was like in the early '00s. The Ritz is alive and seems a more dynamic place.

Just stayed one night in this fantastic hotel, and every second in here was a treasure.After renewal of the guest rooms, the decor now is much more modern and sophisticated but still with the luxurious element of the Ritz Carlton chain. The view from high floor is breathtaking, and you can easily see both Tokyo Tower and Skytree from the lounge at the lobby (so even you only reserve the basic type of room, like I do, can still enjoy this a million dollar scene). When the weather is nice and the sky is clear, I can see Mount Fuji from my room.The location of the hotel is absolutely excellent. There are tons of amazing shops and restaurants in Roppongi Midtown, let along three museums are just nearby. The amenities in the guest rooms are really in good quality. But the most impressive part is the service. Everyone in the hotel greeted me with warm and big smiles. The adorable staff, Ai chan, who works in the restaurant Hinokizaka, were absolutely the most kind staff I had ever met so far in Tokyo. And other female staff, like Nishi chan, even led me to the destination just because she saw confusion in my face while looking at the map. This is the place that makes your feel you spend your money worthy. I wish that I will have a chance to experience this beautiful and touching experience in the near future.

The Ritz Carlton is located in Mid Town and towers over an area which includes parks and older properties. The hotel is situated from the 42nd floor upwards.Very convenient location and the hotel offers everything you would expect from a 5* hotel.

Beautiful hotel room on the 50th floor. Suite was gorgeous and large with great amenities like a Nespresso machine, quality teas, TV in the bath room and wonderful toiletry items. Bed was huge and comfortable sleep on quality linens. Really appreciated the comfy PJs! Staff were amazing and tending to my needs like bringing extra bath salts at a late hour and packing a quick breakfast before my trip to work. Would stay again!

My husband and I really loved every moment of our stay at the Ritz. At first I was a bit concerned because it seemed far away from the center of the city, but it is directly on two subway lines so it was easy to get where ever we wanted. And after a L-O-N-G day of sightseeing in the crazy bustle of Tokyo, it was so pleasant to come back to a quieter area, and sit out at the cafe with a glass of wine, or walk through the beautiful park surrounding the hotel.  Everything about this hotel lived up to the Ritz Carlton name. Every single person who works there was extremely friendly and helpful. Our room was gorgeous, with an amazing view of Tokyo from floor-to-ceiling windows. I'm sorry we didn't have a chance to try the spa -- it looked great. The concierges were so helpful in giving us suggestions and directions to all the places we wanted to visit and arranging dinner reservations. I highly recommend the Ritz Carlton Tokyo.
user_name:
PkNeel
New York City, New York

review_body: From the minute we arrived our experience at the Ritz was outstanding. Their focus on service is unmatched. For example, Delta Airlines left one of our pieces of luggage in ATL so when we arrived at the hotel we made them aware. The entire staff seemed to know of the issue and kept us abreast of the situation until Delta delivered it the next day.Food and beverage was outstanding. During our stay on two occasions we hired a car service through the hotel and I was amazed at their attention to detail in their goal of providing quality service.The structure itself is first class with views of the entire city and beyond...including MT Fuji..

This was the last night of our trip to Hong Kong and Japan. What a way to end the trip.I always like and appreciate first impressions. When our taxi stopped at the driveway the bell boy met and greeted me with my last name. At the entrance of the tower another young lady did the same and took us to the 45th floor. Mind you, we took a local taxi and I have no idea how the staff knew we were in that taxi. Reception was friendly and very happy. Fluent English all the way, a good thing during our our trip in Japan.We booked a Club Room but were upgraded to corner suite which I must add was the pinnacle of our trip. This suite goes well with other suites we stayed at before (Shangri La, Four Seasons JW Marriott and Sheraton to name a few).The location was fantastic and convenient. In the heart of Roppongi shopping area. The hotel is in Midtown Tokyo complex standing on a high quality mall.We had an early breakfast before flying out to Hong Kong. The service and greetings were impeccable. I can go on with how good our stay was, but let's just say this was more than 5 stars stay.

Had a very nice 3 night stay at the Ritz. I was there for two nights on business and then my girlfriend joined for the third night.Great view from the room, nice bar with very friendly staff, good breakfast buffet and a good concierge. The room was a good size and the bathroom was very good. The pool is very nice with a great view and the gym is well equipped.The location in Roppongi is great. Fun area to just walk around. The midtown complex has a number of restaurants and shops if looking for somewhere close and convenient (when had busy work evenings) and then other great places in Roppongi if have more time to explore a bit further afield. Roppongi also well located in between the Maronouchi area where I had a lot of meetings, and the Shinjuku/Shibuya area where I always enjoy exploring.My one complaint is I asked the concierge for suggestions for a Teppanyaki place nearby and they sent me somewhere that I felt was not particularly good and was overpriced (Kisentei). I did ask for a nearby restaurant, and this wasn’t on the Ritz’s standard recommendation list, but I was not impressed with the food and wish the Concierge had suggested I went to the Teppanyaki at the hotel which I heard was very good! I also asked for suggestions of things to do while in Tokyo and there list was extremely generic. Basically visiting all the standard sights. I felt they could have been a bit more inventive. However, when I asked them to make specific reservations they were very helpful so not all critical here.I have stayed in Tokyo for business at a number of the top hotels and I would definitely go back to the Ritz. The only hotel that I have stayed at that I think is a class above is the Mandarin Oriental. Others including the Conrad, Four Seasons, Peninsula and Grand Hyatt are comparable. For me choosing a hotel in Tokyo depends on the location. For Roppongi it comes down to the Ritz or the Grand Hyatt. I would say both are comparable and great hotels.

A luxurious hotel in midtown with all the facilities and details. Beautiful views from the lobby and rooms of all the city up from the 46 floor. Expensive which is normal but I found excessive wine price list. Wonderful and big room and lovely swimming pool. Service excellent as Japanese style

We had the pleasure of spending a full week at the RC Tokyo last week with our son. While my wife attended a conference, I enjoyed touring Tokyo - we would highly recommend the RC Tokyo for families visiting Tokyo! 1) The pool is immaculate and child-friendly. Some properties I looked into did not allow children into the pool. 2) Food options are plentiful. The breakfast buffet is outstanding, and the hotel has top-tier food options for lunch and dinner as you'd expect. For something more informal, the food court and 24h market in the Midtown complex offer tons of other choices. 3) Room quality - the rooms overall are top notch with great bathrooms, television (we didn't spend time watching TV but the screen was impressive) and comfy linens. 4) Kids. The RC has a lending library of kids books and some fun activities on offer. The staff enjoyed interacting with our son and he fondly speaks about his "Tokyo home" 5) View. The only downside of this hotel and many others in Tokyo is having to take two elevators to get to your room. However, the room view is worth it!
