New York City, New York

review_body: Great hotel: comfortable, roomy, great view. Many people spoke English, which was very helpful (provided for a stress free experience). Room service and club lounge were great. Slept very well. No noise. Very nice rooms had large nice bathrooms and a seating section.

Just spent a fab 12 nights here, 1st time in Japan and this hotel was amazing. We had the cheapest double room bit couldn't believe how large it was, huge bathroom room. Service by all the staff was second to none. Place was beautiful and part of midtown mall. Loads of excellent eating spots, full range of prices and choice, which after a long day was great. This was one of the best hotels we have stayed in. Now staying at the Ritz Calton in Kyoto and , to our shock, this is as good. Will write full review at end of our stay. Japan is everything I hoped for and more

Worth the extra money to stay in the Club Level rooms. Food and drink throughout the day is wonderful. No ATM in the hotel which is a bit inconvenient. If you need an ATM, you must go to the 3rd floor of the Midtown Tower and go into the post office. That is the only ATM that would take my US-issued Chase Visa.

By far the best hotel experience I've had! The staff made us feel special by providing excellent recommendations and chatting with us each day. Unbelievable service and immensely beautiful hotel. I can't say enough about this great hotel.

The Ritz Carlton exceeded all our expectations. The Tokyo Ritz staff is amazing at all touch points. I travel frequently and have never received this level up of attention. All hotel employees should spend a day watching and learning from the Ritz Carlton Yokyo team.Here's an example. I went to the lobby at 430 am where I saw coffee the day prior but it wasn't set up yet. Before I could blink the gentleman at the front desk was handing me a cup of delicious coffee. Don't stay anywhere except the Ritz Tokyo.

On top of the list of memories from Tokyo is the hotel where I stayed - 44th floor in the Ritz Carlton. In a country where 1 out of 10 people speak English, everyone from chamber maid to service boy, every single staff in this hotel spoke English. The concierge would help me plan my visit every day (and I stayed for three weeks), guide me on where to go and how to...no other hotel I have stayed in (in any country) has delighted me more.

I booked a facial treatment for myself and my mother who was visiting me in Tokyo and after booking through the website was looking forward to the experience. I have to point out here that I specified that we were not staying at the hotel but had just booked two spa treatments. All went well on arrival and until the end of the treatments. However after paying and waiting for the elevator to arrive, the spa manager (I presume) suddenly appeared to announce (and in front of the spa receptionist staff who were showing us out) that we weren't welcome again as we weren't guests at the hotel and that the spa is not open to the general public. I was so shocked at the tone, attitude and abruptness of the person that immediately the elevator doors opened, I made a hasty escape. I was made to feel that we had tried to cheat our way into the spa and in full view of all the staff. If I had had my wits about me, I would have pointed out that if she had bothered to look, it would clearly indicate on the booking form that we were not staying there. I had made a point of checking a box that we were not guests just in case.So contrary to what was implied by the manager, we were not "sneaking" into the spa to grab a treatment. In addition, I later discovered that there were several amenities available during the spa visit that no member of staff explained to me. Fortunately for my mother, the member of staff who showed her around had explained the complimentary facilities available and she was able to take full advantage of them. Overall a truly dreadful end of which I will not forget. I also vow never to set foot in the hotel ever again.

In late years the lobby on upper floors becomes a matter of course.This hotel is the same, too and, in the lounge, I enjoy a cigar from the day and can enjoy cocktail.If it is the day when it was fine, the view is a splendid location very, too.It is an affiliated hotel of Marriott, but is a luxury hotel！

very clean and modern. staff are so attentive and polite. area around the hotel is very safe. I would highly recommend the hotel for any special occasion. The concierge was great in obtaining dinner reservations at Ishikawa and also tix for a J league soccer match.

Dear Mr. RolfsWhat a wonderful experience it was to stay at your hotel.Your staff was exceptional all the way. Desiree and her team in the lounge made us feel very welcome and at home.Yuriko Ohori is a wonderful young lady! With her positive and friendly appearance, she will certainly further her career with Ritz Carlton. The team at the Concierge desk was very knowledgeable and helpful. Everything was taken care of in time and precisely as promised.We hope to one day be able to return to Tokyo and it will be no question where we will stay.Thank you very much and kind regards from Naples, Florida (where the second best Ritz-Carlton is located).

We spent 9 nights in April at the Ritz Carlton during a family trip in Japan. This is an excellent hotel: breathtaking view, very clean and spacious rooms, very friendly staff, good location in the Midtown. We'll come back, we enjoyed so much our stay.

On a business trip to Tokyo in November, 2014 I stayed at the Ritz for a week and I must say the hotel lived up to its hype. Situated at the top floors of a magnificent building near Roppongi - the entertainment district of Tokyo, the view from the rooms and restaurant are awesome! Please ask the front desk for a room with a view of either the Tokyo Tower or Mt. Fuji. Most likely you will be granted it. The room is opulent and classy. The restaurant has a clear view of Mt. Fuji in the distance and the breakfast spread was limited but nice. The courteous staff, room service, concierge and restaurant servers deserve a special mention for their hospitality. They make you want to come back again. I highly recommend this hotel if you want to stay close to the city center and yet experience the tranquility of staying in a suburban hotel.

Ritz-Carlton Tokyo4.85 out of 5 circlesPlease keep in mind that this review is from my personal experience. While I think of my stay as “The Ritz Done Right”, I must warn that it might not be “typical”. I wouldn’t expect the same series of chance and luck to happen again on my next visit, and no one reading this review should assume that it will happen to them. I know nothing of Ritz policies and am only reporting the experience my family and I had at this property.General Overview (I’ll do an in-depth review on the following pages)….From my pre-travel contacts to the moment we checked out, with personalized service, spacious & well-furnished common areas (to include the club lounge) and well decorated/laid-out rooms (with a view that can’t be beat), the Ritz-Carlton Tokyo earned their position as my favorite hotel in Tokyo…. Was it perfect? No. But other than a possible miscommunication with room service and lack of ambience at the pool, it came pretty close. I would stay here again and I would wholeheartedly recommend it to others.In-Depth Review…2 Adults (40’s), 2 Children (girls ages 3 & 7). Travelling for leisure as a wedding anniversary trip.Pre-trip…Communications with concierge and reservations was good. Questions and concerns were handled in a timely manner. We changed our plans a bit and reservations was happy to extend our stay. Before arrival we were informed of an upgrade.Arrival/check-in… The rooms manager at the Kyoto property arranged to have 2 cars meet us at the Tokyo station (1 for luggage, 1 for the people). One of the gents was at our platform waiting to help with luggage and lead us down to the cars. He was aware of my children’s names and used them when starting a conversation with my 7 year old After a 15-20 minute ride we arrived at the property where there were no less than 2 management types waiting to meet us and escort us to our room (Rooms director, Club Lounge director, and I think there was an asst. F&B manager as well). Everyone knew (and used) our names… “Hello Mr. T, welcome to the Ritz-Carlton Tokyo”. We were escorted up to the 45th (?) floor to the main lobby area and then to a secondary set of elevators that took you to the rooms. Upon reaching our room we were given a brief tour and check-in was done with the Club Lounge manager right in the room. All went smooth enough. Passports. Credit card. A couple signatures.Room……There are upgrades and then there are “upgrades”. This was the later type. I was almost in shock to be honest. Corner” Milenia” Suite (80 m2) on the highest floor (53rd) overlooking Tokyo Tower down to Tokyo bay and Odaiba on one side and the Tokyo imperial palace in the distance on the other. Stunning would be an understatement. By far the best view of the 3 Tokyo hotels we stayed in and tied for 1st when it came to room layout. Here there is basically a long hallway that connects the room’s 3 main areas (in order as you enter… bathroom, bedroom, and living room). First impressions and all that? This is “The Ritz Done Right”.Living Room… This is the corner section of the room and it gives the best views. Sofa, coffee table, chair, side table, desk with chair, gentlemen’s valet.They brought in an extra bed for the children and placed it next to the window facing the Tokyo tower (the chair and side table were moved to the side). I had been initially worried that it might make the living room a bit crowded but it actually fit in quite well.A little story that makes a vacation property into a memory…. My wife was laying next our 3 year old in the extra bed (trying to get her to go to sleep) when my daughter turns her attention from the night view out the window and says “It’s beautiful mama” and promptly goes to sleep. In-room guest amenities… Another very impressive aspect at this property during our visit (although I’m not certain at which level such amenities appear i.e. club level, suites, anniversary trip. etc.).Upon entering the living room we found a plate of macaroons and chocolates with a personalized greeting written on white chocolate to my children (“Welcome to Tokyo Sue and Tina”).Bags of children’s goods to include crayons, activity books, children’s cups, and stuffed lions.A chocolate heart with chocolate almonds inside was incased under a glass bell with tea roses. Writing on the plate (in chocolate?) stated “Happy 8th Wedding Anniversary” and there was an accompanying card stating “Happy wedding Anniversary. Have a memorable stay in Tokyo. The ladies and gentlemen of the Tokyo Ritz Carlton”.A great success with the amenities and most certainly the “Ritz done Right”.Bedroom… King size bed. Nightstands with hidden room controls on either side of the bed. His and her closets across from the foot of the bed. Large screen TV across from the foot of the bed as well. Nespresso machine and 3 types of capsules (all clearly marked and described on a card) are located in the bedroom. Mini-bar is located in the cabinet beneath the Nespresso machine.Standard shoe horn, polishing mitt, sewing kit, etc.Bathroom… Large soaking tub next to the window overlooking the Tokyo Imperial palace. Separate rain shower. Japanese automatic toilet. All the bathroom amenities you could hope for in such a property (toothbrushes, cotton swabs, mouth wash, razor, etc.) all nicely arranged in a wooden box. Refilled as used. Children’s soaps/shampoo/toothbrushes were provided and were already in the room without needing to call and ask.Plenty of towels were provided. Robes for the kids were in the room without having to request them.Housekeeping … Everything was replaced/refreshed constantly. Open a toothbrush and another appears in the amenity box. We never ran out of soap or towels. Everything was always nicely displayed & hung properly. Water, Ice and glasses were provided at turndown. Children’s nightclothes were folded and displayed nicely on the bed. Stuffed animal were arranged in cute ways (i.e. sitting on the window ledge looking out the window). Water and water glasses were left for the children and placed next to the extra bed. I had shoes in 3 different colors and left a note asking for another shoe shine mitt. Housekeeping left a cute note back and gave me 2. Club Level Lounge… Located on the 53rd floor (just around the corner from our room). Another highlight of this property. Wonderful views. Spot on personalized service. Good food. Nice selection. Club level concierge is located at the entrance to the lounge. Club staff were quite helpful when it came to helping with suggestions for daily activities, transportation, etc. They would print maps (in both English and Japanese) and other info often without needing to be being asked.Club level director would often come around and ask as to your activities for the day and whether or not you needed any assistance with planning/transportation/reservations/etc.Breakfast buffet had a nice selection. Well presented. Certainly to 5* luxury standards with a few extras thrown in. Egg station is available but may take a bit of time during busier periods (I was quoted 20 minutes one day). We were never in a hurry so the wait didn’t bother us but for those on a schedule you might want to take it into consideration.I was peeling an orange for the 3 year old and one of the Club Lounge staff came along and offered to do it for me. A few minutes later it comes back, peeled, segmented, and cut (he even took out the walls).The girlies somehow ended up with Ritz Carlton Tokyo t-shirts. If they hadn’t been pink I would have asked for one myself. Lol. Either way. It was certainly nice of the lounge staff to do so, and it was another positive moment of our stay.Lounge staff were always very good with the children. From sitting and colouring with them to taking them on little “tours” around the lounge area.. Nice (but a bit of a hassle)…. They have a whole variety of candies at the lounge entrance (and a couple different cookies). It’s a great amenity. I ate a lot of cookies (and I mean a lot). I am not complaining and in no way am I suggesting they get rid of it…but… you parents out there will quickly find out that this is a bit of a distraction when it comes time to actually be eating breakfast (or any other time you’re in the lounge). lolLaundry/pressing… As we had credit for pressing I had them do a sweater and a shirt. We went out and they were hanging nicely in the closet (with a cloth cover over them) by time we got back. Shoe Shine Service… My shoes came back looking nice enough. To be honest, delivering the shoes in Ritz-Carlton paper shopping bags is a bit underwhelming and minimalistic when compared to presentation at the other properties we stayed at while in Tokyo (cloth shoe bags at one… wrapped in tissue and placed into a decorative box at another). Room Service… This was the only snafu we ran into during our stay at the Ritz. Perhaps it was just a miscommunication but the server pretty much rolled the cart into the living room, took out all the food, and left without setting anything up. As my wife and I had salads as starters, I had asked that he leave the hot food in the hot box. Perhaps he took this to mean that I didn’t want him to set it up? At least he came right back with the extra salad dressing I requested. I ordered 4 cakes with ice cream for dessert. For some reason these came at the same time as dinner (versus having us call when we were ready for dessert to be delivered). Needless to say that the ice cream was warm and melted by time we got to it. I guess I could have had him bring them back down but as I hadn’t specified order of service, I decided not to make an issue of it. Oh. My wife and I each ordered the Japanese curried beef which contained only 4 small pieces of meat each. For the opulence of the property itself, I found such portion sizing to be underwhelming and quite minimalistic. We ordered the same thing at The Peninsula and it came with twice as much meat and a half a dozen or so mushrooms.As we were having a fantastic stay I didn’t really want to make an issue of things and mentioned it in passing to one of the lobby lounge/bar managers. Although I had stated that I didn’t want to make a complaint, things got passed on anyways and the room service director tracked me down the following day, offered his personal apologies, and asked me to contact him directly should we need anything further from room service.Pool… If memory serves correct the pool is available for use by children from 0900-1800.While functional, I wouldn’t say that it had much ambience. No candles. No waterfalls. No real design. Of course the views were fantastic,,, but again… the rest of the hotel is a testament to design and grandeur….You hit the main lobby you say wow. You hit your room you say wow. You hit the lounge you say wow. And when you hit the pool it’s more like…. “Oh. A pool”. Water was available in pitchers. Bottled water is reserved for spa “members” (as were a couple of the lounge chairs and a swimming lane).Kickboards and water peanuts are available poolside. Obligatory swim cap will be provided at the spa desk should you not have your own.Jacuzzi is located in the same general area (just a few feet away from the pool) making it convenient to go from one to the other.Entrance…Located on the bottom floor. Nice enough and well-furnished for those times one is waiting on transport. Nice floral arrangement by the elevators. Lobby… The lobby is quite impressive. 2 story ceilings, floor to ceiling Windows, wonderful views, .a 2 story waterfall, floral arrangements, sitting areas, lobby lounge, bar, concierge, main reception. Main Bar/smoking lounge… Japan itself is pretty much a “no smoking area”. So.. In order to smoke you need to go down to the main bar. No bother. I actually like to take a few minutes on my own and don’t smoke around my family anyway. The areea is open yet still intimate, the furnishing are decent enough aethetically and the chairs quite confortable. Service was always polite and Professional. The assistant manager of the bar and lobby restaurant was always quite nice and went out of her way to greet me and take a few moments to make polite conversation. I enjoyed the personal service and of course it was nice to have someone to talk to a bit as to how the day played out.One drawback in having the smoking area in the bar… Manners almost require that you to buy a $17 coffee from the bar (versus bringing a free coffee down from your room or the club level lounge). I didn’t mind this too much. To be honest, with the upgrade I was more than happy to put a bit more money to the property.There was often live music. I remember 3 distinct acts….a vocalist, a pianist, and a small band.Surrounding area…. There is an “upscale mall” with attached Starbucks right out of the hotel’s 1st floor exit.Surrounding area is quite active. Plenty of restaurants and nick knack stores but perhaps not much interesting for a luxury traveler (other than the sights and sounds of course). Each store/restaurant has a hawker out on the sidewalk trying to get you in the door. It was neat to experience it, but it’s perhaps not my favorite area in Tokyo. Check out/departure….. I checked out the night before our departure. If I remember correctly they didn’t ask for my credit card again versus running the bill and having me sign. Transport to my next destination was arranged. Directions to our next destination were given. A small gift bag of candy was presented to each of the children…And a departure gift of Japanese tea cookies was presented to my wife and I.Conclusion……To me, it’s not a question of “would I stay here again” it’s more as to “When will I stay here again”… I will be back at this hotel. I will put aside extra money in order to stay in the same room. Without a doubt I will book Club Level. I will once again enjoy the food, the views, and the service. Heck, I’ll even begrudgingly go to the pool with my daughters (lol). I would certainly recommend it to anyone (even without the added extras that we received).  No, it wasn’t “perfect”, but nothing really is, and they were pretty close to it. Again. I’d put them at 4.85. I took .10 off for the room service incident (I then added .05 for the RS director approaching me personally). I also took off .05 for the less than imaginative presentation of shoes when returned and another .05 for the utilitarian pool area. With all the extras I received, and the fact that my stay exceeded my expectations, I think The Ritz Tokyo deserves to be rounded up to a 5 circle rating.On a final note…. my positive experiences with the Ritz brand in both Tokyo and Kyoto have lead me to book stays at 2 Ritz locations for my upcoming visit to New York (Central Park and Battery Park).

As a result of a last minute change of plans I had to leave my wife in Tokyo for four days whilst I headed out of town. Thank goodness we were staying in the Ritz Carlton. The staff were ultra-attentive, both when I was there and when my wife was alone. The club room was wonderful; the concierge service, both before we arrived and whilst we were there, was outstanding. We didn't have a suite but the space and facilities in our room were still great - with fabulous views over the Tokyo Tower and down to the river.The location is great. Easy access to the metro if you need to leave, and really unusual shopping and dining options just at the bottom of the tower. And throw in three art galleries within walking distance and you have a real winner.We are now spoilt for staying anywhere else in Tokyo. Thank you Ritz Carlton!

For a 5 star prestigious hotel, you would expect a quality dining experience with great ambiance, service, and food. If you don't believe me, all you have to do is take a quick glance at the buffet restaurant and you will see what I mean. The food selection and quality is just a big let down for a hotel like the Ritz Carlton. My wife and I were trying to enjoy a set lunch in the lobby lounge. The food was just so so. A bit salty, nothing spectacular, and very overpriced. But what was more disappointing was the ambiance. Given it's Tokyo, you would expect the staff to be exceptional. As the restaurant is in the lobby, we had an unfortunate experience with a screaming kid running around the lobby and restaurant for over 40min. You would expect the staff at some point to say something to the parents. Instead, the staff turned a blind eye and continued to avoid any contact. At this point it was clear that every table was frustrated with this and yet, nothing has been done.

Still in residence, part way through a one week stay. On the 50th floor, the day and nighttime views are magnificent. The room is huge by any standard and so is the bathroom. Luxurious amenities. First class service from the moment we arrived, gracious and discrete yet delivered to the highest standard. Arranged our transfer from our cruise ship in a very nice sedan for 10000 Yen. Less than half of what the cruise line would have charged. Access to the Club Lounge is on the expensive side if not included in the room rate but for up to 5 different food offers throughout the day and flowing alcohol is actually good value for money. Tokyo Midtown Mall has everything you might need right below. Will definitely stay here again, visited friends who were staying at the Mandarin Oriental public areas / lounge / bar here superior. Super!

We stayed for 3 nights here on the 52nd floor, club level. We knew that we were in for a treat - we imagined that the Ritz in Tokyo would be a pretty fine start to our 10 day trip around Japan. But honestly, we just could not believe our luck when we arrived at this hotel. We were ushered up to the club level on the 53rd floor and settled in to a table by the floor to ceiling windows. The view was absolutely spectacular. After a wonderful snack of cherry blossom welcome drinks, finger sandwiches and sweets, we were shown to our room. We had a corner room with 2 super comfy beds, which was perfect as we were a family of 4 - lots of room for us and the incredible view stretching out over Tokyo Sky Tower to the marina in one direction and over the city to the new and extremely impressive Sky Tree in the other. Wow!!! We had been in Tokyo a matter of hours, but felt like we'd had these amazing experiences already! Bathroom was luxurious and spacious replete with all the little touches such as toothbrushes, hairbrushes and emery boards encased in the signature silver Ritz boxes. We had 3 amazing days and nights at the Ritz and came back again 8 days later for one more night. We dined at the Ninja Restaurant (highly recommended if you have small boy in tow) and when we got back to the hotel, Seiko and her team had brought a whole cake and individual chocolate mousses to our room, which was set up with a welcome back message on our beds! The kids were overjoyed and it was such a thoughtful touch. Cannot WAIT to come back. A big "Thank You" to everyone at the Ritz Cartlon Tokyo.

We stayed at the Ritz Carlton Tokyo for 6 nights in mid April 2015 before heading to Kyoto and then for another 2 nights before heading back home. From the moment of arrival, the knowledgable and professional staff take care of you with a smile and graciousness I've hardly seen before at any other hotel. Check in staff were efficient and spit on, concierge extremely knowledgeable and anticipated our needs. From A to Z - the service was impeccable! The hotel ambiance serene; location - connected to the midtown complex - fantastic. Hector - the assistant Direcor or rooms - greeted us warmly during the second part of our stay and made our experience (as newly weds) that much for special. The views are amazing and the spa is exactly as you'd expect at the Ritz Tokyo. I've travelled pretty much all over and I've never raved about any hotel, but this one deserves it.

The corner room is very spacious and the hotel is very Clean luxurious and its conveniently located on top of Tokyo midtown. The supermarket is open 24 hour and easy to find food nearby. The swimming pool and gym is good however if you want to use the sauna whirlpool and locker area they charged ¥5000 per day, which I think it's absurd. We stayed at 5star hotel and this should be included.Other than that my experience is fantastic.

We checked in in the Club Lounge on the 53rd floor, and were immediately offered afternoon tea with cherry blossom soda, cakes, scones and savoury bites. We were then taken to our room, 5330 on the same floor, with fantastic views over Tokyo to Mount Fuji (almost!). It was a lovely room, with traditional decor, a huge bed, two comfy chairs, fridge-style minibar and a kettle. The large bathroom had a deep bath, separateshower, two washbasins and a Toto loo. There were also pyjamas! The WiFi was very good and free.The Club Lounge was large with excellent service. The food presentations were very good: mini pies, vegetables, chicken, smoked salmon, cheese etc., plus Champagne, beer and wine. We used the gym here, which was very well equipped and quiet.We decided to splash out on the Rolls Royce airport transfer service, which was a very hedonistic way to finish, but a great way of softening the blow of having to leave.

The Ritz Carlton Tokyo is a 5 star plus property. From the amenities, to Club Lounge, to the Food and the beautifully appointed suite with amazing views, but most of all the Staff! My wife and I arrived on April 17th and from the moment we stepped out of the car the amazing staff could not do enough to ensure we had a present experence. Unfortunately my wife got food poisoning on our flight over from United States. The staff went over and above to assist us In changing or canceling various reservations and plans that we had on our itinerary. They even prepared special meals to try to accommodate my wife sensitive stomach. The hotel manager Massa and the assistant manager Hector were great. I can honestly say I have stayed at countless hotels all over the world and the staff here would rank amount the top 3. I would definitely recommend this property to anyone looking to come to Tokyo and truly experience a five-star stay.

We had two connected delax rooms on the 49th floor. The rooms were clean and roomy. The view of the city was great although it was not the side of Tokyo Tower. The ventilation noise coming from the bathroom was very loud. And so was the air conditioning noise in the room. The room was very dry and affected our throats. The noises and dryness bothered our sleep. We didn't complain because we stayed there only one night. What was most inconvenient was that they did not offer any basic skin care products for women; such as cleansing lotion, face soap, skin lotion, face cream. We travel light and we usually use basic skin care products that the hotels provide. Ritz not having basic skin products available for guests was very puzzling!

Had a pleasant stay at this hotel. It was a very good sized room, clean and with all the amenities that come standard at the ritz. The breakfast was a little expensive and disappointing. It was a little difficult to find a decent breakfast in Tokyo and although the hotel had a shopping center attached to it, nothing was really open until 11am leaving it difficult to find options for breakfast. The concierge was okay but not as helpful as some other ritz properties we have been to. With all this said, we would stay again as the room was nice and the location was good with the train being right down stairs.
user_name:
Rachelle L
New York City, New York

review_body: I've stayed at this property twice now in the past 4 months, both times in a club level room. The rooms at this property are very expensive, even by Tokyo standards, but I think this is partially due to location. The hotel, part of Tokyo Mid-Town, is very centrally located, and Tokyo Mid-Town is somewhere you can spend a lot of time between shopping, dining, and museums. I am not a big fan of the decor of the rooms, which seems dated and somehow just not as modern/clean as you'd expect in a very modern place like Tokyo. The size of the rooms is generous, and the views from club-level quite nice (you can either face Tokyo Tower or Fuji, but I guess Tokyo Tower is the more requested view). The club has a decent offering of food and beverage, but again, I find the furniture and look to be underwhelming and dated. Service was quite different the two times I was there. The first time, they had fudged the reservation so the room wasn't ready, they were too busy to check us in at club-level, and they literally asked me to fill-out the same form 3 times. It was super frustrating. The second time, the service was much better, but the 2nd time there were also super vigilant about charging extra for every single thing. They charged us extra for all 3 of our kids (one of whom they counted as an adult), and they wanted to charge us $250 USD for a roll-away bed (I successfully negotiated that fee away). Service at the club the 2nd time was very good, and there is a woman named Desiree there that is exceptionally good at client service. I must be honest in saying that I have always preferred Four Seasons, St. Regis, and Mandarin Oriental to the Ritz properties as I feel these properties are notably better at the small details and at service. All this having been said, we enjoyed our stay and obviously liked it enough to return a 2nd time, although the decision to return was based mainly on location. If you go during sakura season as we did, the location is key as Mid-Town has a ton of amazing sakura and places you can actually have drinks/food under the blossoms.

Having been to Tokyo a few years ago, we were planning on staying at the Park Hyatt again, however, we are so delighted we switched and decided to stay at The Ritz Carlton, it was so relaxing, so comfortable and just delightful in every way. We went to the Park Hyatt for dinner and endured poor food and tedius service so were so pleased to skuttle back to the supreme luxury and exquisite service of the Ritz Carlton. If like us, you are weighing up one or the other, I can highly recommend the Ritz Carlton.

This elegant hotel provided a highlight of a 5 day visit to Tokyo . The staff is wonderful . Our room was large , beautifully appointed and spotless. The huge bathroom with two sinks was a real luxury . The adjoining upscale mall provided easy access to the metro .

This hotel being located from the 45 to 53 storeys, one can enjoy wonderful view of the down town tokyo on a clear that, and the view is even better for the rooms facing the Tokyo Tower which is located not far away. The service is good and professional although not over the top. The Midtown of which the hotel forms a part of, is linked to two subway links and require a big of walking. The shopping mall is classy although it lacks a large departmental store. The supermarket sells quality food stuffs and fruits. We had breakfast at the hotel and find the spread acceptable and I am impressed with their egg benedict which is offered. The spa is very good and it costs an additional 62,000 yen for use without any spa treatment.

We had six wonderful nights in the Ritz Carlton, Tokyo Mid Town and cannot praise the hotel highly enough. The room was beautifully appointed with fabulous views towards Tokyo Tower and out across the Bay. The hotel was very easy to get to and well located for access to pretty much everything - short taxi ride from Tokyo station if you have heavy luggage. The Club Lounge was welcoming and had even better views across Aoyama cemetery which was in full cherry blossom bloom at this time of year, towards Fuji. The service was impeccable and the staff faultless. Food in the lounge was lovely and readily replenished. Overall, a wonderful stay.

We stayed at the Ritz Carlton after our cruise ended. We were thrilled with the most memorable experience one could imagine!!!! The rooms were large with amazing views. The amenities were the best I have ever seen. We could see MT FIJI!!!!! The hotel is first class in everly way, it is as if you are sitting on the top of the world. The location is perfect and close to all shopping and subway (which was very easy to use) The executive lounge was the best I have experienced and the staff was so attentive to our every need. They could not do enough. They were always there to assist with any needs or suggestion. The food was amazing!!!! WE LOVED THIS HOTEL AND HOPE TO GO BACK SOON.

I stayed at the Ritz during my stay in Tokyo and in general I was impressed by the property. The hotel is very well connected within Roppongi and has some of the best views in Tokyo from the rooms. The staff was very polished and polite at all times as one would expect from a Ritz. However I did feel that the rooms whilst immaculate looked a bit dated in comparison to other luxury properties in Tokyo (like the Mandarin Oriental or the Peninsula). The rooms however are very large for Tokyo standards and have all the amenities you could ask for and more. One negative part though is that they charge you 7000 JPY to use the steam room and sauna which in my opinion is ridiculous for the price you pay for the rooms. Other properties offer that for free which is what you would expect for a 5 star hotel. The swimming pool was very nice and boasted lovely views of Tokyo as well. I do think it is one of the top hotels in Tokyo but I personally am more of a fan of the Peninsula and the Mandarin which is why I only gave it 4 out of 5 stars.

Outrageously good service - beautiful hotel with every amenity and service. However, the best thing about this Hotel may be the view. Occupying Floors 45-53 of Tokyo's tallest Tower (Midtown Tower), the view of the city is spectacular from every part of the Hotel, including your room. The location is fantastic - within walking distance of sights and neighbourhoods and, a stone's throw from Roppongi subway Station making it very accessible and a great spot from which to base oneself. Hotel Restaurants (4) all excellent and offer great variety. Would highly recommend the Ritz to business travellers and tourists alike.

Located close to a shopping center and metro system, this hotel provides a great base for a stay in Tokyo. My room was on a high floor and provided amazing views. The standard and amenities of the room were excellent. The hotel truly delivers the Ritz-Carlton experience. I would say that this property was one of the best That I have visited. They had very nice pool. Hot tub was not great and they charged for the use of sauna facilities, which is usually something I do not like. Besides of these few things, this hotel was as close to perfect as I can imagine.

This was the first time I stayed at the Ritz-Carlton in Tokyo and certainly it will not be the last. Excellent service complements the spectacular views over the metropolis, spacious and exceptionally well appointed rooms, great location in the heart of Rappongi. Facilities include a great gym and pool area and a bar with beautiful vistas. Highly recommend it.

Just spent a long weekend at the Ritz Tokyo. Wow, what a hotel. The staff is totally incredible. Everyone goes out of their way to make your stay unforgettable.The rooms are beautiful and totally well equipped. The head concierge is a diamond. She knows everything about the city. If you're coming here, make sure to contact her for reservations for dinner all over the city. The entire concierge staff is fantastic.The lobby has wonderful music every night, and it's a must do on your visit to the Ritz. Also, a special call out to new Asst. Director of Rooms, Hector, who also seems to be everywhere in the hotel, and does a spectacular job.All in all, the Ritz is a top hotel in a fantastic city.One more thing: if you want an unbelievable massage outside the hotel, I highly recommend Erawan Thai massage, which is about a 7 minute walk from the hotel. One of the best massages ever anywhere. Have the concierge make an appointment for you.

This hotel has exceptional service. We did have an issue with our transportation to the hotel due to some miscommunication. They were very apologetic and paid for our cab. The staff gave detailed directions to places we were attempting to see and recommend sights. The housekeeping was very detail oriented, wrapping up our power cords, laying out my pj's at night and organizing our stuff. Beautiful place to stay and close to metro. We used the Tokyo metro nearly everyday, it is easy to use and clean.

Helpful and devoted staff. Great restaurants. Nice view. We loved the shops in Midtown.Rooms and bathrooms are spacious and great.Nothing to complain about.The staff handed us towels when we reached the hotel under the rain!

My husband and I just finished a trip covering the Middle East and Asia. We were so glad we decided to stop in Tokyo. The hotel was absolutely stunning. The lobby has magnificent chandeliers hanging and the staff was so lovely. Our room was very large as we were upgraded to a suite. In our suite we found pajamas that we enjoyed wearing during our stay. The view from our room on the 51st floor was spectacular. We could see out to Tokyo Bay.The bed was the most comfortable of our trip. Attached to the hotel was the Tokyo Midtown Mall. It had all the shops you could dream of as well as fabulous restaurants, bakeries and pastry shops. It was also attached to the subway system which made getting around Tokyo very easy with a Pasmo card( the concierge sells them). The hotel restaurants were very good but a little on the pricey side.The lobby lounge has excellent hamburgers, drinks and snacks. It has live music in the evening. If you can afford this hotel, it is probably the best in Tokyo.

With a wonderful centric location in Tokyo Midtown, the Ritz-Carlton Tokyo has by far the best hospitality and facilities of the city. You will get to admire one of the most precious hotel lobbies with impressive views of the city from the 45th floor of the building! From the staff, to the restaurants, to the glamorous accommodation - there is no doubt that experiencing this luxurious property is a must for any visit to Tokyo!

I have long loved this hotel, often saying it is my favorite hotel in the world. However, I do think the hotel is showing its age and there are definite areas where improvements are needed, especially when compared to other Ritz Carlton and high-end hotels - and I am writing this review comparing the Ritz to other Ritz properties and high-end hotels.My room was spacious with a view of Mt. Fuji. The bathroom was nice and had a shower, a bathtub and two sinks. Amenities are Asprey. The room had a safe large enough for a laptop which is important to me. While the desk offered sufficient power plugs, there were none near the bed – this is essential for business travelers today. Furniture is quite dated.The concierge lounge was perhaps my biggest disappointment on this trip. I must say that service was excellent – I was always called by name and the employees there were friendly, attentive, helpful, and courteous. However, the food offerings were, truthfully, pathetic – especially in the evenings. They were meager, at best. The Ritz should be ashamed – especially given the amount of money necessary to upgrade to the Club Level. One tripadvisor reviewer said they only offered lettuce and crackers – and, stunningly, there really was not much more than that. My advice to those staying in this hotel would be to not upgrade to the concierge level – it’s really not worth the additional cost.  And, finally, wifi was beyond terrible – it was difficult to get a connection and speeds were painfully slow and, as a result, it was difficult to work. In fact, at one point, I considered moving to another hotel because the wifi was so bad that I was unable to get work done. I did call the front desk and the receptionist was apologetic – but I didn’t get the sense anything could be done about it.I do still like the hotel. However, some investment in the property is needed to compete with other high-end hotels in Tokyo. While service is excellent, it is also important that the product be outstanding – and, right now, I’m not sure that is the case. Due to the decrease in quality of the concierge lounge and the wifi, I don’t know that I would stay here again.

This Hotel is almost intimidating. I was dropped off by a taxi in front of some pretty crazy automobiles. A vintage Aston Martin, two Bentleys, an Audi R8, Mazarati, and a few BMWs. I took the elevator to the lobby. It was on the 45th floor. The views were amazing. I missed the front desk because I was distracted by the bar/tea room and views over the city. There was a piano on a raised glass platform. Over. The. Top.The rooms were great. No complaints, but didn't blow me away the lobby did.Only down side was the front desk. While their english pronunciation was quite good, I felt like very simple concepts and requests seemed to confuse them and take a long time to sort out. I spent almost 45 minutes trying to check in because my upgrade to the club level didn't get processed as part of the original reservation. Felt like this was a far flung outlet of the Ritz that didn't understand how their rewards program and upgrades worked.

What can I say? Glitzy, glamorous, cosmopolitan, the best of the best in Tokyo. Located in the Midtown Tokyo tower, the rooms are on the 36th floor and above, so the panoramic views will be postcard-perfect. Our room had a view of Mt. Fuji. Rooms are enormous, bathrooms had tubs (with bath salts) and stand-up showers as well as separately-enclosed WC with Japanese washlet toilet. Staff speak multiple languages and will address you in your native language when you call room service, for example. Speaking of which, room service has excellent Japanese as well as western dishes (e.g. burgers, pasta). The Tokyo Midtown tower in which the hotel is located has swanky retail and restaurants and is connected to the Tokyo subway.

Enough cannot be said about this property....everything you come to expect from the Ritz brand. Hotel is remodeled, excellent service, great lounge, rooms are large and spacious, bathroom is huge. This is one of the better Ritz properties I've stayed at over, certainly book it if you're visiting!

This hotel is simply excellent. I have never had service of such a high level. The staff are so polite, attentive and helpful that they have spoilt me and will prevent me from ever enjoying a hotel again. I cannot thank them enough for what is and has been a world class stay and quite possibly the best hotel I have ever stayed in. The staff are willing to go the extra mile at every turn! Excellent!

If you are reading this review, you likely have stayed at a Ritz Carlton property somewhere in the world. You likely even may feel all Ritz properties are similar in their outstanding service. Well, this is indeed true with one exception: The Tokyo Ritz takes that level of service, comfort, and quality to the highest level. Having stayed in Ritz properties globally, as well as other high-end lodging establishments such as Four Season, Fairmont, etc, there are a many aspects of the RCT that differentiate it from the rest:Service: Simply put, it is perfection. Staff from the lobby to the Club Lounge anticipate every need. They are in communication with each other to ensure that happens and stand ready to provide the service and requests the guest needs. They know you by name (a quality essential at this level of hotel) and treat the guest with respect, kindness and a warm smile. I had some unique needs being a US Masters Distance Runner in town for the Tokyo Marathon and had special requirements for food and beverages as well as other essential items as my trip went on and had changing needs. There was not a moment that I did not receive personal attention to those needs. In my opinion, good service starts from the top and the Hotel Manager as well as the Club Lounge Director all demonstrate "what good looks like" so their staff clearly sees leadership's example. Best Club Lounge I have ever visited. Rooms: Clean, confortable, spacious and a home-away-from-home feel. Excellent beds, bathrooms, amenities and views. Housekeeping has an eye for detail you won't see anywhere. I know this since I had to spend a bit of time in my room so was able to see the staff at work. Amazing job. Having met the Assistant Director of Rooms, I can see why the rooms are the way they are. The hotel is looking to renovate rooms and they have the right person there to oversee it. Food: Considering my pre-marathon nutrition guidelines do not have me trying some of the great food they offer, what I did have was fresh, delicious, and plentiful. The Club Lounge variety of food throughout the several stages of their day is exceptional. Spa: As part of my pre-race routine, I have a massage at the hotel spa. The staff was excellent and my pre-massage and actual massage was wonderful and exactly what I needed. The facility is amazing, clean and calming. Fitness Center: Very good choice of machines and treadmills. An excellent 24 hour option for those with jet lag and want a great workout at all hours. I found the fitness center to be clean, well equipped and staffed by helpful employees ready to assist. And the views while on the treadmills are amazing.Location: Located above Tokyo Midtown, near the nightlife of Roppongi Hills and the Roppongi Subway Station directly below the hotel, you won't find a better location. The shopping and food just under the hotel is amazing and there is a 24 hour grocery store and a 7-11 for US travelers to get cash at the ATM. And of course, if you read other reviews you will note the hotel is above the 45th floor so the views from the lobby upward are breathtaking. Its unfortunate that there aren't 6 Stars as an option as this would be it. It all starts with the people, as it is irrelevant if the hotel is amazing but the staff isn't. In this case, the staff is the best and anyone considering the Tokyo Ritz needs to simply stop looking elsewhere and reserve your stay here. I know personally, I will be back in February 2016 and I will have stayed in many hotels between now and then and I can tell you now, each will be judged against this one and will be tough to beat.

Great hotel! the beds are incredible. Bathroom amenities and very nice. I stayed at the concierge level floor, which had pretty impressive service. Check in was at the concierge lounge, Even if you don't stay at the concierge level, the service is just outstanding! EVERYONE at the hotel knows your name, literally! EVERYONE GREETS YOU BY YOUR NAME. Wow. It is a pretty big hotel for this service. 5 stars for this hotel and all that represents it!

check-in desk is located on the 45th floor of the property, and rooms are above... as you can imagine, the view is just magnificent. Rooms are a very good size, and have all the amenities of a 5 star property, including a nespresso machine and tea service. Housekeeping service and attention to detail is impecable. The exercise room is wonderful, and so is the inside swimming pool, again, both provide sweeping views of the city and Mt. Fuji. The only drawback that I found was that the spa charges the equivalent of 50 dollars for the simple use of the steam room. I consider this service should be provided gratis to hotel guests.

Ok, so it's not the Lost In Translation Hotel, but it's fabulous. The views from your room (of Mount Fuji if you're facing the right way) or from the enormous lobby (of the city) are breathtaking. The food, service and rooms are all impeccable and at night, when the pianist is playing and the girl singing standards in the bar, it feels like you're in a movie. You're own movie.

What an amazing hotel. The view is simply breathtaking from there. Perfect location. My mother and I also had a drink in the lobby. Wonderful service!! For our next trip to Tokyo, we will definitely be back again!

This is a very good hotel and especially the views from the room and the lobby bar area are impressive. The room is good and has all it needs. The service was wonderful. Having said all this I must also admit that you expect this from a hotel like this and the price you pay for it. Therefore "very good" and not "excellent". If I would travel more regularly to Japan I would probably try out some other places to see the comparison.

We spent 4 nights. All was great ! We stayed in Club room. Perfection. Amenties, staff, room, confort and food.For sure, it was one of the best for us. The view was amazing. The higher place in Tokyo. Location is perfect.

As you can expect, this is really luxury hotel.Location is good, hospitality is really good. Location is perfect.But after I stay several hotel, consider the hotel room price, this is not the best hotel.Still lot place to improve.

Stopped over in Tokyo for an extended 3 day layover after a long week of work in Southeast Asia before heading back to the states. I always love visiting Tokyo but had never stayed here before.Wow. Yes, this place is pricey, though you can score decent deals in the winter, but it pretty much defines the saying You Get What You Pay For. I've been to the Park Hyatt, I've been to other 4 star hotels in the area (the Capitol Hotel is a less-expensive favorite) but if you have the means or feel like spending a few days pretending like you do this is the place to do it.My wife and I stayed in a Club level room - completely worth it, I've read a few reviews suggesting the Club has gone down in quality recently, which makes me think said reviewers are perhaps spending a little too much time in 5 star hotel clubs and need to take a break to get some perspective :) Breakfasts were excellent, afternoon tea was a delight, the service was top notch from start to finish - this is a place that appreciates your business and rewards it. Rooms are large (we had a standard), beds are super comfortable, bathrooms are ridiculously good, TV is nice and has HDMI so you can hook up your own laptop/streaming stick and watch your own TV while you fall asleep.Bar area is very nice with excellent views - I actually prefer the Park Hyatt a little, only because it is a little smaller and has a more intimate feel, the Ritz is huge with high ceilings. Personal preference and not a ding. Food is very good.Roppongi Hills is pretty much in the middle of everything and the hotel is right over Midtown Tokyo complex including several subway lines, making it easy to get around. We had no problem getting to Shibuya, Shinjuku, and Oedu. Rooms are top quality, Western-style for sure (as is the hotel), but that's what it's going for so you can't really knock it, if you want a more Japanese-style hotel there are other options out there. It's the service that really sets this place apart - they have a knack for knowing exactly when they are needed and exactly when to stay out of your way, it's eerie. When we arrived we left the bags with the porter on the first floor and they were in our room before we got up there - a first for me. We had a personal assistant show us to the room and walk us through detail. Every single person we interacted with remembered us as well as details of our day and what we were looking to do. If you are new to Japan or just want to be pampered (the level is entirely up to you) after a long flight this is the place.Oh and the views from the club level are spectacular, morning, noon, and night. Hope for clear days because it is something else.I'll be here again!

We just spent 3 nights at the Ritz Carlton Tokyo for our anniversary and it was the most fabulous experience. Honestly, it enhanced our visit and made it a celebration we will remember forever.  We stayed on the club level and our room was huge and with a spectacular view of the Tokyo tower and Mt Fuji. Plus the staff at the Club Level was extremely attentive, helpful and wonderful. They treat their guests like royalty. I don't remember everyone's name but the club Manager Desiree was wonderful and so was assistant manager Yoshikazu....but they were all very attentive and helpful..I just don't remember everyones name.The location was fabulous....lots of restaurants nearby and the subway is in the attached mall plus obviously the staff can get you a taxi immediately. The club room has a spectacular view of Mt Fuji. The breakfast had a tremendous amount of food and they will get you anything further you need and they make eggs any way you want...phenominal breakfast. There are meals and snacks and drinks throughout the day that were terrific.I highly recommend the Ritz for anyone visiting Tokyo...you won't get better service or view anywhere.

We stayed at the Ritz Tokyo for several nights right before Christmas and right after Christmas. The service level was superb--everyone from the concierge team, front desk personnel, restaurant staff, club level attendants, bellmen, and maid service. The hotel is conveniently located in the Midtown complex, which has many restaurants, shops, a small museum, a high end supermarket, and 7-11 convenience store. The complex is also connected to 2 subway lines. The surrounding area is know for "nightlife", and can get somewhat seedy at night on some streets, but still safe.The level of service was exemplary. The bellmen and front door staff were enthusiastic about helping with bags, and they also delivered the bags promptly even before we arrived to our rooms. The concierge staff were so helpful and assisting us with making dinner reservations and with printing maps for us to use when going to our restaurants (we learned that street addresses are confusing and insufficient in Tokyo, and only a map would help clarify directions). The restaurant staff and club floor staff were efficient and friendly. All the staff we encountered were pleasant and genuine, which is harder to achieve at a large hotel.We had breakfast at the hotel restaurant (Towers Grill and Azure) in all but one morning. The breakfast buffet was very well stocked with an assortment of fruits and breads, charcuterie/cheese/smoked fish, egg station, waffles & pancakes, and oatmeal made to order. There was also traditional Japanese breakfast items like grilled salmon, soup and rice. Although expensive, the breakfast was well worth it. The views from the restaurant were amazing.The 24-hour accessible gym was medium sized and adequately stocked with machines. The view was terrific, as expected. However, they did not offer any gym gear to sale (no shirts, shorts, baseball caps), only gym gear for rent. Although we did not swim, the lap pool looked clean and had a great view as well.The rooms were spectacular. Because the hotel is at the very top of an office building/mall complex (I think at the tallest building in Tokyo), the rooms are very high up and all have spectacular views. We had a view of Mount Fuji, and other rooms have views of Tokyo bay and Tokyo Tower. The rooms were very generously sized, and the large bathrooms had double sinks, a bathtub with separate shower, and a separate toilet room. Housekeeping did a terrific job each day and our room was cleaned very well. My only disappointment was that on our first of two stays, it was not clear to me whether the room was upgraded, as I have the Gold level in Ritz's loyalty program which normally has the benefit of an upgraded room. On our second stay, they did upgrade us.The club floor had very good service as well, but we thought the breakfast on the club floor had much less variety than the breakfast at the restaurant, although the evening wines and dessert presentations were good.It is easy to get a taxi from the hotel, and the attached mall had conveniences such as a foreign ATM card-compatible ATM machine, a Starbucks, a Japanese-style food court in the basement, various mid- to higher end restaurants, 2 subway lines, a small museum, a Uniqlo store, a Muji store, and various mid-to-high end clothing shops. The high end supermarket was terrific and we were able to buy snacks and beverages there.The immediate surrounding area gets somewhat seedy in one direction, however. In the evenings, when we headed back to our hotel from dinner, we would be accosted by people trying to get customers for hostess bars. This was a nuisance, but we still felt safe.The room had reliable wifi, and it was complimentary.We would definitely stay there again, and are already looking forward to our next trip.

review_body: The Ritz Carlton Tokyo provided us with the best possible views from the room of the extravagant city of Tokyo, the location is very nice and quiet. The hotel has the lobby in floor 45, our suite was in Floor 53, so we had amazing views to both towers and even , from the concierge lounge, we could easily spot the famous Mt Fuji.Katayama was an amazing host, very proffessional and with perfect English. He welcomed us and showed us our room and provided everything we could need. Arranged a Playstation in the room for our son and explained everything we needed to know.Next time I would not ask for concierge level, the only thing I liked is to have a good concierge in our floor, he was very efficient and help us a lot with our trip to Kyoto. It s great to have such a proffesional concierge, but the lounge lacked variety of meals and the quality of the food was not something we could appreciate. The staff is very attentive at the concierge lounge but they don t have too much to offer.We decided to have breakfast at the Grill on floor 45 as the breakfast was better, not superb, but better than the concierge level. A highlight in this hotel was to have a bath overlooking Tokyo from floor 53.. and dining at its great restaurants... the sushi was excellent and the designs of the Japanese restaurant was lovely as well. Very Good experience.

Had a wonderful experience with my family trip to Tokyo staying at The Ritz Carlton with arrangements made via American Express Platinum where we had four nights for the price of three. We arrived at Haneda airport which was about a $70 taxi ride, much better then the $120 fair to Norita. Arrived early morning and felt warmly welcomed by hotel staff. Hotel staff were great from start to finish. We stayed in room 5210 which is on the Club floor. I recommend the added cost for thee Club floor as there are all kinds of added amenities such as afternoon tea, snacks at night and breakfast including omlette bar in the morning along with its own concierge. Our room defined the word luxury. Large space, great linens, comfy bed, great view, unbelievable bathroom amenities. Located conveniently in "mid town" close enough to all the sites. No negatives except cost of taxi service back to Norita.

The Ritz-Carlton Tokyo is definitely one of the premier hotels in Tokyo's Minato area. As a solo female traveler, most people advised me that my experience could be mixed in Tokyo, but it was nothing but superb. The Ritz Carlton is located on the 45th to 50th floors of the highest building on Tokyo, so no matter which room you have, your views will be spectacular.Sushi dining at the restaurant the first evening was just excellent. The hotel concierge assisted me in securing a reservation at the Michelin star rated Sushi Masado for my second night. Concierge helped to arrange a full day tour around the city, which in my opinion, is a terrific way to see the city then decide which of the attractions require a second visit. The rooms were spacious and extremely clean. Everything was pristine, from the bathrooms to the windows. They take excellent care of details, and I appreciated that. Thank you for 48 wonderful hours in Tokyo (and free wifi)!Tip: Do try the bagged great tea in the room. Even their bagged teas are better than the higher-end ones outside of Japan.

We spend our new year vocation in Japan and we chose Ritz carton tokyo to stay in .. The hotel was great on all ..location,service,food,entertainment. It's connected to a mall and metro station and it located in the heart of the city . The frensh resturant Azure and the Grill tower resturant was serving the best food ever . I can say Ritz carton choice makes my vication un fogattable.

We visited Tokyo and we selected Ritz Carlton Hotel because of my Friends recommendation. First impression was "Wow"!! what a great stuff working in this hotel!! The room with stunning views, superb decoration, great bed (i ordered for my christmas present!!), wide spaces, cleanliness ... I wish enjoy this the rest of my life! Of course, staying in Roppongi district is fantastic for shopping and the receptionist was so helpfull selecting the most exotic shopping center, boutiques and places to visit.Indeed, I will recommend to everyone enjoy Ritz Carlton Tokyo. Thank you very much and i am looking forward coming back again in short.

We had a great time walking to dinner every night. It is close to every type of Japanese Cuisine you may want. It is also next to a very upscale mall, mostly food, so if you are a foodie, this it the place to stay. Wonderful service, and comfortable rooms.

I stayed 2 nights in the Tokyo Ritz Carlton and became a superb experience. I had stayed before in several hotels in Tokyo and be far the exquisite and at the same time friendly service outperforms other hotels I the same category.My room was spotless, with superb views and with the silence that helped relax and recover.Superb breakfast buffet.
