review_body: 5 star hotel with excellent service and facilities. Staff was very helpful and friendly. Fantastic stay and will definitely be back. Central location close to train station. Ideal for tousrists and business travelers.

When I go to Tokyo I usually stay at the Mandarin Oriental. This time, however, I stayed at the Ritz. As ever it did not disappoint. Service outstanding. In room dining the usual high quality. Bedrooms well presented and the usual large marble bathrooms. In addition the facilities (gym / pool etc ) were great with stunning views across to Fuji!Location is good with high class malls and bars just a short walk away.So whether doing business or just a city break this is a great spot. Don't miss it!

This is a lovely hotel with large spacious rooms. My room had a great view of the city. The lobby bar was always busy and atmospheric. Staff were all friendly and helpful. Would definitely recommend this hotel.

I love this hotel!I stayed for one night and was given room 5038, by way of an upgrade.The room is in the corner with very large double aspect windows, on the 50th floor. The views are absolutely amazing and the room is quite a lot larger than a normal room. The only potential issue is that you can slightly see into another room, though this wasn't a problem as there was no one in it.The beds are comfortable, the bathroom large, with separate bath and shower and two basins. I would almost describe the decor as modern Art Deco, if that makes sense.I also had a great breakfast.I can't recommend it highly enough.

My wife and I stayed five nights at the Ritz Carlton Tokyo and loved every minute of it. The room was gorgeous, clean and luxurious. The view from the 48th floor was never boring. The staff were all extremely professional and courteous.How great are they? One day we booked a tour to Mount Fiji with an outside tour group which was supposed to pick us up at 8:00AM. When the tour group had not arrived on time, the staff of RC called to investigate and found that the tour group had dropped the ball and forgot to send a shuttle. Ritz Carlton sprung into action and arranged a private driver to rush us over to the tour company's central hub and escort us to the tour bus, getting us there within 2 minutes of the final departure time. Without them we would not have made the tour. This is just one example of how they went above and beyond for all of their guests. Ritz Carlton Tokyo - If you read these, THANK YOU FOR THE AMAZING EXPERIENCE IN TOKYO.

From the main entrance delicately scented with the Ritz signature scent to the fully stocked vanities in the baths, they really do think of everything! Everything about this property feels luxurious. Just like any Ritz. The really special aspect of this hotel is its location and view. Perched atop Tokyo Midtown Tower it offers incredible views of Tokyo from every window. Have a drink or afternoon tea to enjoy panoramic views of the city. Actually do both so you can see it by day and night! My one complaint and it's probably more self inflicted... But coming from the office side of the plaza and trying to get to the hotel can be difficult. Even with signage I got lost more than once.

The Ritz-Carolton Tokyo is a great hotel. Stunning rooms which are very large, extremely large bathrooms. His and her sinks. Comfortable beds. Helpful staff that were willing to go the extra mile when asked. Stunning views of Tokyo. This hotel has a subway underneath with makes it very practical as well. It is also above the Midtown shopping mall with a Dean and Deluca and nice supermarket for any snacks etc.The breakfast is delicious. The nespresso machines in each room and in the lobby are great for coffee any time.Thanks to another traveller we found the Tim Burton exhibition at the nearby Mori Arts Centre which was very quirky.

I could not fault the rooms and the view here. As always staff are friendly and keen to be of service. I was on business. The room rate seemed fair but the drinks and food in the lounge were inevitably very expensive. The breakfast was limited for someone staying 11 days as I was. But good quality and cooked to order dishes really good. The room was the best though. 50th floor views. Huge bathrooms. Very decent size. Highly recommended if you're staying on business.

Beautiful view in the restaurant, the service was perfect! 20th Birthday really successful! I had this incredible wagyu beef in a pinot noir sauce, just melting in mouth. The new dishes of Chef Miyazaki are a success!

when I am in Tokyo, I either stay here or Shangri-La. this time I stayed at Ritz Carlton. as usual, service level was wonderful. the cleanliness the level of interior finish and attention to detail, excellent, especially after staying in other Asian cities where you can see unevenand poor quality interior finish, etc. Location is great, especially the wholeTokyo Midtown complex has everything you need, a museum, a supermarket, all the wonderful food shops and restaurants in the Midtown complex make it easier to eat out, bring prepared food in to your room etc. If you are into natural spices and sources, you can go to Kayanoya on the ground floor and they even serve lunch and dinner. there is a fish restaurant run by a famous fish store also on the ground floor. the view is great from all the sides. I prefer the side where you can see Mt. Fuji. but other sides include a view of Tokyo Bay with fireworks of Tokyo Disney in a distance, or Shinjuku skyscrapers. You cannot go wrong with this choice in Tokyo.

body language is bad. Speaks with very little courtesy and no smile? Am I in a Ritz Carlton?I love Ritz Carlton for its reputation as the best, please do not allow unhappy employees to spoil your image.

The hotel was fairly standard Ritz Carlton, so the real stand-out here was the exceptional staff. Extremely friendly and courteous. The room was spacious with a nice view of Mt. Fuji. The gym was clean and seemed to have newer equipment. The hotel is located above the Midtown shopping mall and was within minutes' walk of the Roppongi station. Very convenient location.Side-note: I love the Ritz Carlton's mobile app, wherein you can request amenities and they arrive within minutes. However, the dental amenity at this property contained the stiffest, most abrasive toothbrush I have encountered in my life.

Very elegant, as usually high quality food in restaurants and bars , very good spa, very good location. I like the bathroom very much, especially TOTO washlet. Of course, the breathtaking view from 50th floor. Also, I' m very satisfied with conference and banketing services. Location is very - near green garden. Possibly walking around and jogging.

Tokyo, Japan, is complicated, international -- yet firmly Asian, and urban busy with innumerable moving parts. Ritz Carlton Tokyo is likewise a marvel of countless, ever turning hospitality parts confidently interacting to the delight of an international guest base. The hotel is a fine movement Swiss watch (with Tokyo kinetics) ticking away at the comings and goings of global Urbanites expecting and getting Royal service and luxury treatment from all quarters of the hotel: Spa, Restaurants and Lobby. The key features are the forever cityscape vistas, as the property is located in a tall high rise building in Midtown. The lobby is on the 45th floor and at any given moment Tokyo City and Mt. Fuji views are breathtaking. Nothing compares. Very high above, nighttime Tokyo is as photogenic as any pablum smeared, rosy cheeked neonate in a bassinet. There are red lights dotting the vista exactly like a red headed, sickly kid with a case of the measles. Special to any camera toting neophyte taking spectacular pictures as if in a (light-show movie) of make-believe. Guest Services are the Ritz Carlton philosophy on steroids as the demands and expectations are endlessly serving a cornucopia of language variety. This is more so true in Tokyo than New York, London or Paris simply because the guest mix is intricate due somewhat to emergent Eastern wealth. People watching is priceless as the world calibrates to the rise of Asia and the meshing of Western economies and methods. The Ritz Carlton Tokyo is at the crossroads of the exciting trappings of East/West capability and culture. Amazing.The limitless amenities of the hotel are detailed elsewhere but the club level suites are a drop dead Tokyo bargain. Staying elsewhere in Tokyo seems thoughtless and silly. Hotel management and staff are the enviable model of graciousness and calm in a whirlwind of very big city doings.

The hotel is located directly above Tokyo Midtown shopping mall and has easy access to Roppongi station. Roppongi Hills shopping mall is also a couple of blocks away accessible via the metro/subway tunnels. [I don't recommend either Tokyo Midtown or Roppongi Hills for shopping]. The hotel's Japanese restaurant was under renovation during our stay but there are many other delicious eating options close to the hotel. Our room was on the Club Lounge floor so I don't know if ours was the "typical" room - it was quiet, comfortable, clean and HUGE. The gym is very good - lots of equipment and a nice attendant to make you feel comfortable. The staff are very helpful and friendly.

This hotel is luxurious, beautiful and with exceptional service. The rooms were spacious with great views of Tokyo. However, I thought the location was inconvenient for tourists. When using the trains & subways, I always had to transfer at a bigger station, which became annoying after awhile, esp if you get stuck during "rush" hour and have to squeeze yourself in (yes I had to do this)

My family and I are VERY frequent travelers so we have a fairly good baseline to judge good from bad and very good from world class. Without any reservations, I feel comfortable saying that this hotel has some of the best staff we have encountered anywhere in the world. On this trip to Tokyo, we actually did not stay at the Ritz Carlton but we did make sure to visit the towers grill restaurant on our trip. Not only did staff we had met on our previous stays make the effort to drop by and say ‘hello’, but the concierge did as well. We felt like royalty. We were greeted with our ‘usual table’, and everyone we encountered was vibrant, smiling and professional. The meal was up to the Ritz’s amazing standards and the entire experience was one for the books. Whenever we return to Japan, we will make an effort to stay at the Ritz; and regardless of where we stay, we will always visit the Towers Grill.

I've stayed at the Ritz Carlton Tokyo last year and had such a great time that I have booked into it again this year.Pre arrival service was great with dinging reservations arranged promptly by the concierge team.The arrival experience was great with staff readily at your service as soon as you step off your car.I have booked myself into the Japanese Carlton suite, the ambience of the room was wonderful with all standard amenities one would expect from a 5* hotel. However there's a very minor flaw to the overall decor of the room, that is the missing flower arrangement in the tokonoma. To many, this may not be of any importance, however, it's this kind of tiny things that differentiate between a good hotel to an exceptional hotel.Also, the fruit selection at breakfast seemed to have been impacted by cost cutting, what's left were items like orange slices. I mean, there is nothing wrong with that but when you charge so much for a room, you could have provided something more exotic. Nevertheless, it was still a very pleasant stay at the Ritz Carlton Tokyo and I certainly will return in the future.

Ritz Tokyo has surpassed my expectations of a luxury hotel with nice simple touches that make a difference ranging from towels and bottles of water upon arrival at the bell desk, to lemon/lime flavoured drinking water in the lobby, to jars of candy for children.The hotel rooms were huge by Tokyo standards, with double sinks, luxurious bath tub, fantastic toiletries and fantastic views of the city. We were lucky enough to be in a room where we were able to see Mt Fuji on a clear sunny day!One thing that was missing was a coffee machine, which I had seen in other similar category hotels. However, they do have a wide selection of teas. Location of the hotel is very good, with a short walk to the train station and many amenities in the mall downstairs especially a 24hr supermarket.Concierge was very helpful in making my restaurant bookings and also attaching the relevant maps and travel details.I have certainly enjoyed my stay and would return!

I have stayed in just about every Ritz Carlton in the US. I was hesitant about staying in this Ritz because of 2 reasons....the location and the price. The price is crazy and the location isn't the best but WOW.....it was an Ultra luxury experience......Lobby is.located on the 45th floor and when you enter the piano is playing and the tea service is in full swing. Staff...just wonderful...all of them...English speaking, polite and helpful.....amazing people!! The accommodations were just wonderful. Beautiful view, great amenities and well appointed. The whole experience was just breathtaking. The club level was a little limited but everything else was perfect......
user_name:
Tom F
New York City, New York

review_body: I have been many places but this hotel in Tokyo is probably the best service and best high end hotel that I have ever experienced. From the moment of arrival I felt as if I was royalty. The front desk greeter not only checks you in but stays with you and shows you to your room. THis hotel anticipates your every need ! It is a RITZ CARLTON so the reputation precedes itself but this hotel is BEYOND as the kids say… a lovely experience in a wonderful city.(… and the subway is below the hotel!!! how perfect is that!!!)

Nice view n very good location. Good service! Love it. Have a lot of restaurants and bars near by, we found it amazing before dinner just have an aperitif at the club on 53/F, nice view n relax! Worth to stay.

Nothing but good things to say about this hotel. It's screams class, charisma and style. Also the steak in the grill was exquisite. The rooms, the view, the employees and its location, all just make this a place to breath in deeply in and enjoy every moment. Certainly on my list of places to visit again.

The Ritz Carlton is located on the tower next to the best shopping mall in tokyo called “ Midtown”. The hotel starts on the 45th floor. From the 45th floor lobby featuring a lobby lounge, famous for its afternoon tea. You have as well the tower grill and the “Azur” French seafood restaurant. The rooms are very comfortable with large bathroom. They have an excellent fitness club and a 25m swimming pool. The food and the service are of high Ritz Carlton standard. The location is excellent just 5mn walking distance from the center of Roppongi and 10mn from Roppongi Hill. It is the place to stay in Tokyo if you enjoy shopping, eating and clubing.

This is a super hotel. Quiet. Serene. Traditional. Absolutely no bling-which is our preference. With a staff that works to make you feel like a welcome "guest".For a first time visitor to Tokyo, particularly one who had just fled Hong Kong and its street protests and more specifically, the concern that the army was about to attack its citizens for having the temerity to want to elect their own candidates without Beijing pre-approving the people they were voting for, this was a wonderful harbor from the storm. And we needed it.The hotel is well situated in midtown. There are a couple of outstanding and very reasonably priced restaurants w/in minutes of the hotel. The greatest of them all was "Meat Man" which may be the most remarkable and fun meal I've ever had. Ippudo is a stone's throw away and has fantastic Ramen. You can also walk to Gonpachi where "Kill Bill" was filmed and it's quite the show.The hotel has a wonderful club lounge and Desiree Overhage, its manager, is gracious, professional, friendly and competent. We turned over our 8 days to her and she made our vacation! We had read a couple of guidebooks but were truly at a loss as to how to "see" Tokyo and Desiree saw to it that we not only saw Tokyo, but the Tokyo that suited us. Many thanks to Desiree and her team.The rooms are large, quiet, comfortable and at least ours had a fantastic view. We visited the jacuzzi and pool on one occasion and it's lovely (though it sure has a lot of rules!). Happily, I don't have any tattoos nor affiliations w/any gangs so we used it as we desired.Japan is disorienting to a newbie. "Lost in Translation" means more to my wife and me now than it did when we left home...in every sense of the word "lost". However, we had a great visit and the Ritz was a big part of what made it manageable and wonderful. Highly recommend this hotel

There would be millions of ways in experiencing Tokyo ; yet if you are a busy person who can only squeeze a couple of days to relax , sightsee and shop around this fantastic city, The ritz carlton tokyo ought to be your first choice.Duration of stay : 2 nights (28/9/2014-30/9/2014)Location :The location of Ritz Carlton is the central business district of tokyo, and same as its counterparts in Hong Kong (my hometown) it occupies the top floors of one of the tallest tower in the city. So you don't need to go up to tokyo tower or sky tree to take pictures of the city whilst you get it every night of your stay. (Though, Upgrade is needed for views with Tokyo bay and Tokyo tower) Outside the building, you have 3 contemporary art museum (in which 3 of them are known as the art triangle in Tokyo ) and high end fashion malls selling Japan-exclusive luxurious products. The area is well designed in which you don't actually need a map as road sign with English is everywhere in the area. Hotel Transportation :Tokyo is somehow a well planned cosmopolitan and the metro / subway is well developed. And over developed. The complexity of the subway might beyond your imagination that the same station is shared by different subway companies and the map is more complicated than most major cities around the globe. Yet if you manage to do so you can take the monorail and then interchange to Roppongi and further walks for around 5 mins. The hotel in fact offers me the limousine service. It ranges from Rolls Royce to limousine taxi. This does not only help you to go to / from the airport but can also drive you around in Tokyo for your sightseeing pleasure. With the cheap JPY recently, I have no hesitation to enjoy the luxury limousine for only around 100 usd per hour. (However it should be noted that the limousine is actually very limited ; you better book early) Hotel design : As stated it locates on the top few floors of tokyo midtown. It has an entrance on the ground floor but it does not appear like a palace. The rooms (at least on my floor) are located like a maze. The exterior design of the complex might be nice , not the hotel part is not an amazing one. Room: As I travel in solo, I did not make any upgrade for my room. The size is reasonable (and may be a bit large in this crowded city) Yet still, the room is well furnished with a huge size of toilet. Not only does it has separate bathtub and shower, there are two washbasins and sizable toilet TV. (Attached night view from room of 51 floor) Meanwhile I aware that the room decoration is slightly different for two nights during my stay. It possibly depends on the personal style of the cleaner. Dinning :During my stay, all the hotel Japanese restaurants are under renovation. It's very frustrating that I can't try any of those.The breakfast is included in my package. It's in the style of buffet. (45F - restaurant "tower grill") The choice of food is not a wide range one and there's nothing surprise me regarding the food. However, what's better than having breakfast while enjoying the view of tokyo bay morning? The service depends on the number of customers. In my first day, the customers there are limited and I always got my juice and tea refilled. But not the second day. In room dining in fact surprised me. The room service menu is quite wide ranged. (Attached with an in room dinning - 3 courses) The quality of food is definitely high, in the standard of room services. Typically, the ritz Carlton special blend tea is a unique product here. Services : Japan is famous for personal service and here's no exception. The check in is done in my room directly. For those staffs who met me more than once, they address and greet me with my last name. A complement should be given as all staffs come inside my room pick off their shoes in the corridor before entering. ( This never occurs in other hotels I have ever been to ) I guess they probably aware that I have changed my outdoor shoes to the hotel slippers. The girl who assist me in check in grab my heavy luggage to the room. (Yes I use the word "grab" as she never let my luggage touches the ground even though it's the style with wheels) I feel so sorry as she is so young and small. Thus I give her a big tips. Pressing 9 in the hotel phone would directly pass to someone who can speak your language and assist you. However, as mentioned above there is a problem that this hotel staff is somehow insufficient, it may take a while to answer the call and / or to assist you in person. Like I called for removal of my tray after room service it takes like 45 minutes. Despite this, the staffs are very nice and polite. I would especially like to say thank you to Mr Sakamoto at door bell ; Ms. Tanaka at room service ; and Ms. Yokoyama at call center.Recommend ?It depends on what you need. If you are business traveller, I believe this is better than its major competitor grand Hyatt (same district ; similar pricing), at least in terms of the view. Of course if you are looking for sleeping on tatami to experience the old Japanese style of living then you should leave this page now. (There's actually one or two special rooms with tatami charging a "special price" ) Of course, it's would be nice to visit if the Japanese restaurant are functioned again.Fung (2014/09/30)

The service at this hotel was amazing! I would spend a little extra and get a room on the club floor. The views are spectacular no matter which of the two floors you are on and the food is ok if you are coming and going in between work.

I have seen some rather disappointing reviews here recently, and maybe I am not as fussy as others, but I had a very good 4 day stay here. All the staff were helpful, service was great, they helped me arrange a number of things - and all with a polite smile and great English.I guess the food selection on the Club floor could be better having thought about this after seeing some other reviews, but all in all a great stay.

I expected so much from this hotel, because I've stayed in many Ritz Carlton hotels and I've had flawless service - but not in Tokyo! I was on the club floor and had access to the lounge which serves drinks and snacks throughout the day. What annoyed me so much was, even though we stayed four nights the same staff member at the lounge asked our name and room number everytime. This happened several times. Sometimes, we were back 15 minutes later, we got asked again. Unbelievable!Service during tea time and breakfast was terrible. It took a while to be served even though some waiters were available, but did nothing. The waiters never asked to fill up coffee or tea. Mostly they were aloof. The food selection was very limited. However, the staff and concierge on regular lounge and lobby were attentive and professional. The last two days of my stay, I hung out at the regular lobby lounge. I'd rather pay than having to deal with snooty staffs in the club lounge - very unlike Ritz Carlton. The room decor is very dated and tired looking. It is a stark contrast from the lobby floor which is nice. On the positive note, the hotel location is great. It's joined with a shopping mall and metro. Overall, I'm very dissappointed with this Ritz Carlton. I wouldn't go back to stay at this hotel. There are better options in Tokyo.

The entire experience at this property is amazing. We were greeted upon arrival and personally escorted to the lobby level where the hotel begins and rises 9 floors atop of the 53 story building in the Roppongi District. Attention to detail was abundant. We were personally escorted to our room where a beautiful snack was awaiting us. The Club Room was remarkable with personal, attentive service. The staff took our lead. If we engaged in conversation, they engaged with us. If we went about our business they graciously served around us. The room was large and featured a luxurious bathroom and incredible view of the city. Upon exiting the hotel one day with a bit of rain and asking for directions, the attendant provided us with umbrellas and personally walked to an escalator, rode the escalator up with us, and pointing us in the right direction. The service was first rate. I will definitely stay at this property on my next visit to Tokyo.

TripsterJoe
New York City, New York

review_body: Wonderful hotel in an area close to businesses and government. Rooms were large and bright; the bathrooms outstanding. Some logistical challenges as lobby is on 50th floor, access to shops and building is a walk through a maze which is not well marked. Be prepared for a very expensive experience. The prices at the Bar and hotel restaurants are very steep (US $27 for one glass of wine) locals advise me that the up-charge is for the view - which is impressive! but be warned.

The Service was excellent. The views from our room on the 49th floor was amazing. We were able to get a picture with a rainbow in the background and overlooking the skyline of Tokyo. The Sushi and brunch presentation was above par. Well recommended.
user_name:
Grandtravels
New York City, New York

review_body: I have stayed in many Ritz Carlton in my life but this one is by far the best. Location is perfect, right at the top of Midtown Tower, top level shopping, great cafés and entertainment on Tokyo´s high end shopping mall. The hotel is very classy and has a very nice decor. The rooms are great, I stayed at the club level room and the service was outstanding. The club level private space is good too, champagne and canapés, private concierge, afternoon drinks, exclusive breakfast. Pretty much a great deal if you want to have a bit more privacy and upgrade even more the service during your stay. The room had probably the best views Tokyo can offer.

I was impressed with the guest rooms and common facilities. The guest rooms were very spacious, high tech (control panel for your toilet!!?), and comfortable. The gym, restaurant and lobby bar were all large, yet broken up so that background noise was never a problem. Expensive, but a very nice hotel.

My family recently took a trip to Tokyo, and we chose this hotel over Tokyo's plethora of luxury hotels for it's location. Situated at the heart of Tokyo Midtown, it is a block away from the clubs and stores of Roppongi and has an entrance to Tokyo Metro's Oedo line right in front of the building from which you can quickly hop over to Shibuya, Shinjuku, or even Odaiba. It's only a mile away from Tokyo tower and two from the Imperial palace. The service is impeccable as one would expect from the Japanese hospitality industry, and the views from your room of the Tokyo skyline are simply breathtaking. We will definitely return there again on our next trip to Tokyo.

I stayed at the Riz-Carlton Tokyo for a week in May 2014. The hotel has everything that you would want from an international hotel - large, comfortable rooms with excellent views, fantastic food and very good service. It also has a lovely bar area in the lobby on the 45th floor.I ate in the restaurant for breakfast every day and had room service for dinner a number of times. On each occasion, the food was really good, with a good selection of Japanese and international food.I would have no hesitation recommending this hotel. I very much enjoyed my stay.

Treated like a VIP- the staff here is incredibly professional and friendly. The Hotel itself is overwhelmingly impressive! Start with the lobby being on the 45th floor and enjoy the spectacular view of Tokyo! Beautiful decor- spacious and comfortable- the rooms were so fabulous that I didn't want to leave the hotel! The hotel brilliantly located adjacent to midtown which houses shops and restaurants- nearby food, dining, shopping 7-11 and a convenient supermarket as well. Subway stations are within a block and Roopongi is just down the street!I'd definitely recommend this hotel without hesitation. Staying at the Ritz totally made our trip to Japan a memorable one.

In Tokyo, you should look for properties offering expansive skyline views like Park Hyatt, Mandarin Oriental and Ritz Carlton. We had a dinner at New York Grill on top of Park Hyatt and the view is very impressive but we did not feel like staying there. We were hesitating between Mandarin and Ritz Carlton and decided for the Ritz.The lobby is on the 45th floor so when you get in, the views are magnificent. The lobby is both cozy and vibrant with very high ceilings, a restaurant, lounge, bar area with live music and all-around city views.The rooms offer spectacular views of Tokyo. They are elegant, clean and spacious. Not our style, but nice and roomy with large and well equipped bathrooms. If you like the Peninsula décor style, you’ll like the Ritz Tokyo style. We no fans of that type of décor but the hotel has many other charms that made our stay there memorable.The service is outstanding. The restaurant was very good. The concierge recommendations were precisely what we were looking for. The hotel location is in the vibrant financial city center where you will feel the energy of the working population of Tokyo. The Starbucks at the 1st floor is a great Starbucks and just getting my usual 5-Shot Grande Skim Milk Latte there is a great experience of the Japanese people. The order is taken with great respect like they all treat people. The order is delivered with extreme care and caution to ensure that you cup is 100% clean, not a single drop of milk or espresso could have tarnished the white cup. And when they put the lid on your cup, never will they touch the mouth hole with their fingers. Japanese people have such a phenomenal sense of respect for others, it drives all their gestures, way of life, driving behavior, something very special and worth discovering. It is only though the little things in life that you do while in Tokyo that you discover them and appreciate how they are and how nice they can be.So back to the Tokyo Ritz Carlton… would we return? Yes we would. We would still hesitate between Mandarin and Ritz, and that only for the restaurants they both offer. The Mandarin has a phenomenal restaurant but it was closed when we were there so we tried the Ritz and we not deceived at all, we had a truly good time in Tokyo there, much more then when we stayed in Tokyo at Peninsula.Enjoy!

The Ritz-Carlton Tokyo has a staff that makes your stay a delight. Everyone is helpful and courteous. Our room on the 52nd floor was lovely and the view of Tokyo was spectacular. The lobby is so beautiful that you want to spend time relaxing with tea or a glass of wine while listening to the piano. The location was excellent for business and pleasure. A true delight of a luxury hotel.

I've stayed here twice now, once in 2010 and once in 2013. I travelled here on business and the company that hosted me had the entire 48th floor booked to them. The view is spectacular from the rooms. There is a photo of the view from our room on my website, right after the photos of Morocco, here's the link. http://www.robbahou.com/gallery/travelHonestly, the highlight of my trip was the japanese toilet. These people have got it right. Who needs toilet paper when you have technology?Toilet humor aside, the location is great, right in the middle of Roppongi district, ripe with nightlife and fantastic sushi restaurants.

I have now had the chance to stay at the Ritz Carlton, Tokyo MidTown, on several trips over the last couple of years. It remains consistently one of the finest run hotels I have ever frequented. The service is superb, the rooms are gracious, and the location, at the top of one of the tallest buildings in Tokyo, and sitting on a hill, provides simply stunning views from every window in the building. Yes, the hotel is not cheap. But, for a few hundred dollars a night more, you get a truly remarkable stay. If you can't quite push yourself to afford the cost of a stay there, I recommend stopping in to the lobby bar for a drink or tea (albeit not cheap either). The lobby is on the 45th floor and has exceptional views of the city. It may be one of the nicest hotel lobbies in the world.I stay for business, but I could see this being a fine hotel for families or vacation travel.

Simply outstanding! The best Ritz I have been so far. The rooms and installations are amazing. Actually, the view from my room was top notch (almost like postcard)!The location is just perfect! In the heart of Minato. I told the concierge I wanted to go to Kyoto and he helped me with everything. The very next morning I had an itinerary in Kyoto with private chofer and tour guide. He also took care of the bullet train tickets and the hotel. The service is wonderful. I had a problem because my husband sent me flower for our anniversary and somehow there was a confusion and I did not get the flowers. The Ritz manager came to my room and deeply apologize. Then, he more than compensated me for the flowers and even accompanied me (with other three people from his team) to take the airport's shuttle when leaving.No doubt. If you want an outstanding place in Tokyo, go to the Ritz in Minato.

Beautiful hotel, nice size rooms, nice gym and with the hotel being on the upper floors you get beautiful views. Also had a nice meal at the restaurant on the lobby floor. it's in a convenient location with several metro station fairly close by. Hotel staff is extremely helpful.

Probably the best hotel in Tokyo. This hotel is featuring beautiful decorated, well-appointed and spacious rooms, stunning views, outstanding Club Lounge, good location (Tokyo Midtown Shopping mall, Art Center, Roppingi Hills area and other parts of Tokyo are easy accessible through the nearby Tokyo Metro Roppingi Station) and on top that excellent service, as expected from Ritz-Carlton which is from the moment of check in the moment until departure very hard to beat.I would recommend booking a Club level room or suite which includes access to the Club Level Lounge including breakfast, afternoon tea, cocktails and amazing views over Tokyo. Will definitely return in the future.

Wow. Might seem a little expensive, but worth every penny. The view from the hotel room is impressive. The hotel is very well located in the heart of Tokyo. The service is impeccable. I enjoyed everty minute of this stay.

Just stayed 3 nights at Ritz Carlton Tokyo. Arrived from New York on Saturday July 5th and departed Tuesday July 8th. The personal attention paid to guests is 5 Star. Every need or request is promptly attended to. Our room was on Floor 51 and the views were amazing. We saw Mt. Fuji on a clear morning. The rooms are spacious, beautiful decor, awesome large bathrooms with twin sink and vanity arrangements.The pool, spa and gym located on the 46th floor is awesome. Great pool and swam every day. Here is the one flaw. The 45th Floor lobby is such an amazing large open space to enjoy the hotel, the coming and goings of guests, amazing views and great service - but it is ruined by allowing smoking. The room stinks! and so will your clothes and hair. My wife was so turned off by this!Coming from the U.S. one certainly does not understand indoor smoking anymore and this hotel should eliminate the practice or provide a smokers lounge. End the smoking and the property is perfect.Final note, the hotel is located within the Tokyo Midtown development which has a luxury shopping center, gourmet market, Dean & Deluca, restaurants and the Suntory Art Museum all located in the basement through 3rd level.Enjoy your visit. I would return.

Top notch hotel with great amenities and views - like all other reviews state.PROS- top floors of Tokyo's tallest building. I wasn't facing Tokyo tower nor Mt Fuji but had great city views- Large (large!) rooms with very large bathrooms. Toto bidet, multiple sinks, separate shower/tub.- Effective electric drapes - important in the summer in Tokyo. It starts getting bright at 4am!- Good dinner options in the mall. Starbucks at the Tokyo Midtown plaza level. Grocery store in the mall basement (24 hrs)- 10-minute walk to Roppongi Hills and Mori Tower- really great 46th floor gym and pool area- Plenty of water bottles and refills- No internet surcharge. Good internet speeds for video chats.CONS- If you need to get to Otemachi, Nogizaka station is a bit of a walk (more than half a mile)- Oedo line is closest from the mall basement, Hibiya line is a bit of a walk too. - The access to the Tokyo Midtown plaza is really annoying if you do it on a daily basis. You have to walk all along the perimeter of the building at level 1 to get to the plaza side. Unless you're taking cabs all the time that's the exit you're going to be taking.- Breakfast will run you approx 5000 JPY. This is the Ritz after all.- Limited TV cable selection. No HBO - Japanese TV quality is poor (World Cup is on Japanese TV)- Slow room service (35+ mins) at busy times

The title of this review says it all. The hotel is beautiful, the rooms are spacious, the views are spectacular, the location is perfect, but the staff tops them all. Without a doubt the best service I've ever experienced!At check-in, my wife and I informed them that we were on our honeymoon. They upgraded us to a club-level room with a spectacular corner room view. They gave us a lovely gift of teas to enjoy and sent up chocolates after we were settled. While enjoying the wonderful high tea service at the club lounge we now had access to (note: there was food constantly being served - breakfast, snacks, hors d'oeuvres, cordials and sweets), my wife and I mentioned how much we enjoyed the tea and asked if there was a way to purchase some for the remainder of our round the world honeymoon trip. Helena, who had stopped by to check on us, returned with a handful of various teas for us. These are the best examples of their great service, but not the only ones. From the maid service, doormen, and bellmen, to the concierge and the front desk - everyone was extremely polite, giving, and eager to make sure that we were enjoying our stay. What more can you ask for?

If you can afford it, do it. Great room, great service, great views, great restaurants and facilities, great location (right above Midtown Tokyo). Can't really think of anything to criticize--it was that perfect. Super-expensive, but I guess that's to be expected.

The Tokyo Ritz-Carlton is situated on the top 8 floors of one of the tallest buildings in Tokyo, and the views are spectacular, both day and night. The club level staff is quite international, and Desiree, the club level manager from Germany, was helpful and attentive. The location in Roppongi is good, but you really need to get on the subway and go to Harajuku, or down to the famous fish market in Tsujiki, both of which are only about 15 minutes away. As dedicated foodies, Helena's suggestion of the restaurant Kaikaya, was amazing!

The Location is Perfect! And U have Lovely view from the Rooms!The Design of the Lobby is super refined, and every inch of it is stylish and elegant. The staff is very professional and they have great restaurants!

The Ritz Carlton Tokyo is one of my favorite business hotels in Asia. The lobby is located on the 45 floor of the building so all of the rooms have great views of the city. The rooms are very nice and the service here is excellent.

This is a fabulous hotel in a great location close to the fun of Roponggi. It is in the tallest building in Tokyo so the views are stunning across Tokyo. We had a suite with two way views which were fantastic day and night and we had a view of Mount Fuji. The room was beautifully furnished and the bathroom was amazing - so big and spacious and all the luxuries you would expect from a premium hotel brand. The service was exemplary and staff very friendly and professional. We had room service for breakfast and for one evening and the food was of a very high standard. Staff also laid it out beautifully on the table in our living area just making having room service a little more of an experience. If you want to spoil yourself in Tokyo then this is the hotel. There is an upmarket mall attached to the hotel for some retail therapy and a number of fabulous restaurants in the hotel. But if you want to head out, as mentioned the lively Roponggi is a stones throw away. A must if looking for some luxury in Tokyo.

Hotel is located in Roponggi area.Nice area lots of Restaurant / Pubs Not far from Shibuya Shopping area.Hotel is top few floors of Office Building (probably the tallest one in this area)All Rooms have great view of TokyoLounge also have amazing View of Tokyo.Pool is nice (indoor) and heatedI usually stay in their international roomsThis time I got the traditional Suite.Its actually quite an experience. It a traditional Japanese room, tatami mat and sitting on the floor type of setting.Service staff are great always friendly and helpful and trying to anticipate your needs.Many choice of Food in the Hotel + All have excellent view of the City

It is a very good hotel, everything make you fill so pampered, every body is vey polite…. they helps you in any way you request. Some bed rooms like in the one we stayed in, and the bar, which is absolutely beautiful, have Mt. Fuji view, that makes them breath taken,the sushi restaurant very good. It was the best hotel we stayed in. It is worth the price you pay.

Everything you'd expect and then some from a Ritz Carlton. Unbelievable views from the rooms and bar. The staff were extremely friendly and willing to go the extra mile (they helped us secure a great reservation at a wonderful sushi place).Rooms are much larger than I expected; the bathrooms were the size of some hotel rooms. Fitness centre is a bit tough to navigate; seems you need to be a member to use the pool.

The hotel is exactly what you would expect from a Ritz Carlton, luxurious and sophisticated. You are catered to every minute of the day without it being annoying or intrusive. There is a lovely lobby bar and the restauarant there is top notch. There is a mall underneath which is very convenient for a break from hotel life. The pool is great and so is the spa. Staff is extemelt polite and helpful. I loved this hotel.

We arrived late, checked in and went for a swim and a Jacuzzi to perk up after the flight form Dubai; fabulous pool and great views from the (very) hot jacuzzi. After that we had a cocktail in the beautiful lobby bar, which is smartly “divided” from the chic main lobby by a stunning water feature.In all, we stayed 4 nights here and had a fantastic time. The room was large and appointed perfectly as in Ritz Carlton style; great walk in shower and very comfortable bed. We had a Mt. Fuji view but the unfortunately the hazy weather was not our friend. The staff could not have been more helpful in making and confirming dining reservations as well as giving directions for touring around the local Roppongi area. The great jet lag revival massages in the ESPA are to be recommended and they did what the name implies and really set us up for the first day. The hotel is superbly located not just for local Roppongi but all of central Tokyo is easily and quickly accessible from the adjoining subway line. The last day was a treat as all the cherry blossoms started to come out in the park around the hotel. Would most definitely stay again.

Stayed at the Ritz Carlton Tokyo for 9 nights on business on the Club Level. I had my family with me as they chose to tag along and see the sights of Japan (wife and 10 year old daughter). Pre arrival - the Club Lounge concierge (Katori-san) was absolutely fabulous. Booking sighseeing tours, sumo ticktets and suggesting things for my family to do while I was working - before we even arrived. I can't say enough about him. He also met us upon arrival from the airport - escorted us from the main entrance to our room on the 53rd floor with exceptional views (a corner room with wrap around views) and completed the check in from the comfort of our room. During our stay I cannot give enough praise to the entire Club staff. From Desiree, the Club Manager, to Katori-san, who seemed to be our personal attendant, and Helena another exceptional Club attendant - anything we needed was either anticipated or immediately delivered when ordered. My daughter was doted on like a princess every day and truly enjoyed telling everyone about her daily activities and the sights that she had seen. When we checked out she went to say good bye to Katori-san, and could not find him in the lounge, she was heartbroken. That is, until we arrived downstairs to find him waiting at the car to wish us good bye with a "care package" of goodies for her to take on the plane! Absolutely great personal service! And always with a huge smile on his face. My only negative comment on the Club is my disappointment with the food offerings. For the money paid to stay on the Club Floor I would expect more. I have stayed at other high end properties across the world (and even slightly lower rated (JW Marriott, Grand Hyatt, etc) and the food offerings for both Breakfast and evening hors d'oeuvres in the Club lounges at other hotels far exceed those offered here. After reading the reviews on this site it appears that the food has been scaled back recently - which is very apparent when comparing to other hotels I have stayed it. That is my only "negative" comment, and is meant more for informational purposes. Other reviews have covered the rooms and location so I will not get into those details here. I look forward to my next visit to Tokyo and will definitely be again staying at the Ritz Carlton - I can only hope they go back to the "old" food offerings in the lounge.

Pre-arrival:Queries were answered and actioned quicklyRestaurant bookings were made and follow up in a timely manner.Arrival: Checking was fast and efficientThe property was well maintained Room was large (in Tokyo standard) and comfortable with magnificent view (how could it not be when it was on the 50th floor?)Overall:Magnificent hotel with the usual Ritz standard

Just spent a few nights back at the RC in Tokyo and must say it always exceeds my expectations. Top quality service, unusually large rooms for Tokyo, gorgeous views of Mt. Fuji and other Tokyo sites make it my favorite. Plus, location is ideal for enjoying the Rappongi district with its great bars and restaurants. Always a joy

I've been at Ritz Carlton Tokyo at last April. The hotel is amazing, located at the highest building of Tokyo, Tokyo Midtown at Roppongi. Easy to reach by car or subway (the station is linked to the hotel via underground) and with one of the best views of Tokyo. The staff is very kind, the concierge is always ready to help us and have nice restaurants. Breakfast is really good with american and asian choices.

Stayed in Ritz carlton for 2 nights. Ritz carlton is undoubtedly one of the splendid hotel in Tokyo. Incredible service. Very good customer experience. offers great view, great food. very supportive staff. I had a wonderful stay.

Wonderfully run hotel with exceptional service and true Japanese "Omotenashi". I am a frequent visitor to Tokyo and have stayed at the Conrad which I absolutely adore. Our company hosted an event and a group of us from the US were booked at the Ritz Carlton. The rooms are spacious and very quiet. The bathroom was large with separate tub and shower. Great offerings at the breakfast buffet. Although I didn't visit the lobby bar it was crowded every night and seemed like quite the spot (though I cannot get used to all of the smoking which is still permitted in public places in Japan). Front desk staff were beyond courteous. We had one odd interaction with the concierge who claimed she didn't know any restaurants to recommend in Nakameguro which is a lively, hip neighborhood. Otherwise, it was a perfect stay.
user_name:
JasperNYC13
New York City, New York

review_body: Spectacular views from the lobby (45th floor) in the evening with cocktail "Norwegian Wood"... Comfort, peace and quiet...The best bathroom I ever saw on 52th floor with huge window and great overview.Excellent staff made everything to satisfy all my needs and wishes.

The Ritz Carlton Tokyo was in a great location to explore Roppongi :) Many neat shops, restaurants & bars are within walking distance. Our favorite part of our stay was having high tea in the lobby :) The outstanding service, decor and beautiful views of Tokyo make this hotel a perfect choice :)

We are regular visitors to Tokyo and have stayed at many of the hotels. This was our third time at The Ritz Carlton and have to say that the service this time really made us feel special. The attention to detail by the staff is commendable. The check in experience, the personal touch given by those you come into contact with really makes you want to go back again. The room is large for Tokyo, and the views wonderful. The bathroom is huge, and whilst not new the rooms are immaculately clean and well maintained. We spent time at the swimming pool which was tranquil and thankfully not too busy, and has great views of Mount Fuji. This trip though the highlight was the Club Floor Lounge. If you want to treat yourself then splash out and you will not be disappointed. For the extra cost you are offered a complimentary bar (including champagne), and a delightful five displays a day food buffet (afternoon tea is particularly special). We were offered an upgrade this time (which has never happened to me at a RC before, but was very much appreciated). A special mention to the entire staff in the Club Lounge who really did excel at customer service. They remembered the small things like what tea you are drinking, they refreshed the pot just as you poured the last cup and more importantly genuinely showed an interest in us. A fabulous and memorable stay.

My associate and I visited the hotel in early May and had club floor rooms with a great view of the Tower. We were taken to the lounge for check in which was quick and easy. The room was great and the selection of English television stations was acceptable. I'm usually away from home for a month at a time and having access to English speaking television allows me to feel closer to home.The lounge staff were very helpful and friendly. I was wanting some strawberry jam at breakfast and while not immediately available, they located enough to keep me supplied for my trip. Much appreciated.Room was spacious, clean and quiet, just what I needed after a long flight.Check out was easy. I plan to visit the hotel again during my next visit to Tokyo.

Great hotel, everything is of high standard. Rooms are very nice - although not as spacious as Peninsula - but definitely still larger than the norm in Tokyo. Check-In and Bell service most efficient. Staff very friendly and helpful. Located in the very chilled-out Midtown.

Rooms are spacious. Good location. Helpful staff. I would highly recommend the hotel in all respects. If you're transferring to another airport, you can have the staff send your bags ahead of time. Breakfast is wonderful; worth every penny. Gym is great as well as spacious gym.

The Ritz-Carlton Tokyo has a great view of Tokyo from all sides. Our room, tower deluxe, looked out on Tokyo Tower and the Tokyo Skytree. I don't think there is a bad view for any of the rooms in the hotel.The rooms are spacious with large bathrooms. We had two double beds for 3 people and a feather free room. There is a metro station below the hotel and one a few blocks away. This makes traveling around Tokyo convenient. A few negatives this trip. Only Rose and Jake from housekeeping figured out there were three of us in the room, not two. They made up our room later in our stay. The concierge was unhelpful for most of our trip. I wrote one month in advance to get information and make plans. The requests that were made through reservations were honored but none of the concierge on duty knew about my other requests.This is not a child-friendly hotel. The pool area is closed to children after 5pm and all of the restaurants are upscale. The mall located on the lower floors of the building has convenience stores, restaurants and a grocery store.Just as we were leaving, Tokyo Midtown was having an art festival. We got to see a few of the works before we left. Unique and delightful opportunity.

Previous reviews have all mentioned the good points : location, views, decor etc. The. Ritz Carlton has everything you could expect from a 5 star establishment - but its the people and little things that happen that makes an experience above and beyond expectations and this is what makes the Ritz Carlton Tokyo a great epxerience.As with all experiences involving human interactions, errors and mistakes do happen and its the revovery and "after service" that either makes it or destroys it. We had a couple of incidents at this hotel and the staff were brilliant at recognizing the errors and fixing the issue well and beyond thus turning a potentially negative situation into a positive one. Examples included a shoe polish incident (a bronze coloured shoe returned a patchy black - which was then ultimately fixed to "almost original" colour) - a gesture of apology included a complimentary send off in their Rolls Royce to the airport on our departure. A minor housekeeping error - a cleaning cloth was left behind in the bathroom - the housekeeping manager came personally with a bowl of chocolate almonds to apologise. What impressed us was the immediate follow up action and care taken - it wouldn't have been such a great experience had management ignored or not taken any action.As we stayed 5 nights and used the Club lounge, it was refreshing to see that the club lounge staff recognized us, what we liked and our preferences. On our last day, one of the club lounge staff (a trainee intern from Singapore) was so thoughtful as she presented us with a small package which included a selection of the teas that I had been trying each day at the lounge. A small token but very thoughtful. These little experiences made a good one great! We had a great time in Tokyo, in part because of the warmth and wonderful people at the Ritz Carlton who made all the difference. This was our first stay at a Ritz Carlton and if our budget allows it - definitely will not be our last!

We stayed for a total of seven nights breaking our visit after four nights for a side trip to Kyoto and a five night stay at the Ritz Carlton Kyoto (see separate review).The hotel is pretty much what you would expect. Great views of Toyko, especially at night, and a good central location. The rooms are large with all of the usual 5 star amenities although the furnishings are starting to look a little dated. We opted to stay on the Club floor which on balance was worth the extra cost. Some reviewers have been a little negative but we found the breakfast and the free drinks and snacks which are provided perfectively adequate. Service is generally good and the staff are helpful.This is a safe choice for a visit to Toyko and a hotel which we would be happy to visit again.

Having stayed here many times on business, loved the Club Lounge atmosphere, staff, fragrance that wafts through the hotel, its "almost" perfect. However, 2-points down due to the fact that the Club Lounge have "drastically" reduced their Evening Canapés, and to be honest, their is really nothing to nibble on unless you like lettuce or crackers. Very sad that they have cut back considerably since April 1st, plus the extra 3% tax hike, does not make this such a great deal. Same price (or thereabouts) is the Shangri-la, Tokyo, which has a great location, and a much better "Evening Canapés" - Ritz Carlton is beautiful, don't get me wrong, but if you enjoy the evening time in the Club Lounge, you may well be disappointed.Checking-out is a nightmare when they are a wee bit busy. Took us 20 mins on Wednesday, so leave time if you're in a rush to catch a train/plane, they don't rush, despite the polite "Hai, wakarimashita" It has no meaning. So there you go, minus one point on each count.

Our stay at Ritz Carlton Tokyo was on the 2nd-8th April, we were lucky enough to enjoy the cherry blossom as well. Ritz Carlton's room size is quite big, both for Tokyo and International standard, this is my second time staying at the hotel already.Bed - a bit on the soft side but it is very comfortableview - we have a mt fuji / roppongi hills view, very niceservice - very helpful coincerge , efficient check in . I would like to offer special thank you for their Assistant Manager Kris Kaminsky, he wrote us a welcome card during our first stay, and again on the second stay, he wrote us a welcome and leaving card as well. We feel that he truly appreciates guests and did his best to welcome us. i was travelling with my 3 year old daughter and my mom and dad during the second stay , they were kind enough to make special arrangement for us.Food - We had champagne brunch at the tower grill, overall it wasn't as great service as the first time. there was also a mis-understanding of the seating time, they actually didnt inform us on the 2 seatings and later we were informed we had to leave at 12.45pm ( we started at 11am ) and when we asked to start the champagne at 12.30pm-2pm ( 1.5 hr ) they said we only had 15 mins left, anyway, it was also sorted by their restaurant manager in the end.Spa facilities - it was high end and very luxurious, my only suggestion is that : at the pool side, they have 2 lounges that are for members, my mom, dad and daughter were swimming in the pool and wanted to rest at the lounge chairs, all the chairs were fully occupied, apart from the two members only chairs, my mom and dad couldn't read english, hence the mis-communication and mis-understanding, they were upset they couldn't used the two chairs, perhaps it is a good idea also to make it in other languages other than in English, Overall, it was a great experience, we enjoyed ourselves and will definitely come back.

Very modern hotel with a great service. The spa hot tub has a great view and the massage was very professional! Wish the spa was bigger but I guess for Tokyo standard it is big:)Loved the design and service. Location is great and close to many activities.

First off, I have to acknowledge that they have free super fast WI-FI that is a real relief. It's easy to connect too as well. I have been to this hotel before for conferences (beautiful meeting spaces)but never stayed overnight as a guest. We stayed one night in a one bedroom suite that was incredibly expensive, 18,000 yen BEFORE taxes and this suite has no powder room. It was OK in size but the smallest suite in comparison to other comparable hotels such as the Grand Hyatt n Roppongi, the Penninsula in Ginza, and the Mandarin Oriental and Four Seasons in Marunouchi. The room was nice and had some nice Japanese design touches like washi on a niche wall and Japanese furniture, but overall was not warm or evocative. The bed was very comfortable and it has all the latest technologically advanced amenities you could name including an automatic flush toilet which we actually really disliked. The service was not up to par with the rooms. In all, I have to say the Peninsula is much better in terms of service and value. The suites and rooms are much larger there and it is a better value. I expected much more for what we paid. I think they were at 100 percent occupancy when we stayed and it was very quiet in the room. Also, this hotel starts at the 45th floor so you have to take 2 banks of elevators to get to your room which is annoying especially when they are busy. Location is difficult.

I had a 3 night stay in March for a business trip from the US. The hotel was just perfection from start to finish. The service overall was the best I have ever had in any hotel in the world. Beautiful lobby when entering the 47th floor, great personalized check-in, the views from my room were so insane - I could see nearly all of Tokyo, nice big room with lovely bathroom with soaking tub, shower with rain shower head. I loved that there were two types of bath salts offered for the tub, and of course the toilet was amazingly high-tech.The best part to me - being extremely jet lagged - is that I did not hear a single sound from my room while I was in it. I did not hear any outside noise or hallway noise, no annoying beeps or people's footsteps - it was HEAVENLY!!The hotel's restaurant options are all excellent and perfect for a jet-lagged business traveler, and the breakfast buffet was great. Free Nespresso in the lobby was extra nice.I squeezed in a 90 minute spa treatment my last night and it was totally relaxing and great. The spa front desk fit me in for an appointment without a prior reservation and the therapist was excellent. The heat room experience in the ladies locker room was great with a hot tub overlooking the Toyko Tower - will never, ever forget that view.Super easy to get a cab or car to the business district, and I felt very safe walking around the Roppongi neighborhood in the evening by myself.

travelgal30
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: This hotel is amazing on many levels. First of all, it sits atop one of the highest buildings in Tokyo (rooms start around the 47th floor and extend to the 53rd). It is brand new and state of the art. The rooms themselves are very large, full of amenities, and have amazing views. The other facilities (restaurants, bar, lobby, spa, etc) are impressive as well. In fact, the gym/pool is probably one of the nicest and best equipped workout areas I have ever experienced at a hotel anywhere. The location of this hotel is in a trendy, newly developed area called "Tokyo Midtown"--full of wonderful stores and restaurants. This part of the city is very friendly to foreigners (not always the case in Tokyo). The best part of the hotel is the service. They really try hard to provide a wonderful, personalized experience for each guest. I have both lived and traveled in Tokyo, and I would say that this is currently the best hotel in the city. It's quite pricy, but worth it. Saw a couple of celebrities during my stay.

Obviously this is a very nice hotel with an amazing level of service from the staff, comfortable rooms with great views of Tokyo, posh fittings throughout, including the bathrooms. It's in a fantastic location with a train station right out the door and amazing restaurants and attractions within a very brief walking distance. It's probably the proximity of all those great places to eat that make the restaurants attached to the hotel itself seem so overpriced. There's a nice spa with a lap pool, and exercise room with plenty of equipment available from 7:00 am. (Not sure when they shut it down.)The English channels are few on the television. Great place to stay in Tokyo.

The hotel meets all the requirements set to the 5 star hotel, - good food, attentive service, comfortable rooms... But it has one really remarkable point, - one of the best city views you can find in Tokyo. Do not hesitate to pay a bit more for the rooms with better view. And, of course, you find yourself in the heart of the fast moving Roppongi.Minus, - the rooms are a just bit dated.

We stayed at the Club Level on the 53rd floor for a week and savored every moment. The view from our room was enjoyed every night and morning. Club service breakfast and evenings cocktails were delicious and convenient. The lobby is spectacular. The club concierge printed maps for every adventure. The bathtub in the room with a variety of sea salts was extremely relaxing each night. I could live in that room forever!

Great hotel, wonderful location, friendly and helpful wait staff. All you'd expect of a ritz. Only downside was that western breakfast and room service was not as good as other ritz properties we stayed at. Would recommend to anyone staying in tokyo.

We spent three nights at the Tokyo Ritz Carlton and we can only say a new benchmark has been set for our family. We stayed here Mid-December after a couple of weeks in Thailand. From minute one, we were treated like royalty. There are too many positives to list all of them, but here are a couple: The room was fantastic, with incomparable views of the city, amazing. Our two kids, aged 2 and 4 loved playing on the ledge up against the windows, no fear of heights with those two. The size of the room was excellent, as well as the exquisite bathroom. The club lounge was fabulous, with a nice breakfast and snacks throughout the day and evening. The location was great, you do not have to step foot outside for anything as the shopping mall and Metro station are all contained in the same structure. What impressed us the most, and we have retold this story dozens of times, is what transpired after my son left his teddy bear at the hotel. On the plane home, my son notified us that his Oreo Bear was missing. Catastrophic images tore through our heads of the many sleepless nights ahead... When we returned home, we indeed confirmed that Oreo was nowhere to be found. I sent an e-mail to the RC asking if by-chance they had found Oreo Bear. I received a response from Toshinori Tanaka, loss prevention at the RC. There was a note and an attachment. The note was for me, the attachment for my son. The attachment was a picture of Oreo Bear and a "hand-written" letter to my son. In the letter the bear says that he has been well taken care of, has made many new friends and is looking forward to being reunited with him. Toshinori Tanaka even pretended that he was sending Oreo via airplane and provided his confirmation number and when to expect him. Oreo arrived shortly thereafter, with two RC lion friends for my kids and photos of various places that Oreo had visited with his new friends in Tokyo. If Toshinori Tanaka were a baseball player, he just hit a grand slam in the bottom of the 9th in the seventh game of the World Series to walk off the field with a championship! Many, Many heartfelt thanks from our family to you! This will be a story re-told many times in the years to come and has guaranteed, that anytime this family is in Tokyo, we will stay at the RC again.

I've only stayed here a single night but the quality of service, the luxury of the rooms, the food and drink that were provided were top notch. The lounge bar has excellent views of the city and the Tempura restaurant is exclusively fantastic. Every person of the staff was so helpful and made us feel at home.

I've stayed at this hotel twice. Both stays were truly excellent. It's one of my favourite hotels in the world. Rooms super comfortable - beautiful HVAC - never hearing turn on or off and keeps room at precise temperature. Amazing pool and fitness facility - great views while working out. Starbucks at ground level. Attentive staff. Could not ask for anything more.

Stayed at the Ritz Carlton for a work trip. Hotel is located at the top of a mixed use building with wonderful views of the city. Rooms are very clean and the staff was there to meet each of your needs. Bar has wonderful view of the downtown Tokyo area and you can walk to a lot of stuff in the surrounding area of the city

The Concierge made us feel like it was home. Provided a great itinerary for our stay and even provided fantastic Sumo tickets and provided a great guide. One of the best Ritz-Carltons in the world with great views.

We stayed at Ritz Carlton Tokyo for 2 enjoyable nights. The hotel rooms look out to a great bird eye view of Tokyo. The hotel is modern and comfortable, with warm and helpful staff. We specially enjoyed the swimming pool and the afternoon tea at Ritz.The hotel is convenient location next to a large shopping complex, as Ritz Carlton Hotels always are. The only thing was that, I left my under water MP3 at their changing room, the hotel staff promised to send it back to HK by Courier, but I still haven't got it 11 months later.But I suspect it might be related to the (English) language issue, which is inevitable traveling in Japan.

Stayed at Ritz for 3 nights. I previously stayed at the Conrad and Okura. Its probably the best location out of any hotel, right in the heart of foreigner-friendly Roppongi. All the bars and restaurants friends recommended me to were literally a short walk away. Another plus is the large sized rooms- I was shocked how large they were, compared to the other hotels mentioned. Also the view is also second to none; probably because its in one of the tallest buildings. The only drawbacks were interior- its a classic design but not really to my liking- they managed to make a 6yr old hotel look much older, although this probably comes down to personal taste. I much prefer the Conrad interior. I had room service twice and thought the food was just OK, but there are so many restaurants nearby I guess it doesn't matter. Overall good, but I am still yet to find my favorite Tokyo hotel.

Another Ritz-Carlton gem, the The Ritz-Carlton in Tokyo was definitely a good choice to stay during my business trip to the city. Remarkable staff and blessed with wonderful views of the city line, I considered my stay to be a well-rested one and probably inspirational from those breathtaking looks of the horizon. The rooms facing west had an excellent view of Mt. Fuji. I guess I know what room to take the next time.

The Ritz Carlton Tokyo is a spectacular hotel in Tokyo! The location is as decent as any - nothing is well located in sprawling Tokyo - but the luxury and service make it a standout. The hotel is located on the 45th to 53rd floors and offers views galore. The rooms are very comfortable and the bathrooms are huge and well designed. We had Club Level access which was worth every penny since they have 4 offerings per day including free-flowing champagne during the 3-hour cocktail hour.

I have been going to the Ritz Carlton Tokyo for the last 6 years and it looks as new as when it opens. It does not age fast. Some hotels refer to ‘location, location, location’. The the RC, it could be “location, view, comfort night and day”. Of course, choosing the RC means paying the price, no choice. So how do you get it back? I am not going to tell too much on the luxury side. RC is part of these groups with Conrad which compete. What I like is definitively the combination of the view and the location. Even the Park Hyatt has a great view but nothing is close unless you take a cab. With the RC, you are in Midtown, Roppongi. Two massive opportunities for shopping (midtown and Roppongi Hills). And the nightlife(bars, karaoke, restaurants, shows). Well if you like animations here is the place; Roppongi is more recommended for the blend of culture and the cosmopolitanism. For the view, well the worst is to see the Tokyo tower from the 45th floor. With now Skytree built, there is no bad side at the RC(either Mount Fuji with Shinjuku, or Sky tree with ginza or Tokyo tower and the bay or Shibuya). I woke up there once and saw Fuji-san while the curtains opened(automatically); priceless. The service is as expected from this rank. I prefer the New York grill bar at the Park Hyatt though. But the pool is just non-sense. If you swim there, turn your head and you will see Shibuya! Rooms are large for Tokyo standards and well equipped. They have now free internet(not the case when they opened...). Bathrooms are just massive and also a big highlights for those who like to spend time there. As always, Japanese standards call for full amenities so you do not need your toothbrush or shaving kit. I tried the suite; nothing very different apart from the space.Another good place to check is there restaurants. They have a good brunch, with the same view. To summarise: if you want to be in a buzzing place with the view, prefer the RC than the luxury hotels in Nihon-bashi.

My husband and I had a delightful 8 day stay at the Ritz Carlton using our Marriot points. Our room was spacious with beautiful views of Mt. Fuji. The service was superb! The front desk remembered out names and had a great suggestion to have us complete our check out paperwork right after breakfast on our last morning there so we won’t be delayed with long check-out/check-in lines on our way to the airport.Getting to the hotel: Since it was our first time traveling to Tokyo we decided to take the LimoBus that leaves on an hourly basis from Narita. It was super convenient and a great way to see the City on our way to the hotel. They had a promotion where we got two Metro Tokyo Day Passes when we booked bus tickets to and from the hotel. You can book tickets once you arrive to Narita Airport.Location: The location of the hotel is great! The lobby is located on the 45th floor of one of the tallest towers of Tokyo. Tokyo Midtown is located on the bottom of the tower with easy access to two different Metro lines. Tokyo Midtown was super convenient with a 24 hour supermarket (Precce) which came in handy for mornings when we were heading early to the train station for a couple of day trips and needed some quick breakfast options which we usually bought the night before. There is also a fab French patisserie as well as several high-end restaurants & shops. Lobby: The lobby has superb views of the city with live music in the evening. We had cocktails one evening and really enjoyed ourselves. They had “12 day of Christmas” cocktails, which were fun. My husband asked for their whiskey menu, after noticing their bar menu didn’t have any whiskey on it. They brought us a menu with over 200 whiskeys with great options. Restaurants: We really enjoyed a wonderful New Year’s menu at Hinokizaka, which was awarded the Michelin One Star for 2010. Their breakfast buffet, located at the Towers Grill, was okay. Overall we had a great stay!

Stayed at Ritz Carlton Tokyo in Midtown Roppongi. Great views from the room (NHK tower on my last trip). The lobby lounge and bar in the evening provide superb view of the nighttime Tokyo. The room are spacious. The bathroom are large with Asprey amenities. Breakfast had everything it needs, but I still believe Hong Kong hotels serve the best breakfast. Overall, very pleasant experience.

I recently completed a 2-night stay at the hotel for a business trip. The hotel and the room were extremely nice, but the real prize for me was the level of service. I was treated with tremendous politeness and respect, and quick service when I actually needed anything (although it was rare). The location is good, although it's a long ride from Narita. Look at Haneda if you can.It would be a pleasure to stay here again.

While it is a "5-star" hotel, it definitely is not a 5-star Tripadvisor hotel, nor on par with what you'd expect from a Ritz Carlton. What a shame given their fantastic location, beautiful views, and the potential to be the top hotel in Tokyo. I recently stayed for 7 nights, so I feel the stay was long enough to get a feel for the hotel, service, food quality, etc. I had a western facing room, so on clear mornings, I had spectacular views of Mt. Fuji and the sprawling backside of Tokyo. The views in the lobby faced the other direction, which were more dramatic as you see the skyline of inner Tokyo - but having a view of Mt. Fuji was a treat in itself. Besides these special views, the 30ft ceilings in the lobby on the 45th floor, the perfect location in midtown Roppongi, and always friendly Japanese service, there isn't much else to gloat about.I had room service (breakfast and dinner) on numerous occasions and the food was mild at best. One evening I ordered the Japanese Beef Curry and the beef was arguably the worst beef I have ever tasted - almost to the point where it had spoiled. One one occasion, they told me the food would be ready in 25-30mins and it took 1hr 15mins.The room size is fine (and above average for Tokyo hotels), but they are in need of a facelift. Even the toilet in the room (and I love Japanese toilets) was not as nice as some public Japanese toilets. On nearly ever occasion I called someone within the hotel (whether it was the Bell Desk, Concierge, Front Desk, etc), I sat on hold for at least a few minutes. On my last day, I asked for a late checkout of 2pm and was told there would be a charge for it. I understand if hotels are completely booked and need to abide by a standard checkout time to ensure guests have a room upon check-in, but this was not the case. Loyal clients stay at Ritz Carlton hotels b/c they expect exemplary service, and I did not feel the hotel provided it this trip.Regarding the location, there is a sizable 4-story mall just below the building that holds a wide array of clothing stores, food court, and even a Dean & Deluca. In conclusion, it is obviously a nice hotel with a superb location, but it is arguably the weakest Ritz I have stayed in and they need to do a better job all around to bring the hotel up to the standard of the hotel brand.

I stayed here for a week. The hotel was luxurious as was my room. Fast service and nice food. Great business location. Hotel was v expensive but thats what you expect in a 5 star in Tokyo. I will stay here from now on for all my trips to Tokyo.

I booked a regular room. Upon check-in, I was told by the receptionist that I was upgraded to a room on the Club floor but cannot use the lounge. He tells me that I should be grateful since the room on the Club floor being very special, equipped with a Nespresso machine. He reiterated though that I may not use the Club lounge. In my mind, I thought, "Why bother upgrading me to a room on the Club floor when I cannot use the lounge? Furthermore, why should I be so grateful and why is this receptionist so condescending?". Anyway, I was quite tired so I could not been bothered to complain then. As I walked into the room, the bathroom door was wide open and saw on a chrome mirror shiny pillar a 15 inch hand mark with either hair gel or moisturising cream, probably at 7ft hight where housekeeper had missed. I got quite bothered but waited until the following morning to complain as I had to dash out. The following morning, I called the operator and I asked for the duty manager to come to my room. The Club Supervisor turned up rather than a manager. He was apologetic and actually quite nice but it gets interesting from here. I asked specifically for the General Manager to reach me as I wanted to talk about my experience. The Club Supervisor concurred and I had checked out. Later that night, I received an email from Ms Mamiko [--] who is the PA to the GM. Her tone was super polite on the surface but really quite rude reading between the lines. She goes "I hope you would visit the Ritz-Carlton Tokyo soon" but lacked saying do reach out to the GM's office when making the future reservation.
