New York City, New York

review_body: We arrived via the subway (having come in from Kyoto) and walked from the Roppongi station. We found the Ritz Carlton cafe easy enough. The entrance to the hotel is through a bit of a maze, though well signed. On this main level there was no one to great us or take our bags (this happens on the lower level with car arrivals) and no one to direct us to the check in area when we got to the lobby level. Check in was professional, if uneventful. Still no one asked to help us with our bags. We pack light, we can handle our bags, but it seemed such a simple miss for the Ritz Carlton to make...The room was large, much larger than our room at the Park Hyatt or in Kyoto. The bathroom was so large it almost seemed silly, but I won't complain about that. The Ritz does little touches well. We were looking at the menu of the steakhouse, and they offered to give us a tour of the restaurants (which are truly lovely with amazing views of Tokyo Tower). We had drinks in the bar each night and the staff remembered us and our preferences. I realize it's Japan, but I was surprised that smoking was allowed in parts of the bar.... that is a bit disappointing, but they managed to seat us far away from the smokers. If you can, make your way to the back of the bar (to the left upon entering) there a few tables tucked away with lovely views.Overall this hotel felt more appropriate for high end business folks than us on holiday, but outside of the arrival everything was of a very high standard. The location in Rappongi strikes me as better for business folks as well.

Now that we’ve experienced the Ritz Carlton Tokyo, we have a new favourite in Asia. Our top luxury hotel locations in Asia have been the Mandarin oriental in KL for value, and the Four Seasons in HK for style. Now we happily add the Ritz Carlton Tokyo for service. Hands-down the best overall service we have seen anywhere. No request went unfulfilled by staff from any department and always quickly, with a smile and helpful hints. From the club lounge, to the front desk, to the concierge and the staff in food & beverage, all were world-class and worthy of massive praise. The staff at ‘Roku’ the Japanese cultural gift shop at main reception also gets a heartfelt thank you for their wonderful help; and special thanks to the entire team at the Towers Grill.The room was spacious by Tokyo standards and was impeccably clean, plus had a terrific view. The bathroom was very large. The hotel is not new however, so there is nothing flashy or particularly high-tech about the rooms or general decor. There is a respectable sized pool for such a high-rise and the spa treatment I had was wonderful. There is an odd mix of what you can and cannot access though since some things are reserved for Carlton Club rather than club floor guests or Marriott Gold members. I’ve seen people complain about this and, had I been excluded from something after paying for a club level room, I would have been upset as well (although we were not as these were never full). What could possible improve? Perhaps a stretch, but check-in can be a bit strange and I see in the Tripadvisor.com comments that some were put off by it. It is odd that you walk in the ground floor into essentially a largely empty hallway. No reception area and no immediately visible signage. The one staff on duty when we arrived was on the phone so we wandered around until we found that we had to take the lift to main reception, and then have someone escort us to the Club lounge for club level check-in. More/better signage or staff to escort to the lift would solve all of this. Other than that, PERFECT, almost better than perfect. We will certainly return. Now the 64-thousand yen question….is it worth the price? It’s strange that in an agglomeration of 35 million people, Marriott members have only one ultra-high-end ‘Ritz’ and one ‘Courtyard’ to choose from. No ‘Marriott’ or ‘JW’. Plus, where when you compare what is available, the Courtyard Ginza is a VERY good hotel in its own right. Very swanky for a ‘Courtyard’. Well placed and you can book the largest club room there (massive, with massage loungers and a sitting area) for one-third of what you will pay for a regular club room at the Ritz Carlton. All in all though, the Ritz Carlton service is something that must be experienced to be believed; and yes worth the price. MANY THANKS!

I stayed for 2 nights at the Ritz-carlton Tokyo. It has a great location, elegant settings, but I did not get the experience I was expecting in a 5 star hotel in Japan. First, the staff was not as welcoming and pleasant as in previous hotels I had stayed in Tokyo ( Mandarin). Second, the room, although spacious,elegantly appointed with comfortable beds and great bathroom, had a stained carpet. I complained to the reception desk and was moved to another room with equally stained carpeting.: I cannot understand how a 5 star hotel in Tokyo, a Ritz- Carlton, can have such low standards. Ruined my stay.

A truely excellent hotel. Rooms are very comfortable, large bathrooms, great views. The lobby bar is unique since the lobby is on the 45th floor of the building! Service was very good, and there is plenty to walk to from the location. I also had a great sushi dinner with colleagues at the restaurant as well. From a value perspective, you are paying for the great experience but still a good stop.

This was bar far the worst hotel check in experience I have ever had. So bad in fact, I left to stay at another hotel. The staff was rude, inconsiderate, and I actually think they were untruthful. The check-in experience was so bad, I made arrangements to stay at another hotel. Strongly recommend not even trying to stay here, and stay elsewhere. Shame on the Ritz for treating a Marriott Gold member so badly.

Located in Roppongi part of Tokyo, its nestles in the "Beverly Hills" of Tokyo.. A 53 floor glass tower, gleaming in sunlight. This hotel, for me anyway, is "perfect" in every sense of the word. From check-in to check-out, its pure sophistication.. Club Lounge is large, warm, and exquisite. Was that 007 just being served a Vodka Martini? - If you like unpretentious luxury, this is for you! Value for money?, not really, but then again, when you stay here, you don't worry about the price. Breakfast? Very nice, eggs cooked to order, even asked if I wanted my eggs soft, medium, or hard. Tables in the Club Lounge were a bit small at breakfast. Evening cocktails, overlooking Tokyo at sunset , should not be missed.. Romantic with stunning views, make this THE best hotel in Tokyo, bar none.

Very nice hotel centrally located. There are probably others that are as good are better with respect to atmosphere of the lobby and restaurants. Lobby is on the 45th floor. Doesn't feel open like hotels with entrances on the first floor. Great traditional afternoon tea. CONCIERGE ARE FANTASTIC! Really helpful and knowledgeable. They're great for Americans who don't speak Japanese. Restaurants are not exceptional.

This is a great hotel. Concierge and bell desk are great. Fantastic bathrooms. And the place smells nice too.If I had to come up with anything critical it would be two things.1) The lack of an a decent onsen for regular hotel guests. It's Japan! The onsen spa is reserved for Ritz Carlton club members. The Dormy Inn offers a better onsen sadly.2) I get the feeling more and more that the "Ritz" management is so consumed with making their brand the number one luxury address in every city that regular guests lose out. Unless you're staying in a club suite you don't really get any access to common space. The lobby lounge is occupied by ladies who lunch, and the spa (above), is reserved for club members. So as a guest, although you're staying at this posh hotel, it often feels like you're an after-thought to the visitors.### That said, I've still found myself staying here repeatedly. They get most of it right.

We spent 4 days here and experienced all that this hotel had to offer: the rooms (we changed midway through to experience a different view), restaurants and lounge, spa, exercise facilities/pool and utilized the concierge service. EVERYTHING was incredible and we did not experience any hiccups or flaws. We have stayed at many RC properties and this one was by far the best. The service was phenomenal and the staff were incredibly accommodating. While it is difficult to point out 'highlights' when everything is so great, some of the areas that stood out were:1) Breakfast buffet: Incredible selection of western and Japanese food that was expertly prepared. The wonderful view added to the experience.2) Swimming Pool: Very clean and well maintained with all of the supplies (goggles, caps, flutter boards) that you need readily available and brought to you by one of the attendants.3) Cleanliness: The rooms, linens, public areas were all impeccable.Definitely one of the best hotels in Tokyo, especially with the recent downgrading that took place at the Four Seasons Chinzan-so, which was equivalent in quality.

Everything about this hotel truly meets what you would expect of a Ritz-Carlton. The ambiance and amenities are plush and luxurious, the views from all windows are amazing, and service is impeccable. The location in Tokyo Midtown is very convenient to the train lines, with easy access to any part of the city. There's also plenty of nightlife and food in the Roppongi area.I must give due credit to the concierge staff, who never once led my husband and me astray with their restaurant recommendations. Every meal suggested to us by the concierge was superb, and very considerate of our requests for fine or casual dining, or for a quick bite for lunch. The staff was also very helpful with assisting us in navigating the city, finding places of interest, or even venturing out into further parts of the city for specific needs.The room itself was a spacious retreat - very well-appointed with excellent details, even in the turndown service. We loved the porcelain tea set in the room so much, I ended up purchasing one from the same designer in the shopping center of the lower levels of the building. The bathroom had all the comforts one could ask for. We could not have had a better or more comfortable stay during our trip to Tokyo.

This place is seriously high class. It’s luxurious, while still being warm, welcoming and comfy. Located atop a high-rise building, the hotel has commanding views of the city. As expected, the hotel has blow-your-mind service with usual Japanese courtesy and grace. Stay here to treat yourself to some well-deserved pampering.

one of the best hotels I have ever stayed in. The service is impeccable and the rooms are plush, beautiful and big. The King bed was one of the softest Ive ever slept in and the Toto bathroom- well you can imagine the options. The neighborhood is just fabulous with many high end restaurants, a huge starbucks for your morning coffee and a couple of metros close by. Its also easy to get from narita and haneda to this hotel because it has an entrance in the metro and you can walk right into the hotel.I had to change two trains from narita but the subway system in Japan is so clean and efficient its much nicer than taking a cab which would cost you $300 for a one way ride from narita. The hotel has a bar which is lovely but pricey and they did try and charge us a cover which, we refused and were surprized by, since we were guests at the hotel. They waived it so maybe it was just a language issue. The concierge made all our restaurant reservations and helped us everyday with maps and directions. We had a very good room service breakfast on our last day. Not the best Ive had but pretty good.

review_body: Service; phenomenalValue; a bit pricey but worth the priceSleep quality; once you stop worrying how much you are paying for the night you sleep like a babyCleanliness; it's Tokyo, everything is spotlessLocation; great, walking distance to everythingRooms; beautiful

I just returned from a week at the Ritz Carlton and there are many positives to list. The staff is wonderful and welcoming. The room was spacious and extremely comfortable and quiet. The views over the city ( the hotel is on the top floors of one of the tallest structures in the city) are astounding especially at night. The Spa and exercise facilities are excellent and well maintained. The concierge staff was very helpful with directions and dinner reservations.I cannot compliment the staff at the Ritz enough. They are well trained and go out of their way to be polite and helpful.The hotel has a number of restaurants and serves a breakfast buffet daily that was very good.We ate dinner in the Japanese restaurant on New Years eve thinking it might be difficult to find a reservation off property. We had a wonderful traditional multi-course meal that was a great experience although it was insanely expensive. Given the holiday I tried not to think about it but when I got the bill it was hard not to feel a bit taken advantage of.There is one other thing that prevents me from giving the hotel 5 stars. I like to stop at the hotel bar and have a nightcap when I travel but the Ritz bar charges a cover for what amounts to standard cocktail lounge music. Even if you sit at the bar for 1 drink you get hit with a cover charge every night. I think hotel guests should be able to enjoy a drink without a cover given that there is no other bar in the hotel. The Ritz is above a complex that includes a great mall with some nice restaurants and access to the Metro without even stepping outside which is a nice convenience.Again, overall I liked the hotel very much and would return but I'd dine elsewhere and find a nearby bar to avoid a very hefty bill at checkout.

Very helpful concierge. Club floor was worth it if you go several times a day... Food was decent, dessert was excellent, drinks were nice. Roppongi was great fun, and a fabulous place to be....The hotel is really gorgeous. And new. Spa was lovely but is incredibly expensive.

JAC0130
New York City, New York

review_body: Everything about the hotel is luxurious, never mind the polished fixtures and fittings and fine fabrics, the sheer amount of space you are surrounded by is the most luxurious aspect of all. It's location in Midtown is very convenient for business across Tokyo, and the shopping centre and small adjoining park provide enough amusement for the business traveller with some spare time. The sushi bar in the hotel is excellent, it was mostly filled with Japanese guests which is a testament to its quality; the price was high but not outrageous, compared with other top-notch sushi restaurants in Tokyo. Like the room sizes and views, the room rates are stratospheric and only for the very well heeled (or us mere mortals on business), plus they are very firm about charging for a late checkout which was an unpleasant surprise to a Ritz-Carlton member. The latter is the reason I am reducing 'excellent' to 'very good'.

I LOOOOOOOOOVED staying at the Ritz Tokyo when I went here in February. It was the best hotel I have ever stayed and the staff was extremely accommodating, friendly and even went out of their way to make our stay extra special. The moment we checked in, the concierge asked if we would like to upgrade our suit to a large romantic suit for only $40. We totally took this offer. Our room was amazing with a crazy view of the entire Tokyo City. We also enjoyed High Tea at the lobby lounge where the staff didn't even have to ask if we wanted a window seat. They automatically situated us right by a huge window and consistantly poured our tea as soon as our cups were empty. Now thats excellent service. Lastly, our concierge every morning greeted us and remembered our names by the 2nd day. The moment we stepped out of the elevator they knew our names. On our last day in this hotel, we had trouble arranging our train and pickup in Hakkone so our concierge took care of everything, arranged our transportation and even booked a special pick-up by a taxi holding our names as we arrived in Hakkone. I 100% recommend The Ritz-Carlton Tokyo. You will NOT be disappointed!

I stayed at the Ritz Carlton as part of a business trip to attend a conference in Tokyo. The Ritz was as expected a great property and provided excellent service. For the duration of my stay I received the excellent service that you'd desire from the Ritz. Though I was out working most of the day it was a treat to come back to my room at night - primarily because it had such a great view of the Mori Towers. Looking out at the Tokyo Skyline at night from the 47th storey made me feel oddly peaceful and also as if I was living in the age of Jetsons! The rooms had huge windows on one wall which added to the beauty of the view.The hotel is housed in a huge complex that has a subway station attached and also a big shopping complex to one side which is convenient if you don't have a lot of time on your hands to shop. Also Roppongi is one area of Tokyo that was pretty alive at night so when I stepped out to buy potato chips at 12AM I was surrounded by office goers emerging and going into bars. Also side note - before visiting Tokyo during my research online I was led to believe that Roppongi is not a very safe area - however when I stepped out alone at midnight to visit the convenience store and just take a walk down the main road, I was pleasantly surprised. While I did get my share of being street hawked by waiters and restaurant service women to come and eat at their hotel - I didn't find any of it unpleasant or something I couldn't handle.

Best Tokyo hotel with unbelievable views of Tokyo city.A modern development with shops and restaurants. I can't imagine a better more attentive service. Perfectly clean, nice atmosphere and friendly stuff

My husband, Daughter and I spent our Thanksgiving holiday at this wonderful hotel. The service was impeccable. We upgraded to the "Club Level" and it was well worth the additional cost. The lounge offered us a continental breakfast every morning, in addition they had a lunch, afternoon tea, evening Hor'devours with spirits and an finally a sweet offering after 8 PM. also with spirits. The room was large and roomy for all of us to stay in. The spa was unbelievable, I had a wonderful treatment and massage that was so relaxing. The only negative thing I can say about this experience was when I went to the pool are to soak in the Jacuzzi with my husband after a long day of walking they made me put a bandage type cover over a very small dragon fly tattoo I have at the base of the back of my neck. Since I am allergic to latex and the material was like that of a large latex bandaid this put a big damper on my relaxation. I was told this was some kind of cultural thing. Not sure what but I will remember this for any future visits.

You can may be have similar luxury rooms in other hotels in Tokyo, but the Ritz Carlton offers by far the best view. We stayed in room 4911 on the 49th floor in a 80qm suite and could see both towers the old one and the Skytree. Really nothing to complain about. The gym is great, fitted with modern equipment and from there you have also a breathtaking view. The hotel is located in a busy area, especially at night as there are all the nightclubs, bars and fancy restaurants. We liked it a lot!

Best Tokyo hotel with unbelieveable views of Tokyo city. Very expensive but worth every yen. Staff goes out of their way to please you. Can't wait for my next visit. Would definitely stay here again! Part of massive Midtown Tower project. Don't have to expose yourself to the elements to visit offices there. Galleria Shopping right there at Midtown also. Great shops and restaurants.

Funny a great hotel like this can be unfamiliar with some cabby drivers in Tokyo. The driver first thought we were going to Ritz Hotel, which does exist somewhere in Tokyo. Should had known how to pronounce Ritz Carlton in Japanese.The hotel is a perfection from the moment you step into the GF lobby. Best of all, all staff members speak good English, and the bellhop even offer to file a complaint on my behalf for the not-so-smooth taxi ride. I just didn't want to take that so personally, but 1+ for the attentiveness of the staff.The hotel is also on the upper floors of a commercial complex, just like the Strings Intercontinental I stayed and loved last month. The lobby is on the 45F, and the elevator is so fast that you can feel it ascending and descending with your eardrums... The lobby itself is gorgeous, so is every small details.The check-in process took longer, but I expected already. It is the fault of the reservation system of Marriott.com, that I had to have four different reservations for two rooms for 4 nights (the last 3 were added to the first night, but the hotel was so busy that choosing "modify" gave me weird results, so I had to just put down different reservations), and they were busy attaching them together, and made sure that we didn't have to check-in and check-out. Big thanks!The room is so huge in Tokyo standard. It is twice the footage of the Corner room I stayed in Intercontinental in Shinagawa (hence the price being almost doubled). This is only the Deluxe Room (lowest I think), who knows what the larger ones look like... There was no single item in the room not functioning correctly, and everything was just flawless.The Nov 23rd weekend was a national holiday in Japan, so the breakfast during the weekend was quite popular. We had to wait during the weekend to get seated in the restaurant serving breakfast. Not a problem, since the breakfast was so good and the choices were the most adequate among ones offered among all the top hotels and resorts I've stayed in.Although I had my Ritz Carlton credit card long ago, I didn't use RC that often is just because of the value associated. The service and the quality of room is outstanding of course, but the price is really beyond what leisure travelers would like to spend. Moreover, RC being a super 5-star means that it doesn't recognize elite membership as to-the-edge as other Marriott brands. I can be upgraded to a club level in Renaissance just for being a gold member, but club level is excluded from the upgrade of RC (which is totally understandable since club level in RC is way better than just having the title, so there is a cost issue). However, it's hard not to choose something that is also a famous international chain, gives good upgrade to elite members, costs a lot lower, and sits in good spots of the town as well, when paying with your own money.All in all, it is a fabulous hotel, and it was actually fully-occupied for the Nov 23rd weekend.

Fabulous hotel and staff and rooms and everything. I worked with the concierge desk via email to arrange restaurant reservations and a tour guide. The concierges were super easy to work with and their recommendations were even better. Highly, highly recommended. Well worth the money.

The Ritz-Carlton Tokyo is located on top of the Tokyo Midtown, a modern development with shops and restaurants. The lobby is at the 45th floor, which was confusing to get to. Once I get to the room, it was amazing. The view was beautiful, and the room was very spacious. I was surprise to see such ample room in Tokyo. During my stay in the summer, I saw 2-3 fireworks going off at the same time from my room. The large size swimming pool was kept at a comfortable temperature. The service was amazing. The staff here is very nice. Lovely experience overall.

The hotel has a lot to offer. I was traveling with work and had a relatively good corporate rate on the room (35,000 yen, almost $400USD). It included free internet and a couple of other amenities.I totally agree with most of the other reviewers - great location, good staff, quiet room, very spacious and comfortable,amazing views from room, restaurants and gym/spa, lots and lots to like.It's hard to get over the cost of restaurant food here. My breakfast buffet was something like 4500 yen for a buffet after they added a service charge. I got room service once - Japanese beef curry. It was tasty and the service was good, but for 2800 yen with service fee there were about 5 small pieces of beef to go with the big bowl of rice. Of course it's a Ritz Carlton so you expect outlandish prices for everything but until I get an unlimited expense budget it costs a star.

It really can't get better than this. I traveled here for business and because everything is so expensive in Japan, this hotel is actually in my hotel cap *gasp*.Awesome factor #1: They care about YOU. I checked in at 12:00am after 15 hours of flying and as soon as I walked up to the front desk, they greeted me by name. What?? Do I have a name tag or something? How did they know it was me? Oh--they actually USE your flight information to anticipate when you'll check in. That's a first. Any time I've provided flight information, it's usually unnoticed by the front desk.Awesome factor #2: "Ms. sfstef. It turns out that we're out of the room that you requested, so we've upgraded you to a club level suite. You won't get access to the club, but you get to enjoy all the other room services, including housekeeping twice a day for clean up and turn down." And the incredibly beautiful view of Roppongi Hills and Tokyo from the 52nd Floor of our building.Awesome factor #3: Perfect English 24/7. In Japan, that can be hard... but at a cosmopolitan hotel like the Ritz, it's the norm.I really can't thank this hotel for Wowing me with the experience I had. Not to even mention the perfect location for expats (Tokyo Midtown and Roppongi are high end, businessey, but not overly crowded like Shibuya or Shinjuku. They also don't draw the masses at any point in time... weekday nights are actually pretty calm)I would stay here all the time if I could afford it. But alas, these experiences are reserved for when I'm feeling extra special (or if I can afford 45000 yen a night). :)By the way--the rooms are spotless. Literally spotless. Not a leftover hair from another person, and not a speck of anything questionable on any surface (viewable to the naked eye). Plenty of pics attached!

Rtiz Carlton Tokyo located in the top most towers of one of the tallest towers in Tokyo is a beautiful hotel with excellent rooms. Stayed there for 6 nights and enjoyed every bit of it. Situated in the happening Roppongi, the hotel is well connected with all modes of transport. It is also well connected with the airport with an airport shuttle operating from here. The rooms are beautiful with a wonderful view of Tokyo. The space is extremely luxurious by Tokyo standards. The bathrooms are one of the best designed bathrooms I have seen in any hotel. The service is also excellent. I would recommend this hotel to anybody planning a stay in Tokyo

It was a business trip but since my Husband is on him Vacation leave, he decided to join me with our 3 years old daughter. It was such a great hotel and I high recommend everyone to stay here if you are traveling to Tokyo. The lobby is located in the 45th floor, and as it is so high up, we were impress with the beautiful view of Toyko. Check in was efficient. We booked a club room which was located in the 53rd floor. Our room had a stunning view of tokyo and we even see Mount Fuji form our window! Room is spacious and very very clean. And the Club lounge was so good. We just keep going to the club lounge coz the food there is so good especially the High tea and Pre-dinner snack. If you like Roppongi area, then you will like the location as it is just on top of Mid-town. I usually stayed at the Conrad but compare to Ritz, I think Ritz is better, people are nicer and the hotel is more homey and welcoming.

Stayed at the Ritz-Carlton Tokyo for two nights and as previous reviews go I have no complaints. It is kind of a hassle having the lobby on the 45th floor then switching to another elevator to get to your room but this is certainly customary with high-end hotels in Tokyo in order to get a great view from your room. In terms of modern decoration I wouldn't say it beats Conrad Tokyo but in regards to location it does. The hotel is within walking distance of Roppongi station so theres no cab needed for that part. Roppongi Hills, Midtown Tokyo, restaurants, shops, nightlife, entertainment, etc. are all within walking distance as Roppongi is in the heart of Tokyo. Clearly this hotel is marketed towards the upper class and business but for your average Joe like myself sometimes its good to splurge and treat yourself especially if it's for a special occasion. As a tip, typically you're going to want to put your 'nice clothes on' when staying at high-end hotels as the majority of folks in or around the hotel will be there on business wearing suites. And it's not a big deal I suppose on how you dress if you're just there for vacation but it can get awkward if you find yourself in a restaurant/lobby/shop/etc and you're the only guy wearing a t-shirt and jeans, in my opinion. Free wifi is excellent and fast. In regards to the TV they could really do more to put more of a variety of channels for foreigners or english speakers. Theres 17 'internation channels', 5 of them are just different news channels, 2 of them are the exact same channel, 3 are channels that are still in Japanese, etc. So in that aspect I would like to see more variety, sometimes you'll find yourself in your room with nothing to watch. For breakfast I had waffles and french toast and while it wasn't the healthiest of choices the table tray and condiments it was presented on was pretty impressive, I'll definitely be ordering breakfast again at my next stay. Bathtub in my room was nice but they really need some bubble bath there, I even called services and they said to use shower gel and that it would make bubbles. Well If people are going to pay top dollar for this hotel I think supplying or atleast stocking some bubble bath for the bathtub isn't too much to ask. I wish these types of hotels had a power outlet by the bed so you could charge and browse the internet on your phone while laying down, a tad bit annoying how most hotels don't have it. But clearly those are minor nitpicks, overall I enjoyed my stay there and the location makes it hard to beat.

You have to give it to Japanese, I can't imagine a better more attentive service. Perfectly clean, nice atmosphere. the food could definitely better. and cover charge to drink in the bar is nothing I've ever heard of. Ask to take it off the bar bill, its ridiculous. Swimming pool is amazing, jacuzzi turbo jets will replace the best shiatsu massage. great view from the room

Have stayed several times this year and I have come to feel very at home here with no cause for complaint at all. Delightful staff and beautiful rooms with huge bathrooms and wonderful views. On a clear day and in the right direction you will see Mt Fuji in the morning or perhaps the port of Yokohama. The location in Roppongi can be a bit of a turn-off if you don't like Roppongi (I don't particularly) but there are plenty of good eateries and drinkeries if you walk down in the other direction to Akasaka.Charming Japanese garden just across the road from the taxi stand area.

Great people an location. Complete service and good facilities. In a city with many options the views give this hotel an advantage. Close to great bars and restaurants the sushi bar inside the hotel serves brilliant Japanese food.

I stayed at this hotel for one full week. Everything about the hotel was perfect. Amazing view from the room, fabulous gym for workouts, extremely courteous staff (despite the language barrier), amazingly prompt service, the works basically. The rooms are well spaced and comfortable. The sleep quality is just amazing. The location is also fabulous. Our business was in the Midtown building, so that was convenient as well.In the evening, Roppongi is a very short walk away and is extremely lively to help you strum yourself out of a busy office day.

i have stayed in Ritz Carlton tokyo 3 times so far and have to state that it is excellence at its best. there customer service is amazing. i had a broken suitcase while i checked in. on my next day in the hotel i found a note on the desk stating that Dear Mr. Chaaban, we took the courtesy of your absence and sent your suitcase to maintenance department for fixing. with compliments. honestly this blew me away. they have amazing food in the hotel and room service is just great. i highly recommend the chicken corn soup ( it is the best chicken corn soup i have ever tried), their wagyu beef burger is a must and their japanese sashimi restaurant is amazing too. make sure to ask the chef for omakase (free style sushi) you will love the creations of the chef as he will do things not on the menu. but prepare your credit card cuz u will definitely need it. bon apetit and enjoy your stay at the Ritz.

Travelling to Japan can be an ordeal, particularly when coming from Europe. It wasn't that long ago, prior to 3G that one needed to rent a local mobile phone and beg the concierge for a weird adaptor to download emails on a painful internet connection. Hotels were geared to the local market- and all the better for it - but sometimes disorientating for a Western traveller. Clearly time moves on but the jet lag, environment and climate can still be a killer if you're in town for a couple of days with a 13 hour flight on each end. Happily the Ritz Carlton eases the pain enormously. Yes it's a very American hotel in many ways and yes it's probably a bit 90s in decor (The newer Mandarin Oriential beats it for style stakes) but still retains a very definite Japanese style and welcome. The service is fabulous - not just slick and efficient but very warm and friendly. The housekeeping staff can't do enough and take great pains to make you welcome, almost as if you're a guest in their home. Sounds crazy but true, they take a real pride in what they do. The rooms are large, beautifully appointed and the bathrooms are spacious and lack for nothing. The Asprey toiletries are a treat too! I stayed on a club floor so not sure how different this is but it was great. Wifi was not just free - everywhere in the hotel that I went (room, club lounge, lobby, restaurants) but very high speed. Great mobile phone signal - all the stuff that makes it easy to feel connected to home and settle in and work.The restaurants are expensive - as other tipsters have commented and indeed the lobby lounge is to be avoided, a cup of tea was over £15 - but I must say the quality of the food (both the cooking and the ingredients) was, and I don't use the word lightly - stunning. The breakfast buffet is excellent, with chefs preparing egg dishes on demand to an amazing standard - with a view of the city through floor to ceiling windows that is simply breathtaking. And I guess you have to pay to get food that good shipped up 45 floors!Interestingly, eating off room service was a surprisingly affordable (it's relative term in Tokyo!) option compared to the restaurants with great variety - I ordered a Thai Chicken Curry which was as good as any I've ever eaten anywhere in the world, and a perfect in-room supper.A real highlight is the fitness centre - not just stuck away in some basement (take note Four Seasons Hotel New York, winner of my worst hotel gym in the world award) - a great swimming pool, on the 46th floor with fabulous views and flooded with natural light, and a superbly equipped gym, again with amazing views over the city and plenty of high - end Life Fitness equipment, the same as in my regular gym back home. Someone has clearly thought about how to build a proper spa and gym in this place.All in all, a truly outstanding hotel - a great place to do business from and to come back to after a hot and jet lagged day out and about. Can't recommend highly enough.

This hotel is located inside Tokyo Midtown complex, one of a high end malls in Japan. The lobby is grand and the staffs were really helpful. They started to assist us in so many things even way before our arrival. Restaurants reservations, luggage delivery service, everything was very well managed by the concierge. The room is spacious with a great view of Tokyo Tower, grand bathroom, clean, top notch.Thank you for making our trip memorable. Special thanks to the staffs, specially the concierge team.

Everything about this establishment was impeccable from rooms to service. The hotel is part of a massive shopping and restaurant complex which is realty handy. Felt foood and drinks were overpriced in the hotel

Excellent hotel Delya for breakfast seating and for table booking in the bars. Helpful staff (as always in Japan).No Clock Radio (an essential in any hotel).$25.00 for WiFi.....when are hotels going to wake-up to the fact that guests regard this as an almighty rip-off.I deliberately avoid hotels that charge. My travel agent put us here. Would not stay again.

Wow. If you want to feel amazing, this is the hotel for you. Upon arrival we upgraded to the ritz club with a room on the 52nd floor. This meant we had an amazing room, it was huge with a gigantic glorious bathroom, the views of Tokyo were breathtaking! I would totally recommend upgrading to the club, as you get food & drinks included 24/7 on the 53rd floor and use of the pool/ wet area free. The bed is so comfortable, if I wasn't in Tokyo (with so much to do) I would have wanted to stay in bed all day. The rooms are pristine, and have everything you need. I loved the purple water body moisturizer, it was luxury! Wifi, multi region adaptor, a dvd player, cables for connecting your ipod/ computer to the tv system. Tea, Green tea and coffee making facilities, a nespresso machine. Staff are just so lovely, I was blown away by the service! Breakfast also delicious in the Tower restaurant. Loved that we could order our eggs however we liked and watch them get cooked by the chef. Great to have the option of a Japanese breakfast also.The spa services we got were expensive but excellent! Also, and the location- brilliant! Was so convenient being so close to the train. Loved our stay here, were very sorry to leave. Can't recommend highly enough to people, and can't wait to return.Thank you Ritz-Carlton Tokyo!

This was y fourth stay in May for 10 days. I keep coming back to this place for its amazing location but I cant help feel its getting a bit antiquated. The rooms are very large for Tokyo but the deco is more on the classic 90´s style and looks more like an old Sheraton. Lobby has great views but not as impressive as it could be, St Regis in Singapore is way more impressive for example.Service is generally good except some of the employees are a bit stuck up and look down on you. Bell boys and doormen are excellent, the ladies at concierge are very nice and so were the cleaning ladies that did our rooms on the 52nd floor.The Pool is excellent if you want to do some exercise.If you are on business this is a great hotel but if I go as a couple again I will probably look for somewhere more relaxed.All in all a good hotel but not as good as it should be.

I stayed in this hotel some weeks ago during a business trip to the Japanese capital. The hotel is kept in pristine conditions. Style, classic with some "four seasons" colours all over the place. I found the main lobby a bit "interesting" with all the fountains and similar elements surrounding that area. The rooms are quite spacious and functional (you wont find larger rooms in Tokyo for that price). I got an upgrade to the club floor and enjoyed the amenities. The gym is rather good and with all the equipment you may need for a hotel (another detail you wont find in Tokyo). Overall, one of the best choices for Tokyo at the moment.

I recently stayed at the Ritz Carlton in Tokyo for 7 nights and was one of the best hotel stays. The hotel is on the top floors of Tokyo Midtown Tower and my room offered a wonderful of Tokyo and the Japan State Guesthouse, which was beautiful. The rooms are large and come with a walk-in closet and bathrooms with double sinks, separate shower and tub and also a TV in the bathroom. I had asked for extra towels to be in my bathroom when I reserved and as requested they were there. There is a handy control panel next to the bed for all the lights, drapes and shears drapes. Outlet had a converter already plugged in, which I found great as I forgot to bring my adapter. I cannot fault any of the service received in the hotel from the cleaning of the room to the turn down service, service in the bar. A nice touch every morning is the coffee waiting in the small alcove off the lifts that you can help yourself too.The only thing that I would fault is that the lobby lounge has a cover charge in the evening for hotel guests, which I found absolutely unbelievable. I luckily had a rate that included the cover charge but for the price of the hotel this should really be included. You receive a 20% discount on anything bought in the lounge as a hotel guest but still not very customer oriented if you ask me. All in all an amazing stay and will be back again when I am in Tokyo in a few months time.

Great quality in a great location. The ritz Tokyo is located in roppongi, close to the nightlife and connected to tokyo midtown, a retail/commercial complex with lots of shopping and restaurant options. Right in front of the hotel is a small park which is great for families. The rooms are large, luxurious and comfortable and service is typical of ritz-Carlton hotels worldwide. Overall my favorite place to stay when I'm in Tokyo.

I have stayed both of them many times. Both are great hotels and service is equally good. However, I ended up staying at Ritz Carlton more than Grand Hyatt because the room at Ritz Carlton is bigger and I like Ritz's gym facility better. Also, the restaurants and bars that I visit are nearer to Ritz. If you are using taxi then Ritz has a better chance of avoiding traffic jam as it has several ways to get to the hotel. For shopping, both locations have great shops but I think Mid Town has better selection of upper end items.

It's the Ritz, high prices and sky high expectations. With a reputation for delivering the best in hotel service, this hotel meets and exceeds even the highest expectations. But the thing that stands out is not the impeccable service or quality of everything in the hotel, it is the incredible views! The lobby is on the 45th floor and the rooms on floors above that.At check-in they offered a suite for a moderate increase in price per night. I asked to see the suite and was blown away by the incredible views from the corner suite. I calculated the extra cost and decided as much as I loved the suite, it was too much money. The prices advertised don't include tax and service fees the hotel charges. Those are extra fees I am used to in the States but hadn't seen in Japan. I decided against it and was told I could get the suite at price lower than the cost of the extra fees, so I took the suite. I am glad I did. Some amenities in the suite: an espresso machine; very deluxe Toto toilet system, incredible shower system separate from the soaking tub with television and views of Tokyo and the newly opened Skytree, and even a well stocked living room filled with quality magazines and books.It is in a wonderful location with excellent stores nearby, good restaurants, even a next-door cooking school, and the most amazing (and expensive) fruit store I have ever experienced. It is also only a block from the Roppongi area famous for a wild and somewhat sleazy night life.My recommendation is that if you are offered an upgrade to a suite, check it out and try to negotiate a good deal. Regardless, you will be in for a great view of Tokyo!

I stayed here for a week on a business/leisure trip and was totally blown away by the warm, sincere welcome of the staff. The concierge staff is exceptional. Kumiko arranged concert tickets in advance of our arrival into Tokyo. Along with this, she created a concert packet including an article about the performance and English translation on our tickets so we could find our seats! Since we travel one-bag (carry-on only), this means we have to do a load of laundry once or twice depending on the length of our trip. Many of the hotel guests were rock stars, business men, rich woman toting shopping bags, etc. and I was a little worried about the response I might get asking about a coin laundry place. Not only did they completely understand, they had a proper pre-printed map of a local place ready to go...apparently this is common for guests with longer stays.Our room had an excellent view of the city and sunset each night from the 45th floor. The tub was fantastic for soaking weary muscles in bath salts (which were replaced each night) after too much exploring. I also appreciated having separate sink stations in the bathroom, as well as a separate toilet room for privacy. There was a double shade arrangement (on remote) for privacy and then blackout. The lights in the room were controlled by a console on either side table of the bed; there were room lights, reading lights, and even subtle floor lights under the furniture so you could light a soft path to the bathroom in the middle of the night without waking up your partner. The desk was in a great location for being useful, and the room was spacious, well-appointed, and smartly laid out. I also loved the wallpaper that featured tiny fans in exquisite detail. The hotel location was excellent and we had bars, restaurants, and breakfast places (not common in Tokyo!) right outside our door. Best of all, the Hibiya line for the subway stopped right under the mall we were next door to, so getting out to explore was a snap.I would not have enjoyed our visit to Tokyo as much if it weren't for all of the staff at the Ritz and I highly recommend them.

Convenient location depending on where you want to go. Some find Shinjuku, Shibuya better but I've always loved staying at Roppongi, you're kind of away from it all but not far from them either. With Roppongi Hill and Midtown and the neighbourhoods nearby you've pretty much got everything you need.Visited not long after 3/11 and there was a concern on the use of energy by hotels so air con was supposedly turned lower. Wasn't too bad for me. Really loved this place for its convenience. The Airport Limousine bus also makes a stop here.

Stayed at the Ritz two weeks mid December. Very professionell crew, friendly and making you feel at home. General manager very supportive and present, helping where possible. Views spectacular, location ideal. Looking forward to a next stay. Highly recommended!

The Ritz Carlton Tokyo and the surrounding area:My first trip to Japan in Oktober 2011 started with a three night stay at the Ritz Carlton Hotel in Minato/Roppongi. After the long flight from Europe I wanted a luxurious base to explore this fascinating city. The Ritz Carlton sits on the top nine floors of the mixed-used Midtown office tower with 53 floors, currently the tallest building in Tokyo, situated in Roppongi Hills – a lively area with stylish boutiques, clubs, restaurants, the National Arts Centre and interesting galleries like the MA Gallery (This area is more fancy than Shinjuku and Shibuya and much more lively as the area around the Imperial Palace and Tokyo Station, which are a little boring and quiet in the evening).In the small but very elegant entry lobby at the ground floor the bellboys took my luggage to be sent to my room and led me to the elevators whisking me up to floor 45 where the spacious two-story main lobby and the several restaurants are located. Stunning views over the skyline of Tokyo.Because of the location atop the Midtown shopping centre you can reach the subway within minutes and also have a wide choice of elegant shops, bars, coffee and pastry-shops at your doorstep (wonderful variety and quality – as in Paris – but at least as expensive..)The Service:Smooth as silk check in, no problem to check in early and to get an upgrade.The service was faultless during my whole stay – friendly and professional. Good recommendations about sights, restaurants in the area and public transportation through the concierge. The Room:I had a reservation for a Deluxe Room and asked for a room with a view of Mount Fuji, but none was available, instead I was upgraded to a Tower Deluxe Room on floor 48 with a breathtaking view over the south of Tokyo, the bay and the Tokyo Tower through floor to ceiling windows. Later I had a look in a Mount Fuji View room, stunning on a clear day, but these days are rare in Tokyo! So I was very happy with the view of Tokyo Tower, impressively illuminated in the dark. Very spacious room (about 54 square metres), very elegant in the” Ritz Carlton Style” (more “old money” than “cutting edge” – if you prefer “cutting edge” have a look at the new Shangri La or the Peninsula).Gorgeous bathroom, spacious with wonderful large rain shower booth, Flat-TV and the famous TOTO toilet, which at first frightens the European with the many buttons and switches, but after some attempts of trying out, you will love it!As expected in a Ritz Carlton Hotel there is nothing to be missed in the room. Fantastic beds, ample storage space, an assortment of tea and coffee for the kettle, individual lightning, magazines, fresh flowers, fruits and all technical equipment you may need.The Food:Very expensive but absolutely comprehensive buffet-breakfast at the Towers Grill, a very elegant setting affording great views again through the floor to ceiling windows.The best bacon I have eaten in my whole life and an unusual wide fresh fruit selection.Lunch at the Hinokizaka Restaurant (1 * by Guide Michelin) was a memorable experience, but the bill brought tears to my eyes.All in all:The Ritz Carlton Tokyo is a very expensive hotel (expect to pay 650 US Dollars for one night without breakfast) – but it delivers well.Fantastic location for sightseeing with the subway 50 stories below, very stylish public areas, spacious rooms in a more conservative but tasteful style offering breathtaking views over Tokyo, professional and friendly service, nice spa/health-club with pool and great food at a high price.Things you have to see and to do:Do not miss the wonderful Senso-Ji Temple in Asakusa, the people-watching in Ueno Park, the Hama Rikyu Garden with the 300 year old pine tree, the Yoyogi Park with the stunning Meiji Shrine, the vast Shinjuku Gyoen Garden (wonderfully coloured leafs in autumn), great souvenir shopping at “Tokyo Hands” in Shibuya and a visit of the Tsukiji Fishmarket in the early morning. For the sweet tooth – try Kit Kat with wasabi flavour, sounds crazy – but I loved it!Taxis are very expensive, use the Airport Limousine shuttle and in Tokyo the subway instead.About Tokyo and the people:I thought about Tokyo as a crowded city full of nondescript skyscrapers and full of rushing, rejecting people. The truth is that Tokyo is one of the most fascinating cities I have ever travelled. It is colourful, full of energy, fashion conscious and stylish, the city is very clean and very safe, the food is to die for (and it is not only sushi!), the great parks and gardens let you breath, the atmosphere in the wonderful temples will calm you down, the architecture is stunning (in Ginza, where every square metre costs a fortune, you can admire how clever – and beautiful – modern architecture can use limited space).But what really makes Tokyo so special and unique are the people in Tokyo. I travel a lot around the world, but I have never met so many helpful, polite, civilized and friendly people as in Tokyo. Hope to return soon for a longer trip!

Just came back from a 11-day stay in the Ritz-Carlton in Tokyo. As the title of this review suggests, I had an awesome time staying here. I would definitely recommend it to anyone staying in Tokyo and will come back here again. LocationIt is located in Roppongi which was extremely convenient for me since its a short 10-minute walk to our office in Mori Tower. You can also access the train system through mid-town mall which is connected to the hotel. So we had no problem going to other places in and out of Tokyo. It is walking distance from lots of restaurants and bars in roppongi so we had no problem looking for a place to eat. Impressively, you either get a view of Mt. Fuji on a nice clear day or the Tokyo Tower (since they're on opposite sides of the hotel). ServiceThe service is top notch. The staff are so very respectful and helpful. They will run to push the elevator button when they see you head towards the elevators. They will always greet you when they see you and ask how you're doing. They have on several occasions given recommendations on where to eat and what to do and gave directions on how to get to places. You can also ask them to book the airport shuttle for you which was very convenient. On our last night, they gave us a small plate of truffles which I ate in under 10-minutes. Every night, I get back to find a card on my bed that tells me the forecast for tomorrow, e.g. 10% rain, and temperature high and low. There's three sets of channels to choose from, I personally enjoyed watching the Japanese shows but they also have a set of English channels that carry CNN, BBC, etc. If you stay, try the coffee they serve at the lobby. We always got a cup on our way to work. Its actually pretty good and extremely helpful in the cold. AmenitiesThe rooms are awesome. The bathroom is huge with a nice big and deep tub, toilet, shower and his and hers sink. The algae salt they have were so good that I took more baths than usual (I usually just take a shower). The TV in the bathroom was convenient for when I took my baths. The toiletries they include are better than the travel ones I bring with me from home. The curtain can be controlled by switched on your bedside table. And since the hotel starts at the 45th floor, rooms have pretty good views of Tokyo.

The famous Japanese hospitality was in full display during my stay at the Ritz Carlton in Tokyo. This was a business trip and the hotel was close to my work place plus the location is bang in middle of the Roppongi area, a happening night spot. The hotel building had a mall underneath and subway lines. Also an excellent Starbucks right outside. The room itself was on 50 floor which provided a fantastic view. Every little need had been taken care of - I did not need to unpack most of my stuff. All toiletries were in the room. They had fresh comfy pyjamas available every day. The bathroom was as big as most other hotel rooms :)I recommend using the Airport Limousine Bus service. Its inexpensive and comfortable way to & from the airport and stops right in front of the hotel lobby.This was by far my best experience staying in a business hotel. They had catered to every need a business traveller will have.

This is an outstanding hotel, the service is impeccable, the club level worth the extra price, and rooms immaculate. All around - setting the pace for Ritz Carlton world-wide. I wish the other Ritz locations would take notice. Each experience with the team began and ended with the customer needs - not excuses. Expect to want to return!

Stayed at a club level room over a weekend - as others have noted, it is worth the splurge (the food was good and I probably wound up saving money by taking meals there). I stayed at both the Ritz and the Conrad during my stay in Tokyo and would absolutely pick the Ritz for the following reasons:1) Spectacular lobby - OK, both lobbies are amazing, but the Ritz's, with its Tokyo hi-so crowd, classical grand piano, and jaw-dropping views of the city was a cut above the Conrad and imbued a real sense of place.2) Gym facilities were probably the best I've seen in any hotel, anywhere.3) LOCATION. At the swanky Tokyo Midtown complex in Roppongi - this location is absolutely the middle of Tokyo and the Midtown and Roppongi Hills complexes are brand-new palaces of shopping and restaurants. The Roppongi area is particularly fun if you are looking to go out and party (yes, I am probably younger than the average Ritz-going customer so this may not be a concern for everyone...). The Conrad's location near Tokyo bay was great if you wanted to be in the business district of Shiodome but was totally dead at night.4). Service. This was Ritz service and details through and through - the little touches like Nespresso coffee makers in the rooms, the friendly greetings, etc were definitely better than the Conrad, which felt more like a high-end corporate hotel (think the W).5) Giant, well-appointed bathrooms. As others have mentioned - two vanities, separate shower and bathtub, etc.6) Views. Amazing views from every part of the hotel.Where the Conrad was better:1) Room decor. The Conrad rooms were modern, masculine, and sexy. The Ritz's were a bit vanilla but still very comfortable.

My colleague told me this might be the best hotel in Tokyo. And the first step into my room, I got hit by the night view though the large window.It was amazing 3 nights in Ritz. Everything was satisfying. You can get a big room (very rare from hotels in Japan), perfect service, comfortable bed and bath beautiful Roppongi night view. They even have a big indoor swimming pool free of charge.

The Ritz Carlton Tokyo is a gem. It may not be the flashiest hotel in town, but it is extremely comfortable, well appointed (check out the beautifully designed porcelain tea set for guest use), and well run. The service is excellent and accommodating, and the rooms are reasonably spacious with a sublime bathroom and amenities (Japanese toilets! Bliss). We stayed in a Club level room with our small son, and it was well worth the splurge. The Club lounge is fabulous - relaxing, with a good selection of food and drink 24 hours a day and, weather permitting, a wonderful view of Mount Fuji. Unfortunately our son got sick and we couldn't explore the surrounding area as much as we would have liked, but the fact that having had to spend most of our time in the room wasn't a hardship confirms my positive impression of this hoteI. I definitely recommend it.

I recently stayed here for 4 nights in a one bedroom corner suite with my husband and young daughter and had a fabulous time. The first impression on walking into the room was OMG look at the view and believe me from the corner suite that is all you see with Mount Fuji on the horizon. The bathroom is everyone's dream double sinks, tv, a private toilet cubicle with a heated toilet seat/control panel and a power shower. The bedroom was very nice too and we enjoyed nights of fabulous sleep. Personally I felt the suite was let down a little by the furniture in the living room it wasn't so great and looked much older than the 4 yrs but with the view continually distracting us it didn't seem to matter so much.There were all the luxuries you would expect from this kind of hotel even down to complimentary pyjamas stowed in the drawer. House keeping was fabulous our supplies/towels/toiletries were constantly replenished throughout the day. One morning I had reason to return back to the room and as I walked in all I could only think was it looks like a major spring cleaning is going on rather than the remaking of the bed. Two small things that my husband and I both thought would have made things perfect would to have had milk or cream in the fridge rather than the powdered coffee mate provided... The hotel has obviously gone to the great expense of installing very expensive coffee machines but then spoilt the effort with powdered milk. Also perhaps the addition of one or two more English tv channels would be very welcome by guests.We booked our room through a travel agent so it came as a shock/ big disappointment to us that having a suite costing over $1000 a night didn't entitled us to have use of the club lounge or as we discovered the next morning include breakfast. The continental breakfast we experienced was a huge let down and certainly not worth the money. If breakfast isn't included in your rate I'd strongly suggest eating out at other nearby cafes/outletsThe rest of the foods/drinks/service we had in the lounge were all excellent and couldn't be faulted. As to our other experiences with members of staff we approached, whether it was a doorman, front desk clerk or concierge we found them all extremely helpful and willing to assist. The hotel is linked to the Midtown Plaza which we found very useful for shopping, restaurants and the metro system. Getting to Disneyland was a breeze once we figured out how the system worked.Would I return to this hotel? In a heartbeat but not at the price we paid for basically a room only package it wasn't worth it. I would take a smaller room that enjoys the club lounge benefits which according to the web site includes complimentary internet, five complimentary food and beverage presentations a day plus access to the gym and pool it seems a much better option.

One of the best five star hotels we have stayed.. customer service in Japan is as expected really high and Ritz's service is excellent. The view from the room is just too incredible.. we practically slept under the Tokyo skyline at night. The location of the hotel is very strategic as it is next to the Tokyo Midtown shopping centre. Great and memorable stay!
I asked for a high floor and got 52nd floor, loved the view! Very nice room with big bathroom and TV in it! Nice stuff, friendly and helpful

Don't know what to add. I love this place. So I'll try and comment on some other things:Concierge: Really helpful. I wish I remember her name, she was totally cool. And she didn't turn up her nose when I wanted an authentic and cheap ramen place, nor when I asked her about a coin laundromat. (I can't bring myself to pay twice what my underwear cost to get them washed. Hotels are so silly this way still).Gym: It's kinda lame that they charge extra to use the locker room at the gym. I know it's a spa and all that, but really, at $500+ a night for rooms, you can't let your guests use the gym lockers without dinging them another 2,500 yen? Staying at the Hyatt Roppongi Hills the week before, I was impressed by how they went out of their way to sign me up to the Hyatt Gold Club just so I could enjoy their lockers and spa. The Ritz could learn from this.Lobby lounge: Because its a destination itself it didn't seem very inviting to the regular guests. After a day of work or sights it came across as stuffy. I felt like I needed a top hat and monocle.****Hotels can't be perfect for everyone and I was being critical above to add something new to the conversation. Overall, if you've got the means, or want to splurge, this is an amazing hotel.

This Hotel is a real modern palace but the views it offers You beat everything in the hotel! the service the rooms, the beds everythinng is perfect but when you look outside the window you forget everything around...:) priceless experience
A true five star hotel in every sense. All the rooms (I think) have stunning views over Tokyo and the hotel is just a short walk to some of the main shopping areas. Incredible food too.

From the moment I walked in I felt special. Everyone greeting and welcoming you to the Ritz with smiling faces.When I went to check in I was told my room was no longer available which made me a little angry as had paid extra for views of Tokyo Tower but before I could open my mouth to complain I was told I had been upgraded free of charge.Our upgrade room was a suite on the 49 floor. The suite consisted of a corner living room with floor to roof windows over the city. The room had a great desk area with internet cable a sofa, chair, table and mega flat screen tv.The bedroom had a window as the whole outside wall which had views of the city and mount Fuji from the bed. The bed was very comfortable with additional pillows in the cupboards if you wanted them (the bed had four massive ones to start with. Another huge tv on a set of drawers. The blinds lights etc can be controlled directly from your bed so great when you wake up.The bathroom was huge. It had an amazing showers bundles of towels and a massive bath big enough for two people. If you happened to run out of towels an evening turn down services was on offer if you wanted.The whole room was spotless and the cleaning staff had kept it in very good condition.The hotel follows suit and is kept to the highest standards. The restaurant which we had breakfast in had stunning views over the city. My only moan about the who stay in the hotel was the breakfast. Some items such as bacon and sausages were cold. Im sure they would heat them for you but was a huge issue so didnt bother.The hotel is located centrally in Roppongi which is great for a night on the town if not a little seedy. Its right ontop of a shopping centre and 5mins walk to the Mori Tower but really dont see the need to see as the views from the hotel are stunning and worth every penny for a special occasion.

The views from this hotels are amazing and on a clear day you can see Fuji. The rooms were massive (especially for Tokyo standards) and the bathrooms are huge. The desk area is very practical and the bed extremely comfortable. From a room perspective, this place was well worth the money. The biggest disappointment for me was the service. The Ritz is usually known for their outstanding service and in this area the front desk staff was lacking. I called the hotel in the morning to ask for an early check-in and they said it was possible; however, when I got to the hotel it was no longer and option and I had to wait. I realize that early check-in is not guaranteed but if they say something they need to live up to it. Also, I like to stay on the upper levels of the hotel and requested a room on a high floor and was given a room on the second floor of the hotel (which was 47 stories up) and was disappointed with the flippant response from the front desk staff which said all rooms are high here. The other disappointment for me was the gym. I was told that my room rate included gym access and when I went down to use the sauna- I was told it wasn't included which was disappointing. When i mentioned these complaints to the front desk manager, I was effectively brushed off.

I stayed here with my family for one night before travelling up to Nagano and it was amazing. Great views of the city from the sky lobby. Great staff, very helpful and very comfortable rooms with all the amenities. Great bar as well! Would love to come back!

The previous reviewers have detailed how great this place is.The view from my 51st floor room was incredible - the whole city sprawling out below the window.Super comfortable room with fab bathroom, practical desk area, giant TV, great bed, charming service - all in all a properly 5 star hotel. Loads of attention to detail which extended to the rest of the hotel including the nice touch of a free coffee station off the main lift lobby with cups and lids etc to go. I ordered toast for breakfast and when it came the waiter asked me to check the temperature of the toast in case I wanted them to warm it up more with the toaster that they brought up with them just in case. First time that has happened to me!Service most places in Tokyo is charming but this place has the edge on the competition.Will definitely go again - it has certainly set the standard for others.

Everything is great - the bathroom is huge, and I have heard its the most earthquake proof building in Tokyo. Anyway, you can't go wrong here - except on price. I went for business in May 2011 and it was $400 ish a night, in November it was $1500+ so I am staying elsewhere.
user_name:
Dan H
New York City, New York

review_body: I knew I was in for the Lost in Translation experience when staff actually walked in front of me (while constantly saying "welcome, welcome") to activate the automatic doors. Yup the automatic doors. Then there was seemingly every member of staff in the hotel standing around in the lobby all saying hello as if they were waiting for us. Very impressive but also slightly unnerving to someone not used to such levels of service. The room was in a nutshell gobsmackingly amazing. With views of Yoyogi park and the various skyscrapers of Shinjuku and even (on the last day which had a clear morning) views of Mt Fuji! Everything automated including the curtains while the massive bathroom had a separate TV which meant long periods in the bath drinking tea whilst watching crazy Japanese television. Bliss. The hotel is about 40 - 45 floors up and includes a swimming pool even further up which was interesting when swimming and looking out to see nothing but clouds floating past. Again the service here was impeccable. Then there were the little touches including a little card presented after evening turndown telling you about tomorrow's weather for example. Those little touches make all the difference.

We stayed on the 53rd floor at the Ritz and the view was just incredible. The Sky Lobby is another highlight, with the same views and a fantastic selection of whiskies.We ate at the Kutani the night before we left, which was a mix of fantastic food and intimate dining with personalised service from Chef Yoshida. Highly recommended.

This may be the nicest hotel that I have ever stayed in. The rooms have amazing views. The food is spectacular. The bathrooms are huge and luxurious. The pool is very nice. The gym is as good as in any hotel I have ever seen. Really a nice hotel. And the location is spectacular, in the heart of the nightlife district and where a lot of the office buildings are. Some of the staff could speak a little better English (or another foreign language), but they were certainly very helpful in getting me baseball tickets. In sum, an exceptional hotel.

Stayed here this month for 6 days and have to say I was very impressed with the hotel overall. It is in the Minato-ku / Midtown area of Tokyo and quite central. The rooms are quite classical which is not really to my taste, I prefer a little more modern decor but it was new, clean and done tastefully. From the moment you arrive you won't have to worry about a thing, every tiny detail is handled for you from the amenities in your bathroom, the subtle fragrance wafting through your floor to your food allergies and idiosyncratic requests. I stayed with relatives and their children who had children's cutlery and crockery provided at each meal time in room or in restaurant without prompting along with tiny bathrobes and slippers. Restaurants are excellent, breakfast buffet is comprehensive and high tea is lovely.Very friendly and accommodating staff who speak english with no problem at all. This is a great hotel for business or couples because it has the level of service you need / want on these occasions. In saying that if you take your family your children will be well looked after so this place gets my highest recommendation. If you are looking for a more Japanese experience then perhaps look somewhere else, this is very culturally neutral so not right if you want to immerse yourself in Japan but great if you need to know you can get things done without the typical Japanese obstacles.

The rooms are large with magnificient view and comfy beds! One of the best rooms I think for standart rooms. You can actually see the TokyoTower .The rooms here starts at higher floors (i think 50th above). The bathrooms are also huge with tv near the tub and with amenities by Remede. The hotel is located @Roppongi area, near mrt station. Surroundings the hotel, there are a lot of restaurants and bars at night. Adjacent to the hotel is a small size mall with many small restaurants and a supermarket.( i think open 24 hours) and Starbuck. Behind the hotel, there is a small park. The hotel service are excelent.

There are many different types of accommodation in Tokyo and if you want something that is a cultural experience then the Ritz wouldn't be the best choice but if you are are on business, cost isn't too much of an issue and you want a very comfortable bed and great facilities, then there is really only one choice, the Ritz ( there is also the ANA but in reality they are poles apart).Getting from the airport to Tokyo is always an expensive exercise unless you take the train or a shuttle - both of which are efficient once you have worked out what you are doing - and the car service from the Ritz is exorbitant. Reception is on the 45th floor along with a lounge. The smoky smell is off putting but this is Tokyo. Check in is efficient.The rooms are fantastic. Huge by Tokyo standards (I'd estimate at least 3 times larger than the last room I had at the ANA) and as you'd expect luxuriously appointed. Huge windows with a panoramic view of Tokyo.From service menu was surprisingly small but not as exorbitantly expensive as I anticipated, unless you wanted the special burger with foie gras which by my calculations cost three figures - not surprisingly i passed on that so I can't give you a review :(I used the pool and was very glad I did, would recommend it.Service as you'd expect is top notch.Free wi- fi. Thank you Ritz!Summary - very nice. Very pricey. But most things are n Tokyo.So in short

I spent 5 nights at this hotel as it's close to our office and I have to say on the back of the previous reviews I was expecting a lot and I was not disappointed! Perfectly situated on top of an office complex in Roppongi you're first 'wow' moment will come at the floor to ceiling windows and the view from the 45th floor reception/lounge/restaurant area..wow!! Apparently this is the highest building in Tokyo and considering how many skyscrapers there are here I was surprised to see us towering over most of them. Did I mention the view? (hehe)I arrived late at night and check in was smooth, courteous and very efficient. I know some colleagues that arrived in the morning or even early afternoon had to wait to get their rooms but I was escorted up to my room on the 47th floor within 5-6 mins of arriving.Room:- When I walked in I was surprised by the size of the room and of course the night view at the enormous panoramic window at the end of the room. I'd read that rooms in Tokyo are typically on the smaller size but this 'standard' room was quite large and the bathroom absolutely enormous with full size rainshower, two separate sink/basin areas and a huge deep-soaking tub. Gadget fans will get a kick out of the 'command center' next to the futuristic toilet (common in Japan) and the in-bathroom TV etc.- Overall the room is well laid out, functional and comfortable. The bed was superb and I slept VERY well during my stay (apart from the jet lag.)Food:- I didn't tend to eat in as the prices are exorbitant but the few meals I did have including the breakfast buffet in the mornings was very nice. The food was flavourful, nicely presented and ticked all the boxes but the price is very hard to get past (think USD$100+ for a 2-course room service dinner!)Tip: If you don't mind an evening drink or two, instead of raiding the hideously overpriced mini bar, pop down to the 'food court' under the hotel complex as there is a 7-Eleven that sells everything from snacks to beers etc that you can just pop in the fridge for the duration of your stay.Facilities:- I worked out in the gym on the 46th floor most mornings and it was a great setup. A large room with comprehensive machines, free weights, and cardio machines. Due to jetlag I was typically in there very early in the morning so not too many people around so never a wait etc. The gym is accompanied by a large indoor pool and jacuzzi area which again was fairly quiet. Staff and attendants were everywhere and always had bottled water, towels etc at the ready.Pro's:- Location is amazing and a walk away from the energy of Roppongi- Very high quality 'everything' from the fittings, to the lounges, to the gym, room, bed etc..you will feel very pampered.- Very quiet rooms! (barely heard any noise on either side of me or above me..a rarity!!)Cons:- Of course the prices! If I was a leisure traveller and not on a corporate rate there is no way I could justify staying here. If the room rate didn't kill me, the 'incidentals' would..Even for Japan, this hotel is expensive.- The internet connectivity was flaky at best. All my colleagues complained of the same intermittent connectivity in their rooms and public areas. Luckily this was included in our rate or I would be very sore about having to pay for it.Summary:- This an incredible hotel that is well deserving of all the glowing reviews. Well situated and incredibly luxurious if you are looking to be spoiled/pampered while staying in the bustling area of Roppongi, then its hard to look past the Ritz Carlton. You will not be disappointed!

Spent 5 nights at this hotel, which were made quite pleasant by the high luxury standard of the hotel amenities, the friendliness of the staff and the overall quality of the service. The hotel is very well located above the Tokyo Midtown commercial complex (with many fine restaurants and shops), with access on foot to the vibrant Roppongi night-life and within a few minutes by metro to many of Tokyo's attractions. The hotel occupies the top 7 floors of a commercial tower and all rooms have a spectacular view overlooking one side of the city. From our room, we could see mount Fuji on a clear day! The beautiful rooms are quite spacious, even by western standards. The amenities are among the best among Tokyo's luxury hotels, while the Ritz trumps many others with better taste when it comes to its interior decoration and furniture. Although the hotel has been in operation for 5 years, everything still looks new. All rooms have a modern 42" LCD TV which can be connected to a PC, in addition to a DVD player.The downside of the Ritz is of course the price. All that luxury doesn't come cheap and you feel it whenever you order anything extra. In-room dining is extremely expensive considering the size/quality/price compared to what you get a few floors below in Midtown. The breakfast buffet is pricey but very good. In-room breakfast is an expensive joke in comparison! The other thing I noticed is that air circulation in the room may not be very effective, considering that you cannot open any windows. The A/C system is very effective and extremely silent yet I'm not sure if it actually draws fresh air from outside or simply recirculates the air in the room. Having said that, not at any moment did it feel or smell 'stuffy' anywhere in the hotel. Overall a very nice hotel and definitely worth the money if you wish to pamper yourself!

We arrived at the club lounge to check in at lunch time and sat down with the most amazing views and complimentary canape buffet selections which were all well presented along with this unusual tasty cold green milky tea which was absolutely superb. Then they checked us in with our rooms and the rooms were amazing with views of the city and amazing facilities and service. I highly recommend this hotel.

The hotel room is very impressive with spacious layout, flat-screen TV, comfortable beds and excellently equipped bathroom. The Tokyo view outside of my window is breathtaking. Room levels are quiet. As any other 5-star hotels in Tokyo, in-room dining has limited choice and all their restaurants are very expensive ($100 set menu for lunch?). But fortunately right next door there's a sizable shopping mall with good and reasonably-priced restaurants to choose from. I enjoy the diversity to choose from.
